Text

CHAPTER I. In [[the county town]211-the county town of [a certain shire]213-a certain shire]212-the county town of a certain shire there lived ( about forty years ago ) [one Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , [a conveyancing attorney of considerable standing]214-a conveyancing attorney of considerable standing . [The certain shire]215-the certain shire was but [a small county]216-a small county , and [the principal town in [it]215-the certain shire contained [only about four thousand inhabitants]218-only about four thousand inhabitants]217-the principal town in it contained only about four thousand inhabitants ; so in saying that [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was [the principal lawyer in [Hamley]1-hamley]219-the principal lawyer in hamley , [I]0-i say very little , unless [I]0-i add that [he]66-mr. wilkins transacted all the legal business of [the gentry]220-the gentry for twenty miles round . [[His]66-mr. wilkins grandfather]221-his grandfather had established the connection ; [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father had consolidated and strengthened it , and , indeed , by [his]66-mr. wilkins wise and upright conduct , as well as by [his]66-mr. wilkins professional skill , had obtained for [himself]66-mr. wilkins the position of [confidential friend to [many of [the surrounding families of distinction]225-the surrounding families of distinction]224-many of the surrounding families of distinction]223-confidential friend to many of the surrounding families of distinction . [He]66-mr. wilkins visited among [them]224-many of the surrounding families of distinction in a way which [no mere lawyer]226-no mere lawyer had ever done before ; dined at [their]224-many of the surrounding families of distinction tables -- [he]66-mr. wilkins alone , not accompanied by [[his]66-mr. wilkins wife]227-his wife , be it observed ; rode to the meet occasionally as if by accident , although [he]66-mr. wilkins was as well mounted as [any squire among [them]224-many of the surrounding families of distinction]228-any squire among them , and was often persuaded ( after a little coquetting about " professional engagements , "[227-his wife] and " being wanted at the office "[227-his wife] ) to have a run with [[his]66-mr. wilkins clients]229-his clients ; nay , once or twice [he]66-mr. wilkins forgot [his]66-mr. wilkins usual caution , was first in at the death , and rode [home]230-home with the brush . But in general [he]66-mr. wilkins knew [his]66-mr. wilkins place ; as [his]66-mr. wilkins place was held to be in [that aristocratic county]231-that aristocratic county , and in those days . Nor let be supposed that [he]66-mr. wilkins was in any way [a toadeater]232-a toadeater . [He]66-mr. wilkins respected [himself]66-mr. wilkins too much for that . [He]66-mr. wilkins would give the most unpalatable advice , if need were ; would counsel an unsparing reduction of expenditure to [an extravagant man]233-an extravagant man ; would recommend such an abatement of family pride as paved the way for one or two happy marriages in some instances ; nay , what was the most likely piece of conduct of all to give offence forty years ago , [he]66-mr. wilkins would speak up for [an unjustly - used tenant]234-an unjustly - used tenant ; and that with so much temperate and well - timed wisdom and good feeling , that [he]66-mr. wilkins more than once gained [his]66-mr. wilkins point . [He]66-mr. wilkins had [one son]235-one son , [Edward]66-mr. wilkins . [This boy]236-this boy was the secret joy and pride of [[his]236-this boy father]222-his father 's heart . For [himself]66-mr. wilkins [he]66-mr. wilkins was not in the least ambitious , but it did cost [him]66-mr. wilkins a hard struggle to acknowledge that [his]66-mr. wilkins own business was too lucrative , and brought in too large an income , to pass away into the hands of [a stranger]238-a stranger , as it would do if [he]66-mr. wilkins indulged [his]66-mr. wilkins ambition for [[his]66-mr. wilkins son]239-his son by giving [him]239-his son a college education and making [him]239-his son into [a barrister]240-a barrister . This determination on the more prudent side of the argument took place while [Edward]66-mr. wilkins was at [Eton]2-eton . [The lad]241-the lad had , perhaps , the largest allowance of pocket - money of [any boy at school]242-any boy at school ; and [he]66-mr. wilkins had always looked forward to going to [Christ Church]3-christ church along with [[his]66-mr. wilkins fellows]243-his fellows , [the sons of [the squires]245-the squires]244-the sons of the squires , [[[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's employers]247-his father 's employers . It was a severe mortification to [him]66-mr. wilkins to find that [his]66-mr. wilkins destiny was changed , and that [he]66-mr. wilkins had to return to [Hamley]1-hamley to be articled to [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father , and to assume the hereditary subservient position to [lads whom [he]66-mr. wilkins had licked in the play - ground]249-lads whom he had licked in the play - ground , and beaten at learning . [[His]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father tried to compensate [him]66-mr. wilkins for the disappointment by every indulgence which money could purchase . [Edward]66-mr. wilkins 's horses were even finer than those of [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father ; [his]66-mr. wilkins literary tastes were kept up and fostered , by [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's permission to form [an extensive library]253-an extensive library , for which purpose [a noble room was added to [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's already extensive house]255-mr. wilkins 's already extensive house in [the suburbs of [Hamley]1-hamley]256-the suburbs of hamley]254-a noble room was added to mr. wilkins 's already extensive house in the suburbs of hamley . And after [his]66-mr. wilkins year of legal study in [London]4-london [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father sent [him]66-mr. wilkins to make the grand tour , with something very like carte blanche as to expenditure , to judge from the packages which were sent [home]230-home from [various parts of [the Continent]5-the continent]259-various parts of the continent . At last [he]66-mr. wilkins came [home]230-home -- came back to settle as [[[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's partner at [Hamley]1-hamley]262-his father 's partner at hamley . [He]66-mr. wilkins was [a son to be proud of]263-a son to be proud of , and right down proud was [old Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins of [[his]66-mr. wilkins handsome , accomplished , gentlemanly lad]264-his handsome , accomplished , gentlemanly lad . For [Edward]66-mr. wilkins was not one to be spoilt by the course of indulgence [he]66-mr. wilkins had passed through ; at least , if it had done [him]66-mr. wilkins an injury , the effects were at present hidden from view . [He]66-mr. wilkins had no vulgar vices ; [he]66-mr. wilkins was , indeed , rather too refined for [the society [he]66-mr. wilkins was likely to be thrown into , even supposing that society to consist of the highest of [[his]66-mr. wilkins father 's employers]247-his father 's employers]265-the society he was likely to be thrown into , even supposing that society to consist of the highest of his father 's employers . [He]66-mr. wilkins was well read , and [an artist of no mean pretensions]267-an artist of no mean pretensions . Above all , " [his]66-mr. wilkins heart was in the right place , "[222-his father] as [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father used to observe . Nothing could exceed the deference [he]66-mr. wilkins always showed to [him]66-mr. wilkins . [[His]66-mr. wilkins mother]269-his mother had long been dead . [I]0-i do not know whether it was [Edward]66-mr. wilkins 's own ambition or [[his]66-mr. wilkins proud father]270-his proud father 's wishes that had led [him]66-mr. wilkins to attend the [Hamley]1-hamley assemblies . [I]0-i should conjecture [the latter]271-the latter , for [Edward]66-mr. wilkins had of [himself]66-mr. wilkins too much good taste to wish to intrude into [any society]272-any society . In the opinion of all [the shire]273-the shire , [no society]274-no society had more reason to consider [itself]274-no society select than that which met at every full moon in [the Hamley assembly - room]275-the hamley assembly - room , an excrescence built on to [the principal inn in [the town]277-the town by the joint subscription of [all the county families]278-all the county families]276-the principal inn in the town by the joint subscription of all the county families . Into [those choice and mysterious precincts [no towns person]280-no towns person]279-those choice and mysterious precincts no towns person was ever allowed to enter ; [no professional man]281-no professional man might set [his]281-no professional man foot therein ; [no infantry officer]282-no infantry officer saw the interior of [that ball]283-that ball , or [that card - room]284-that card - room . [The old original subscribers]285-the old original subscribers would fain have had [a man]286-a man prove [his]286-a man sixteen quarterings before [he]286-a man might make [his]286-a man bow to [the queen of the night]287-the queen of the night ; but [the old original founders of the Hamley assemblies]288-the old original founders of the hamley assemblies were dropping off ; minuets had vanished with [them]288-the old original founders of the hamley assemblies , country dances had died away ; quadrilles were in high vogue -- nay , [one or two of [the high magnates of [---shire]6----shire]290-the high magnates of ---shire]289-one or two of the high magnates of ---shire were trying to introduce waltzing , as [they]289-one or two of the high magnates of ---shire had seen it in [London]4-london , where it had come in with the visit of [the allied sovereigns]291-the allied sovereigns , when [Edward Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins made [his]66-mr. wilkins _ debut _ on these boards . [He]66-mr. wilkins had been at many splendid assemblies abroad , but still [the little old ballroom attached to [the George Inn]293-the george inn in [[his]66-mr. wilkins [native town]295-native town]294-his native town]292-the little old ballroom attached to the george inn in his native town was to [him]66-mr. wilkins [a place grander and more awful than [the most magnificent saloons [he]66-mr. wilkins had seen in [Paris]7-paris or [Rome]8-rome]297-the most magnificent saloons he had seen in paris or rome]296-a place grander and more awful than the most magnificent saloons he had seen in paris or rome . [He]66-mr. wilkins laughed at [himself]66-mr. wilkins for this unreasonable feeling of awe ; but there it was notwithstanding . [He]66-mr. wilkins had been dining at [the house of]298-the house of [one of [the lesser gentry]300-the lesser gentry , who was under considerable obligations to [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father , and who was [the parent of [eight " muckle - mou'ed "[66-mr. wilkins] daughters]303-eight " muckle - mou'ed " daughters]302-the parent of eight " muckle - mou'ed " daughters , so hardly likely to oppose much aristocratic resistance to [the elder Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's]299-one of the lesser gentry , who was under considerable obligations to his father , and who was the parent of eight " muckle - mou'ed " daughters , so hardly likely to oppose much aristocratic resistance to the elder mr. wilkins 's clearly implied wish that [Edward]66-mr. wilkins should be presented at [the Hamley assembly - rooms]304-the hamley assembly - rooms . But [many a squire]305-many a squire glowered and looked black at the introduction of [[Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins [the attorney]307-the attorney 's son]306-wilkins the attorney 's son into [the sacred precincts]308-the sacred precincts ; and perhaps there would have been much more mortification than pleasure in this assembly to [the young man]309-the young man , had it not been for an incident that occurred pretty late in the evening . [The lord - lieutenant of [the county]311-the county]310-the lord - lieutenant of the county usually came with a large party to the [Hamley]1-hamley assemblies once in a season ; and this night [he]66-mr. wilkins was expected , and with [him]66-mr. wilkins [a fashionable duchess]312-a fashionable duchess and [[her]312-a fashionable duchess daughters]313-her daughters . But time wore on , and [they]314-their did not make [their]314-their appearance . At last there was a rustling and a bustling , and in sailed [the superb party]315-the superb party . For a few minutes dancing was stopped ; [the earl]316-the earl led [the duchess]317-the duchess to a sofa ; [some of [[their]314-their acquaintances]319-their acquaintances]318-some of their acquaintances came up to speak to [them]314-their ; and then [the quadrilles]320-the quadrilles were finished in rather a flat manner . A country dance followed , in which [none of [the lord - lieutenant]322-the lord - lieutenant 's party]321-none of the lord - lieutenant 's party joined ; then there was a consultation , a request , an inspection of [the dancers]323-the dancers , a message to [the orchestra]324-the orchestra , and [the band]325-the band struck up a waltz ; [[the duchess]317-the duchess 's daughters]327-the duchess 's daughters flew off to the music , and [some more young ladies]328-some more young ladies seemed ready to follow , but , alas ! there was a lack of [gentlemen acquainted with the new - fashioned dance]329-gentlemen acquainted with the new - fashioned dance . [One of [the stewards]331-the stewards]330-one of the stewards bethought [him]330-one of the stewards of [young Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , only just returned from [the Continent]332-the continent . [Edward]66-mr. wilkins was [a beautiful dancer]333-a beautiful dancer , and waltzed to admiration . For [[his]66-mr. wilkins next partner]334-his next partner [he]66-mr. wilkins had [one of [the Lady ---s]336-the lady ---s]335-one of the lady ---s ; for [the duchess]317-the duchess , to whom [the -- shire squires]338-the -- shire squires and [their]338-the -- shire squires little county politics and contempts were alike unknown , saw no reason why [[her]317-the duchess lovely Lady Sophy]339-her lovely lady sophy should not have [a good partner]340-a good partner , whatever [his]66-mr. wilkins pedigree might be , and begged [the stewards]331-the stewards to introduce [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins to [her]317-the duchess . After this night [his]66-mr. wilkins fortune was made with [the young ladies of [the [Hamley]1-hamley assemblies]343-the hamley assemblies]342-the young ladies of the hamley assemblies . [He]66-mr. wilkins was not unpopular with [the mammas]344-the mammas ; but [the heavy squires]345-the heavy squires still looked at [him]66-mr. wilkins askance , and [the heirs]346-the heirs ( whom [he]66-mr. wilkins had licked at [Eton]2-eton ) called [him]66-mr. wilkins an upstart behind [his]66-mr. wilkins back . CHAPTER II . It was not a satisfactory situation . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had given [[his]66-mr. wilkins son]239-his son an education and tastes beyond [his]239-his son position . [He]66-mr. wilkins could not associate with either profit or pleasure with [the doctor]348-the doctor or [the brewer of [Hamley]1-hamley]349-the brewer of hamley ; [the vicar]350-the vicar was old and deaf , [the curate]351-the curate [a raw young man]352-a raw young man , half frightened at the sound of [his]351-the curate own voice . Then , as to matrimony -- for the idea of [his]66-mr. wilkins marriage was hardly more present in [Edward]66-mr. wilkins 's mind than in that of [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father -- [he]66-mr. wilkins could scarcely fancy bringing home [any one of [the young ladies of [Hamley]1-hamley]355-the young ladies of hamley to [the elegant mansion]356-the elegant mansion , so full of suggestion and association to [an educated person]357-an educated person , so inappropriate a dwelling for [an ignorant , uncouth , ill - brought - up girl]358-an ignorant , uncouth , ill - brought - up girl]354-any one of the young ladies of hamley to the elegant mansion , so full of suggestion and association to an educated person , so inappropriate a dwelling for an ignorant , uncouth , ill - brought - up girl . Yet [Edward]66-mr. wilkins was fully aware , if [[his]66-mr. wilkins fond father]359-his fond father was not , that of all [the young ladies who were glad enough of [him]66-mr. wilkins as [a partner at [the Hamley assemblies]343-the hamley assemblies]361-a partner at the hamley assemblies]360-the young ladies who were glad enough of him as a partner at the hamley assemblies , there was not of [them]360-the young ladies who were glad enough of him as a partner at the hamley assemblies but would have considered [herself]363-herself affronted by an offer of marriage from [an attorney]364-an attorney , [the son and grandson of [attorneys]366-attorneys]365-the son and grandson of attorneys . [The young man]309-the young man had perhaps received many a slight and mortification pretty quietly during these years , which yet told upon [his]309-the young man character in after life . Even at this very time they were having their effect . [He]309-the young man was of too sweet a disposition to show resentment , as [many men]368-many men would have done . But nevertheless [he]309-the young man took a secret pleasure in the power which [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's money gave [him]309-the young man . [He]309-the young man would buy an expensive horse after five minutes ' conversation as to the price , about which [a needy heir of one of [the proud county families]371-the proud county families]370-a needy heir of one of the proud county families had been haggling for three weeks . [His]309-the young man dogs were from [the best kennels in [England]9-england]372-the best kennels in england , no matter at what cost ; [his]309-the young man guns were the newest and most improved make ; and all these were expenses on objects which were among those of daily envy to [the squires]245-the squires and [[squires]374-squires ' sons]375-squires ' sons around . [They]376-they did not much care for the treasures of art , which report said were being accumulated in [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's house]377-mr. wilkins 's house . But [they]376-they did covet the horses and hounds [he]309-the young man possessed , and [the young man]309-the young man knew that [they]376-they coveted , and rejoiced in it . By - and - by [he]309-the young man formed a marriage , which went as near as marriages ever do towards pleasing [everybody]379-everybody . [He]309-the young man was desperately in love with [Miss Lamotte]67-miss lamotte , so [he]309-the young man was delighted when [she]67-miss lamotte consented to be [[his]309-the young man wife]227-his wife . [[His]309-the young man father]222-his father was delighted in [his]309-the young man delight , and , besides , was charmed to remember that [[Miss Lamotte]67-miss lamotte 's mother]382-miss lamotte 's mother had been [[Sir Frank Holster]68-sir frank holster 's younger sister]383-sir frank holster 's younger sister , and that , although [her]382-miss lamotte 's mother marriage had been disowned by [[her]382-miss lamotte 's mother family]384-her family , as beneath [her]382-miss lamotte 's mother in rank , yet [no one]385-no one could efface [her]382-miss lamotte 's mother name out of [the Baronetage]386-the baronetage , where [Lettice]69-lettice , youngest daughter of [Sir Mark Holster]70-sir mark holster , born 1772 , married [H. Lamotte]71-h. lamotte [, 1799 , died 1810]387-, 1799 , died 1810 , was duly chronicled . [She]382-miss lamotte 's mother had left [two children]388-two children , [a boy]389-a boy and [a girl]390-a girl , of whom [[their]388-two children uncle]391-their uncle , [Sir Frank]68-sir frank holster , took charge , as [[their]388-two children father]392-their father was worse than dead -- [an outlaw whose name was never mentioned]393-an outlaw whose name was never mentioned . [Mark Lamotte]72-mark lamotte was in [the army]394-the army ; [Lettice]69-lettice had a dependent position in [[[her]69-lettice uncle]395-her uncle 's family]396-her uncle 's family ; not intentionally made more dependent than was rendered necessary by circumstances , but still dependent enough to grate on the feelings of [a sensitive girl , whose natural susceptibilty to slights]397-a sensitive girl , whose natural susceptibilty to slights was redoubled by the constant recollection of [[her]397-a sensitive girl , whose natural susceptibilty to slights father]398-her father 's disgrace . As [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins well knew , [Sir Frank]68-sir frank holster was considerably involved ; but it was with very mixed feelings that [he]66-mr. wilkins listened to the suit which would provide [[his]66-mr. wilkins penniless niece]399-his penniless niece with a comfortable , not to say luxurious , [home]230-home , and with [a handsome , accomplished young man of unblemished character]401-a handsome , accomplished young man of unblemished character for [a husband]402-a husband . [He]66-mr. wilkins said one or two bitter and insolent things to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , even while [he]66-mr. wilkins was giving [his]66-mr. wilkins consent to the match ; that was [his]66-mr. wilkins temper , [his]66-mr. wilkins proud , evil temper ; but [he]66-mr. wilkins really and permanently was satisfied with the connection , though [he]66-mr. wilkins would occasionally turn round on [[his]66-mr. wilkins nephew - in - law]403-his nephew - in - law , and sting [him]403-his nephew - in - law with a covert insult , as to [his]403-his nephew - in - law want of birth , and the inferior position which [he]403-his nephew - in - law held , forgetting , apparently , that [[his]66-mr. wilkins own brother - in - law]404-his own brother - in - law and [[Lettice]69-lettice 's father]405-lettice 's father might be at any moment brought to the bar of justice if [he]403-his nephew - in - law attempted to re - enter [[his]403-his nephew - in - law native country]406-his native country . [Edward]66-mr. wilkins was annoyed at all this ; [Lettice]69-lettice resented it . [She]69-lettice loved [[her]69-lettice husband]407-her husband dearly , and was proud of [him]407-her husband , for [she]69-lettice had discernment enough to see how superior [he]407-her husband was in every way to [[her]69-lettice cousins]408-her cousins , [the young Holsters , who borrowed [his]407-her husband horses]409-the young holsters , who borrowed his horses , drank [his]407-her husband wines , and yet had caught [[their]408-her cousins father]392-their father 's habit of sneering at [his]407-her husband profession . [Lettice]69-lettice wished that [Edward]66-mr. wilkins would content [himself]66-mr. wilkins with a purely domestic life , would let [himself]66-mr. wilkins drop out of the company of [the ---shire squirearchy]411-the ---shire squirearchy , and find [his]66-mr. wilkins relaxation with [her]69-lettice , in [[their]408-her cousins luxurious library]412-their luxurious library , or [lovely drawing - room]413-lovely drawing - room , so full of white gleaming statues , and gems of pictures . But , perhaps , this was too much to expect of [any man]414-any man , especially of one who felt [himself]66-mr. wilkins fitted in many ways to shine in society , and who was social by nature . Sociality in [that county]415-that county at that time meant conviviality . [Edward]66-mr. wilkins did not care for wine , and yet [he]66-mr. wilkins was obliged to drink -- and by - and - by [he]66-mr. wilkins grew to pique [himself]66-mr. wilkins on [his]66-mr. wilkins character as [a judge of wine]416-a judge of wine . [[His]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father by this time was dead ; [dead , happy old man , with a contented heart -- [his]222-his father affairs flourishing , [[his]222-his father poorer neighbours]419-his poorer neighbours loving [him]222-his father , [[his]222-his father richer]420-his richer respecting [him]222-his father , [[his]222-his father son]239-his son and [daughter - in - law]422-daughter - in - law , the most affectionate and devoted that [ever man]423-ever man had , and [his]222-his father healthy conscience at peace with [[his]222-his father God]424-his god]418-dead , happy old man , with a contented heart -- his affairs flourishing , his poorer neighbours loving him , his richer respecting him , his son and daughter - in - law , the most affectionate and devoted that ever man had , and his healthy conscience at peace with his god . [Lettice]69-lettice could have lived to [herself]69-lettice and [[her]69-lettice husband]407-her husband and [children]426-children . [Edward]66-mr. wilkins daily required more and more the stimulus of society . [[His]66-mr. wilkins wife]227-his wife wondered how [he]66-mr. wilkins could care to accept dinner invitations from [people who treated [him]66-mr. wilkins as " [Wilkins the attorney]2602-wilkins the attorney , [a very good sort of fellow]2603-a very good sort of fellow , "[428-people who treated him as " wilkins the attorney , a very good sort of fellow , " as they introduced him to strangers who might be staying in the country , but who had no power to appreciate the taste , the talents , the impulsive artistic nature which she held so dear] as [they]428-people who treated him as " wilkins the attorney , a very good sort of fellow , " as they introduced him to strangers who might be staying in the country , but who had no power to appreciate the taste , the talents , the impulsive artistic nature which she held so dear introduced [him]66-mr. wilkins to [strangers who might be staying in [the country]430-the country , but who had no power to appreciate the taste , the talents , the impulsive artistic nature which [she]227-his wife held so dear]429-strangers who might be staying in the country , but who had no power to appreciate the taste , the talents , the impulsive artistic nature which she held so dear]428-people who treated him as " wilkins the attorney , a very good sort of fellow , " as they introduced him to strangers who might be staying in the country , but who had no power to appreciate the taste , the talents , the impulsive artistic nature which she held so dear . [She]227-his wife forgot that by accepting such invitations [Edward]66-mr. wilkins was occasionally brought into contact with [people not merely of high conventional , but of high intellectual rank]431-people not merely of high conventional , but of high intellectual rank ; that when a certain amount of wine had dissipated [his]66-mr. wilkins sense of inferiority of rank and position , [he]66-mr. wilkins was [a brilliant talker]432-a brilliant talker , [a man to be listened to and admired even by [wandering [London]4-london [statesmen]435-statesmen]434-wandering london statesmen , [professional diners - out]436-professional diners - out , or [any great authors who might find [themselves]437-any great authors who might find themselves visitors in a ---shire country - house visitors in [a ---shire country - house]438-a ---shire country - house]437-any great authors who might find themselves visitors in a ---shire country - house]433-a man to be listened to and admired even by wandering london statesmen , professional diners - out , or any great authors who might find themselves visitors in a ---shire country - house . What [she]227-his wife would have had [him]66-mr. wilkins share from the pride of [her]227-his wife heart , [she]227-his wife should have warned [him]66-mr. wilkins to avoid from the temptations to sinful extravagance which it led [him]66-mr. wilkins into . [He]66-mr. wilkins had begun to spend more than [he]66-mr. wilkins ought , not in intellectual -- though that would have been wrong -- but in purely sensual things . [His]66-mr. wilkins wines , [his]66-mr. wilkins table , should be such as [no squire]439-no squire 's purse or palate could command . [His]66-mr. wilkins dinner - parties -- small in number , the viands rare and delicate in quality , and sent up to table by [an Italian cook]440-an italian cook -- should be such as even [the London stars]441-the london stars should notice with admiration . [He]66-mr. wilkins would have [Lettice]69-lettice dressed in the richest materials , the most delicate lace ; jewellery , [he]66-mr. wilkins said , was beyond [their]442-their means ; glancing with proud humility at the diamonds of [the elder ladies]443-the elder ladies , and the alloyed gold of [the younger]444-the younger . But [he]66-mr. wilkins managed to spend as much on [[his]66-mr. wilkins wife]227-his wife 's lace as would have bought many a set of inferior jewellery . [Lettice]69-lettice well became it all . If as [people]446-people said , [[her]69-lettice father]398-her father had been nothing but [a French adventurer]448-a french adventurer , [she]69-lettice bore traces of [her]69-lettice nature in [her]69-lettice grace , [her]69-lettice delicacy , [her]69-lettice fascinating and elegant ways of doing all things . [She]69-lettice was made for society ; and yet [she]69-lettice hated it . And one day [she]69-lettice went out of it altogether and for evermore . [She]69-lettice had been well in the morning when [Edward]66-mr. wilkins went down to [[his]66-mr. wilkins office in [Hamley]1-hamley]449-his office in hamley . At noon [he]66-mr. wilkins was sent for by [hurried trembling messengers]450-hurried trembling messengers . When [he]66-mr. wilkins got [home]230-home breathless and uncomprehending , [she]69-lettice was past speech . One glance from [her]69-lettice lovely loving black eyes showed that [she]69-lettice recognised [him]66-mr. wilkins with the passionate yearning that had been one of the characteristics of [her]69-lettice love through life . There was no word passed between [them]452-them . [He]66-mr. wilkins could not speak , any more than could [she]69-lettice . [He]66-mr. wilkins knelt down by [her]69-lettice . [She]69-lettice was dying ; [she]69-lettice was dead ; and [he]66-mr. wilkins knelt on immovable . [They]453-they brought [him]66-mr. wilkins [[his]66-mr. wilkins eldest child]454-his eldest child , [Ellinor]73-ellinor , in utter despair what to do in order to rouse [him]66-mr. wilkins . [They]453-they had no thought as to the effect on [her]69-lettice , hitherto shut up in [the nursery]455-the nursery during this busy day of confusion and alarm . [The child]456-the child had no idea of death , and [[her]456-the child father]398-her father , kneeling and tearless , was far less an object of surprise or interest to [her]456-the child than [[her]456-the child mother]458-her mother , lying still and white , and not turning [her]458-her mother head to smile at [[her]458-her mother darling]459-her darling . " [Mamma]74-mamma ! mamma ! "[456-the child] cried [the child]456-the child , in shapeless terror . But [the mother]461-the mother never stirred ; and [the father]462-the father hid [his]462-the father face yet deeper in the bedclothes , to stifle a cry as if a sharp knife had pierced [his]462-the father heart . [The child]456-the child forced [her]456-the child impetuous way from [[her]456-the child attendants]464-her attendants , and rushed to the bed . Undeterred by deadly cold or stony immobility , [she]456-the child kissed the lips and stroked the glossy raven hair , murmuring sweet words of wild love , such as had passed between [the mother]461-the mother and [child]466-child often and often when [no witnesses]467-no witnesses were by ; and altogether seemed so nearly beside [herself]456-the child in an agony of love and terror , that [Edward]66-mr. wilkins arose , and softly taking [her]456-the child in [his]66-mr. wilkins arms , bore [her]456-the child away , lying back like one dead ( so exhausted was [she]456-the child by the terrible emotion [they]468-they had forced on [her]456-the child childish heart ) , into [[his]66-mr. wilkins study]469-his study , [a little room opening out of [the grand library]471-the grand library]470-a little room opening out of the grand library , where on happy evenings , never to come again , [he]66-mr. wilkins and [[his]66-mr. wilkins wife]227-his wife were wo nt to retire to have coffee together , and then perhaps stroll out of the glass - door into the open air , the shrubbery , [the fields]473-the fields -- never more to be trodden by those dear feet . What passed between [father]474-father and [child]466-child in this seclusion none could tell . Late in the evening [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's supper was sent for , and [the servant who brought it in]476-the servant who brought it in saw [the child]456-the child lying as one dead in [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's arms , and before [he]66-mr. wilkins left [the room]479-the room watched [[his]66-mr. wilkins master]480-his master feeding [her]456-the child , [the girl of six years of age]481-the girl of six years of age , with as tender care as if [she]456-the child had been [a baby of six months]482-a baby of six months . CHAPTER III . From that time the tie between [father]474-father and [daughter]484-daughter grew very strong and tender indeed . [Ellinor]73-ellinor , it is true , divided [her]73-ellinor affection between [[her]73-ellinor baby sister]485-her baby sister and [[her]73-ellinor papa]486-her papa ; but [he]398-her father , caring little for [babies]487-babies , had only a theoretic regard for [[his]398-her father younger child]488-his younger child , while [the elder]489-the elder absorbed all [his]398-her father love . Every day that [he]398-her father dined at [home]230-home [Ellinor]73-ellinor was placed opposite to [him]398-her father while [he]398-her father ate [his]398-her father late dinner ; [she]73-ellinor sat where [[her]73-ellinor mother]458-her mother had done during the meal , although [she]458-her mother had dined and even supped some time before on the more primitive nursery fare . It was half pitiful , half amusing , to see [the little girl]492-the little girl 's grave , thoughtful ways and modes of speech , as if trying to act up to the dignity of [her]73-ellinor place as [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's companion , till sometimes [the little head]494-the little head nodded off to slumber in the middle of lisping some wise little speech . " Old - fashioned , "[495-the nurses] [the nurses]495-the nurses called [her]73-ellinor , and prophesied that [she]73-ellinor would not live long in consequence of [her]73-ellinor old- fashionedness . But instead of the fulfilment of this prophecy , [the fat bright baby]496-the fat bright baby was seized with fits , and was well , ill , and dead in a day ! [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's grief was something alarming , from its quietness and concealment . [She]73-ellinor waited till [she]73-ellinor was left -- as [she]73-ellinor thought -- alone at nights , and then sobbed and cried [her]73-ellinor passionate cry for " [Baby]75-baby , [baby]2604-baby , come back to [me]73-ellinor -- come back ; "[73-ellinor] till [every one]497-every one feared for the health of [the frail little girl whose childish affections had had to stand two such shocks]498-the frail little girl whose childish affections had had to stand two such shocks . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father put aside all business , all pleasure of every kind , to win [[his]398-her father darling]500-his darling from [her]73-ellinor grief . [No mother]501-no mother could have done more , [no tenderest nurse]502-no tenderest nurse done half so much as [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins then did for [Ellinor]73-ellinor . If it had not been for [him]398-her father [she]73-ellinor would have just died of [her]73-ellinor grief . As it was , [she]73-ellinor overcame it -- but slowly , wearily -- hardly letting [herself]73-ellinor love [anyone]503-anyone for some time , as if [she]73-ellinor instinctively feared lest all [her]73-ellinor strong attachments should find a sudden end in death . [Her]73-ellinor love -- thus dammed up into a small space -- at last burst its banks , and overflowed on [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father . It was a rich reward to [him]398-her father for all [his]398-her father care of [her]73-ellinor , and [he]398-her father took delight -- perhaps a selfish delight -- in all the many pretty ways [she]73-ellinor perpetually found of convincing [him]398-her father , if [he]398-her father had needed conviction , that [he]398-her father was ever the first object with [her]73-ellinor . [The nurse]505-the nurse told [him]398-her father that half an hour or so before the earliest time at which [he]398-her father could be expected [home]230-home in the evenings , [Miss Ellinor]73-ellinor began to fold up [her]73-ellinor doll 's things and lull [the inanimate treasure]507-the inanimate treasure to sleep . Then [she]73-ellinor would sit and listen with an intensity of attention for [his]398-her father footstep . Once [the nurse]505-the nurse had expressed some wonder at the distance at which [Ellinor]73-ellinor could hear [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's approach , saying that [she]73-ellinor had listened and could not hear a sound , to which [Ellinor]73-ellinor had replied : " Of course [you]505-the nurse can not ; [he]398-her father is not [[your]505-the nurse papa]2605-your papa ! "[73-ellinor] Then , when [he]398-her father went away in the morning , after [he]398-her father had kissed [her]73-ellinor , [Ellinor]73-ellinor would run to a certain window from which [she]73-ellinor could watch [him]398-her father up [the lane]510-the lane , now hidden behind a hedge , now reappearing through [an open space]511-an open space , again out of sight , till [he]398-her father reached a great old beech - tree , where for an instant more [she]73-ellinor saw [him]398-her father . And then [she]73-ellinor would turn away with a sigh , sometimes reassuring [her]73-ellinor unspoken fears by saying softly to [herself]73-ellinor , " [He]398-her father will come again to - night . "[73-ellinor] [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins liked to feel [[his]66-mr. wilkins child]512-his child dependent on [him]398-her father for all [her]73-ellinor pleasures . [He]66-mr. wilkins was even a little jealous of [anyone who devised a treat or conferred a present , the first news of which did not come from or]513-anyone who devised a treat or conferred a present , the first news of which did not come from or through [him]398-her father . At last it was necessary that [Ellinor]73-ellinor should have some more instruction than [[her]73-ellinor good old nurse]514-her good old nurse could give . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father did not care to take upon [himself]398-her father the office of [teacher]516-teacher , which [he]398-her father thought [he]398-her father foresaw would necessitate occasional blame , an occasional exercise of authority , which might possibly render [him]398-her father less idolized by [[his]398-her father little girl]517-his little girl ; so [he]398-her father commissioned [Lady Holster]76-lady holster to choose out one among [[her]76-lady holster many _ protegees]518-her many _ protegees _ for [a governess to [[his]398-her father daughter]520-his daughter]519-a governess to his daughter . Now , [Lady Holster]76-lady holster , who kept a sort of [amateur county register - office]521-amateur county register - office , was only too glad to be made of use in this way ; but when [she]76-lady holster inquired a little further as to the sort of person required , all [she]76-lady holster could extract from [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was : " [You]66-mr. wilkins know the kind of education [a lady]2606-a lady should have , and will , [I]66-mr. wilkins am sure , choose [a governess]2607-a governess for [Ellinor]73-ellinor better than [I]66-mr. wilkins could direct [you]66-mr. wilkins . Only , please , choose [some one who will not marry [me]66-mr. wilkins , and who will let [Ellinor]73-ellinor go on making [my]66-mr. wilkins tea , and doing pretty much what [she]73-ellinor likes]2608-some one who will not marry me , and who will let ellinor go on making my tea , and doing pretty much what she likes , for [she]73-ellinor is so good [they]2609-they need not try to make [her]73-ellinor better , only to teach [her]73-ellinor what [a lady]2606-a lady should know . "[66-mr. wilkins] [Miss Monro]77-miss monro was selected -- [a plain , intelligent , quiet woman of forty]522-a plain , intelligent , quiet woman of forty -- and it was difficult to decide whether [she]77-miss monro or [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins took the most pains to avoid [each other]523-each other , acting with regard to [Ellinor]73-ellinor , pretty much like the famous [Adam]78-adam and [Eve]79-eve in the weather - glass : when [the one]524-the one came out [the other]525-the other went in . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro had been tossed about and overworked quite enough in [her]77-miss monro life not to value the privilege and indulgence of [her]77-miss monro evenings to [herself]77-miss monro , [[her]77-miss monro comfortable schoolroom]526-her comfortable schoolroom , [her]77-miss monro quiet cozy teas , [her]77-miss monro book , or [her]77-miss monro letter - writing afterwards . By mutual agreement [she]77-miss monro did not interfere with [Ellinor]73-ellinor and [her]77-miss monro ways and occupations on the evenings when [the girl]527-the girl had not [[her]527-the girl father]398-her father for [companion]529-companion ; and these occasions became more and more frequent as years passed on , and the deep shadow was lightened which the sudden death that had visited [[his]398-her father household]530-his household had cast over [him]398-her father . As [I]0-i have said before , [he]398-her father was always [a popular man]531-a popular man at dinner - parties . [His]398-her father amount of intelligence and accomplishment was rare in [---shire]6----shire , and if it required more wine than formerly to bring [his]398-her father conversation up to the desired point of range and brilliancy , wine was not an article spared or grudged at the county dinner - tables . Occasionally [his]398-her father business took [him]398-her father up to [London]4-london . Hurried as these journeys might be , [he]398-her father never returned without a new game , a new toy of some kind , to " make [home]230-home pleasant to [[his]398-her father little maid]2612-his little maid , "[398-her father] as [he]398-her father expressed [himself]398-her father . [He]398-her father liked , too , to see what was doing in art , or in literature ; and as [he]398-her father gave pretty extensive orders for anything [he]398-her father admired , [he]398-her father was almost sure to be followed down to [Hamley]1-hamley by one or two packages or parcels , the arrival and opening of which began soon to form the pleasant epochs in [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's grave though happy life . [The only person of [his]398-her father own standing with whom [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins kept up any intercourse in [Hamley]1-hamley]532-the only person of his own standing with whom mr. wilkins kept up any intercourse in hamley was [the new clergyman]533-the new clergyman , [a bachelor]534-a bachelor , about [his]533-the new clergyman own age , [a learned man]535-a learned man , [a fellow of [his]533-the new clergyman college]536-a fellow of his college , whose first claim on [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's attention was the fact that [he]398-her father had been travelling - bachelor for [[his]398-her father university]537-his university , and had consequently been on [the Continent]5-the continent about the very same two years that [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had been [there]538-there ; and although [they]539-they had never met , yet [they]539-they had [many common acquaintances]540-many common acquaintances and common recollections to talk over of this period , which , after all , had been about the most bright and hopeful of [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's life . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness had [an occasional pupil]541-an occasional pupil ; that is to say , [he]80-mr. ness never put [himself]80-mr. ness out of the way to obtain [pupils]542-pupils , but did not refuse the entreaties sometimes made to [him]80-mr. ness that [he]80-mr. ness would prepare [a young man]543-a young man for college , by allowing [the said young man]544-the said young man to reside and read with [him]80-mr. ness . " [[Ness]80-mr. ness 's men]2613-ness 's men "[80-mr. ness] took rather high honours , for [the tutor]545-the tutor , too indolent to find out work for [himself]545-the tutor , had a certain pride in doing well the work that was found for [him]545-the tutor . When [Ellinor]73-ellinor was somewhere about fourteen , [a young [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet]546-a young mr. corbet came to be [[pupil]547-pupil to [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness]548-pupil to mr. ness . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father always called on [the young men]550-the young men reading with [the clergyman]551-the clergyman , and asked [them]550-the young men to [[his]398-her father house]552-his house . [His]398-her father hospitality had in course of time lost its _ recherche _ and elegant character , but was always generous , and often profuse . Besides , it was in [his]398-her father character to like the joyous , thoughtless company of [the young better than that of the old]553-the young better than that of the old -- given the same amount of refinement and education in both . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet was [a young man of very good family]554-a young man of very good family , from [a distant county]555-a distant county . If [his]81-mr. corbet character had not been so grave and deliberate , [his]81-mr. corbet years would only have entitled [him]81-mr. corbet to be called [a boy]389-a boy , for [he]81-mr. corbet was but eighteen at the time when [he]81-mr. corbet came to read with [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness . But [many men of five - and - twenty]557-many men of five - and - twenty have not reflected so deeply as this young [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet already had . [He]398-her father had considered and almost matured [his]398-her father plan for life ; had ascertained what objects [he]398-her father desired most to accomplish in the dim future , which is to many at [his]398-her father age only a shapeless mist ; and had resolved on certain steady courses of action by which such objects were most likely to be secured . [A younger son]558-a younger son , [his]398-her father family connections and family interest pre - arranged a legal career for [him]398-her father ; and it was in accordance with [his]398-her father own tastes and talents . All , however , which [[his]398-her father father]222-his father hoped for [him]398-her father was , that [he]398-her father might be able to make an income sufficient for [a gentleman]560-a gentleman to live on . [Old Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet was hardly to be called ambitious , or , if [he]81-mr. corbet were , [his]81-mr. corbet ambition was limited to views for [the eldest son]561-the eldest son . But [Ralph]81-mr. corbet intended to be [a distinguished lawyer]562-a distinguished lawyer , not so much for the vision of the woolsack , which [I]0-i suppose dances before the imagination of [every young lawyer]563-every young lawyer , as for the grand intellectual exercise , and consequent power over [mankind]564-mankind , that [distinguished lawyers]565-distinguished lawyers may always possess if [they]565-distinguished lawyers choose . A seat in Parliament , statesmanship , and all the great scope for a powerful and active mind that lay on each side of such a career -- these were the objects which [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet set before [himself]81-mr. corbet . To take high honours at college was the first step to be accomplished ; and in order to achieve this [Ralph]81-mr. corbet had , not persuaded -- persuasion was a weak instrument which [he]81-mr. corbet despised -- but gravely reasoned [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father into consenting to pay the large sum which [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness expected with [a pupil]567-a pupil . [The good - natured old squire]568-the good - natured old squire was rather pressed for ready money , but sooner than listen to an argument instead of taking [his]568-the good - natured old squire nap after dinner [he]568-the good - natured old squire would have yielded anything . But this did not satisfy [Ralph]81-mr. corbet ; [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father 's reason must be convinced of the desirability of the step , as well as [his]222-his father weak will give way . [The squire]570-the squire listened , looked wise , sighed ; spoke of [Edward]66-mr. wilkins 's extravagance and [the girls]571-the girls ' expenses , grew sleepy , and said , " Very true , "[570-the squire] " That is but reasonable , certainly , "[222-his father] glanced at the door , and wondered when [[his]222-his father son]239-his son would have ended [his]239-his son talking and go into [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room ; and at length found [himself]570-the squire writing the desired letter to [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , consenting to everything , terms and all . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness never had [a more satisfactory pupil]574-a more satisfactory pupil ; one whom [he]80-mr. ness could treat more as an intellectual equal . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet , as [Ralph]81-mr. corbet was always called in [Hamley]1-hamley , was resolute in [his]81-mr. corbet cultivation of [himself]81-mr. corbet , even exceeding what [[his]81-mr. corbet tutor]575-his tutor demanded of [him]81-mr. corbet . [He]81-mr. corbet was greedy of information in the hours not devoted to absolute study . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness enjoyed giving information , but most of all [he]80-mr. ness liked the hard tough arguments on all metaphysical and ethical questions in which [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet delighted to engage [him]80-mr. ness . [They]576-they lived together on terms of happy equality , having thus much in common . [They]576-they were essentially different , however , although there were so many points of resemblance . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness was unworldly as far as the idea of real unworldliness is compatible with a turn for self - indulgence and indolence ; while [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet was deeply , radically worldly , yet for the accomplishment of [his]81-mr. corbet object could deny [himself]81-mr. corbet all the careless pleasures natural to [his]81-mr. corbet age . [The tutor]545-the tutor and [pupil]547-pupil allowed [themselves]576-they one frequent relaxation , that of [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's company]579-mr. wilkins 's company . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness would stroll to [the office]580-the office after the six hours ' hard reading were over -- leaving [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet still bent over the table , book bestrewn -- and see what [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's engagements were . If [he]80-mr. ness had nothing better to do that evening , [he]80-mr. ness was either asked to dine at [the parsonage]581-the parsonage , or [he]80-mr. ness , in [his]80-mr. ness careless hospitable way , invited [the other two]582-the other two to dine with [him]80-mr. ness , [Ellinor]73-ellinor forming the fourth at table , as far as seats went , although [her]73-ellinor dinner had been eaten early with [Miss Monro]77-miss monro . [She]73-ellinor was little and slight of [her]73-ellinor age , and [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father never seemed to understand how [she]73-ellinor was passing out of childhood . Yet while in stature [she]73-ellinor was like [a child]584-a child ; in intellect , in force of character , in strength of clinging affection , [she]73-ellinor was [a woman]585-a woman . There might be much of the simplicity of [a child]584-a child about [her]73-ellinor , there was little of [the undeveloped girl]587-the undeveloped girl , varying from day to day like an April sky , careless as to which way [her]73-ellinor own character is tending . So [the two young people]588-the two young people sat with [[their]588-the two young people elders]589-their elders , and [both]590-both relished the company [they]588-the two young people were thus prematurely thrown into . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet talked as much as [either of [the other two gentlemen]592-the other two gentlemen]591-either of the other two gentlemen ; opposing and disputing on any side , as if to find out how much [he]81-mr. corbet could urge against received opinions . [Ellinor]73-ellinor sat silent ; [her]73-ellinor dark eyes flashing from time to time in vehement interest -- sometimes in vehement indignation if [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet , riding a - tilt at [everyone]593-everyone , ventured to attack [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father . [He]81-mr. corbet saw how this course excited [her]73-ellinor , and rather liked pursuing it in consequence ; [he]81-mr. corbet thought it only amused [him]81-mr. corbet . Another way in which [Ellinor]73-ellinor and [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet were thrown together occasionally was this : [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness and [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins shared the same _ Times _ between [them]588-the two young people ; and it was [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's duty to see that the paper was regularly taken from [[[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's house]596-her father 's house to [the parsonage]581-the parsonage . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father liked to dawdle over it . Until [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet had come to live with [him]398-her father , [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness had not much cared at what time it was passed on to [him]398-her father ; but [the young man]309-the young man took a strong interest in all public events , and especially in all that was said about [them]600-them . [He]309-the young man grew impatient if the paper was not forthcoming , and would set off [himself]309-the young man to go for it , sometimes meeting [the penitent breathless [Ellinor]73-ellinor in [the long lane which led from [Hamley]1-hamley to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's house]602-the long lane which led from hamley to mr. wilkins 's house]601-the penitent breathless ellinor in the long lane which led from hamley to mr. wilkins 's house . At first [he]309-the young man used to receive [her]73-ellinor eager " Oh !
