After a time [he]309-the young man had the grace to tell [her]73-ellinor it did not signify ; and by - and- by [he]309-the young man would turn back with [her]73-ellinor to give [her]73-ellinor some advice about [[her]73-ellinor garden]603-her garden , or [her]73-ellinor plants -- for [[his]309-the young man mother]269-his mother and [sisters]605-sisters were [first - rate practical gardeners]606-first - rate practical gardeners , and [he]309-the young man [himself]309-the young man was , as [he]309-the young man expressed it , " [a capital consulting physician for a sickly plant]2615-a capital consulting physician for a sickly plant . "[309-the young man] All this time [his]309-the young man voice , [his]309-the young man step , never raised [the child]456-the child 's colour one shade the higher , never made [her]456-the child heart beat the least quicker , as the slightest sign of [[her]456-the child father]398-her father 's approach was wo nt to do . [She]456-the child learnt to rely on [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet for advice , for a little occasional sympathy , and for much condescending attention . [He]309-the young man also gave [her]456-the child more fault - finding than all the rest of [the world]609-the world put together ; and , curiously enough , [she]456-the child was grateful to [him]309-the young man for it , for [she]456-the child really was humble and wished to improve . [He]309-the young man liked the attitude of superiority which this implied and exercised right gave [him]309-the young man . [They]610-they were [very good friends]611-very good friends at present . Nothing more . All this time [I]0-i have spoken only of [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's life as [he]309-the young man stood in relation to [[his]309-the young man daughter]520-his daughter . But there is far more to be said about it . After [[his]309-the young man wife]227-his wife 's death , [he]309-the young man withdrew [himself]309-the young man from society for a year or two in a more positive and decided manner than is common with [widowers]614-widowers . It was during this retirement of [his]309-the young man that [he]309-the young man riveted [[his]309-the young man little daughter]615-his little daughter 's heart in such a way as to influence all [her]615-his little daughter future life . When [he]309-the young man began to go out again , it might have been perceived -- had [any one]616-any one cared to notice -- how much the different characters of [[his]309-the young man father]222-his father and [wife]618-wife had influenced [him]309-the young man and kept [him]309-the young man steady . Not that [he]309-the young man broke out into any immoral conduct , but [he]309-the young man gave up time to pleasure , which both [old Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins and [Lettice]69-lettice would have quietly induced [him]309-the young man to spend in [the office]580-the office , superintending [his]309-the young man business . [His]309-the young man indulgence in hunting , and all field sports , had hitherto been only occasional ; they now became habitual , as far as the seasons permitted . [He]309-the young man shared [a moor in [Scotland]10-scotland]620-a moor in scotland with [one of [the Holsters]622-the holsters]621-one of the holsters one year , persuading [himself]309-the young man that the bracing air was good for [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's health . But the year afterwards [he]309-the young man took another , this time joining with [a comparative stranger]623-a comparative stranger ; and on [this moor]624-this moor there was [no house to which it was fit to bring [a child]584-a child and [[her]584-a child attendants]464-her attendants]625-no house to which it was fit to bring a child and her attendants . [He]309-the young man persuaded [himself]309-the young man that by frequent journeys [he]309-the young man could make up for [his]309-the young man absences from [Hamley]1-hamley . But journeys cost money ; and [he]309-the young man was often away from [[his]309-the young man office]628-his office when important business required attending to . There was some talk of [a new attorney]629-a new attorney setting up in [Hamley]1-hamley , to be supported by [one or two of [the more influential county families]631-the more influential county families , who had found [Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins not so attentive as [[his]309-the young man father]222-his father]630-one or two of the more influential county families , who had found wilkins not so attentive as his father . [Sir Frank Holster]68-sir frank holster sent for [[his]309-the young man relation]633-his relation , and told [him]633-his relation of this project , speaking to [him]633-his relation , at the same time , in pretty round terms on the folly of the life [he]309-the young man was leading . Foolish it certainly was , and as such [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was secretly acknowledging it ; but when [Sir Frank]68-sir frank holster , lashing [himself]68-sir frank holster , began to talk of [[his]68-sir frank holster hearer]634-his hearer 's presumption in joining the hunt , in aping the mode of life and amusements of [the landed gentry]635-the landed gentry , [Edward]66-mr. wilkins fired up . [He]66-mr. wilkins knew how much [Sir Frank]68-sir frank holster was dipped , and comparing it with the round sum [[his]66-mr. wilkins own father]636-his own father had left [him]66-mr. wilkins , [he]66-mr. wilkins said some plain truths to [Sir Frank]68-sir frank holster which [the latter]271-the latter never forgave , and henceforth there was no intercourse between [Holster Court]82-holster court and [Ford Bank]15-ford bank , as [Mr. Edward Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had christened [[[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's house]639-his father 's house on [his]66-mr. wilkins first return from [the Continent]5-the continent . The conversation had two consequences besides the immediate one of the quarrel . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins advertised for [a responsible and confidential clerk]640-a responsible and confidential clerk to conduct the business under [his]66-mr. wilkins own superintendence ; and [he]66-mr. wilkins also wrote to [[the Heralds]641-the heralds ' College]642-the heralds ' college to ask if [he]66-mr. wilkins did not belong to [the family bearing the same name in [South Wales]12-south wales]643-the family bearing the same name in south wales -- [those who have since reassumed [their]644-those who have since reassumed their ancient name of de winton ancient name of [De Winton]83-de winton]644-those who have since reassumed their ancient name of de winton . Both applications were favorably answered . [A skilful , experienced , middle - aged clerk]645-a skilful , experienced , middle - aged clerk was recommended to [him]66-mr. wilkins by [one of [the principal legal firms in [London]4-london]647-the principal legal firms in london]646-one of the principal legal firms in london , and immediately engaged to come to [Hamley]1-hamley at [his]645-a skilful , experienced , middle - aged clerk own terms ; which were pretty high . But , as [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins said it was worth any money to pay for the relief from constant responsibility which such a business as [his]66-mr. wilkins involved , [some people]648-some people remarked that [he]66-mr. wilkins had never appeared to feel the responsibility very much hitherto , as witness [his]66-mr. wilkins absences in [Scotland]10-scotland , and [his]66-mr. wilkins various social engagements when at [home]230-home ; it had been very different ( [they]648-some people said ) in [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's day . [The Heralds ' College]13-the heralds ' college held out hopes of affiliating [him]66-mr. wilkins to [the South Wales family]651-the south wales family , but it would require time and money to make the requisite inquiries and substantiate the claim . Now , in [many a place]652-many a place there would be none to contest the right [a man]286-a man might have to assert that [he]286-a man belonged to [such and such a family]654-such and such a family , or even to assume [their]648-some people arms . But it was otherwise in [---shire]6----shire . [Everyone]593-everyone was up in genealogy and heraldry , and considered filching a name and a pedigree a far worse sin than any of those mentioned on the Commandments . There were [those among them who would doubt and dispute even the decision of the Heralds]656-those among them who would doubt and dispute even the decision of the heralds ' College ; but with it , if in [his]66-mr. wilkins favour , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins intended to be satisfied , and accordingly [he]66-mr. wilkins wrote in reply to [their]648-some people letter to say , that of course [he]66-mr. wilkins was aware such inquiries would take a considerable sum of money , but still [he]66-mr. wilkins wished them to be made , and that speedily . Before the end of the year [he]66-mr. wilkins went up to [London]4-london to order a brougham to be built ( for [Ellinor]73-ellinor to drive out in wet weather , [he]66-mr. wilkins said ; but as going in [a closed carriage]657-a closed carriage always made [her]73-ellinor ill , [he]66-mr. wilkins used it principally [himself]66-mr. wilkins in driving to dinner - parties ) , with the [De Winton Wilkinses]83-de winton ' arms neatly emblazoned on panel and harness . Hitherto [he]66-mr. wilkins had always gone about in [a dog - cart]658-a dog - cart -- [the immediate descendant of [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's old - fashioned gig]659-the immediate descendant of his father 's old - fashioned gig . For all this , [the squires]245-the squires , [[his]66-mr. wilkins employers]662-his employers , only laughed at [him]66-mr. wilkins and did not treat [him]66-mr. wilkins with one whit more respect . [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster , [the new clerk]663-the new clerk , was [a quiet , respectable - looking man]664-a quiet , respectable - looking man ; [you]665-you could not call [him]84-mr. dunster [a gentleman]560-a gentleman in manner , and yet [no one]385-no one could say [he]84-mr. dunster was vulgar . [He]84-mr. dunster had not much varying expression on [his]84-mr. dunster face , but a permanent one of thoughtful consideration of the subject in hand , whatever it might be , that would have fitted as well with the profession of medicine as with that of law , and was quite the right look for either . Occasionally a bright flash of sudden intelligence lightened up [his]84-mr. dunster deep - sunk eyes , but even this was quickly extinguished as by some inward repression , and the habitually reflective , subdued expression returned to the face . As soon as [he]66-mr. wilkins came into [his]66-mr. wilkins situation , [he]66-mr. wilkins first began quietly to arrange the papers , and next the business of which they were the outer sign , into more methodical order than they had been in since [old Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's death . Punctual to a moment [himself]66-mr. wilkins , [he]66-mr. wilkins looked [his]66-mr. wilkins displeased surprise when [the inferior clerks]668-the inferior clerks came tumbling in half an hour after the time in the morning ; and [his]66-mr. wilkins look was more effective than [many men]368-many men 's words ; henceforward [the subordinates]670-the subordinates were within five minutes of the appointed hour for opening [the office]580-the office ; but still [he]66-mr. wilkins was always there before [them]670-the subordinates . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins [himself]66-mr. wilkins winced under [[his]66-mr. wilkins new clerk]672-his new clerk 's order and punctuality ; [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's raised eyebrow and contraction of the lips at some woeful confusion in the business of [the office]580-the office , chafed [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins more , far more than any open expression of opinion would have done ; for that [he]66-mr. wilkins could have met , and explained away as [he]66-mr. wilkins fancied . A secret respectful dislike grew up in [his]66-mr. wilkins bosom against [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster . [He]66-mr. wilkins esteemed [him]84-mr. dunster , [he]66-mr. wilkins valued [him]84-mr. dunster , and [he]66-mr. wilkins could not bear [him]84-mr. dunster . Year after year [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had become more under the influence of [his]66-mr. wilkins feelings , and less under the command of [his]66-mr. wilkins reason . [He]66-mr. wilkins rather cherished than repressed [his]66-mr. wilkins nervous repugnance to the harsh measured tones of [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's voice ; [the latter]271-the latter spoke with a provincial twang which grated on [[his]66-mr. wilkins employer]675-his employer 's sensitive ear . [He]66-mr. wilkins was annoyed at a certain green coat which [[his]66-mr. wilkins new clerk]672-his new clerk brought with [him]66-mr. wilkins , and [he]66-mr. wilkins watched [its]677-its increasing shabbiness with a sort of childish pleasure . But by - and - by [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins found out that , from some perversity of taste , [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster always had [his]84-mr. dunster coats , Sunday and working- day , made of this obnoxious colour ; and this knowledge did not diminish [his]84-mr. dunster secret irritation . The worst of all , perhaps , was , that [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster was really invaluable in many ways ; " a perfect treasure , "[84-mr. dunster] as [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins used to term [him]84-mr. dunster in speaking of [him]84-mr. dunster after dinner ; but , for all that , [he]66-mr. wilkins came to hate [his]84-mr. dunster " perfect treasure , "[66-mr. wilkins] as [he]66-mr. wilkins gradually felt that [Dunster]84-mr. dunster had become so indispensable to the business that [[his]66-mr. wilkins chief]678-his chief could not do without [him]84-mr. dunster . [The clients]679-the clients re - echoed [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's words , and spoke of [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster as invaluable to [[his]84-mr. dunster master]480-his master ; [a thorough treasure]681-a thorough treasure , the very saving of the business . [They]679-the clients had not been better attended to , not even in [old Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's days ; such a clear head , such a knowledge of law , [such a steady , upright fellow]682-such a steady , upright fellow , always at [his]480-his master post . The grating voice , the drawling accent , the bottle - green coat , were nothing to [them]679-the clients ; far less noticed , in fact , than [Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's expensive habits , the money [he]66-mr. wilkins paid for [his]66-mr. wilkins wine and horses , and the nonsense of claiming kin with [the Welsh Wilkinses]85-the wilkinses , and setting up [his]66-mr. wilkins brougham to drive about ---shire lanes , and be knocked to pieces over the rough round paving - stones thereof . All these remarks did not come near [Ellinor]73-ellinor to trouble [her]73-ellinor life . To [her]73-ellinor , [[her]73-ellinor dear father]683-her dear father was [the first of [human beings]685-human beings]684-the first of human beings ; so sweet , so good , so kind , so charming in conversation , so full of accomplishment and information ! To [her]73-ellinor healthy , happy mind every one turned [their]686-their bright side . [She]73-ellinor loved [Miss Monro]77-miss monro -- [all the servants]687-all the servants -- especially [Dixon]86-dixon , [the coachman]688-the coachman . [He]86-dixon had been [[[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's playfellow as [a boy]389-a boy , and , with all [his]86-dixon respect and admiration for [[his]86-dixon master]480-his master]690-her father 's playfellow as a boy , and , with all his respect and admiration for his master , the freedom of intercourse that had been established between [them]693-them then had never been quite lost . [Dixon]86-dixon was [a fine , stalwart old fellow]694-a fine , stalwart old fellow , and was as harmonious in [his]86-dixon ways with [[his]86-dixon master]480-his master as [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster was discordant ; accordingly [he]86-dixon was a great favourite , and could say many a thing which might have been taken as impertinent from [another servant]696-another servant . [He]86-dixon was [[Ellinor]73-ellinor 's great confidant]697-ellinor 's great confidant about many of [her]73-ellinor little plans and projects ; things that [she]73-ellinor dared not speak of to [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet , who , after [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father and [Dixon]86-dixon , was [[her]73-ellinor next best friend]699-her next best friend . This intimacy with [Dixon]86-dixon displeased [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet . [He]81-mr. corbet once or twice insinuated that [he]81-mr. corbet did not think it was well to talk so familiarly as [Ellinor]73-ellinor did with [a servant]700-a servant -- [one out of a completely different class]701-one out of a completely different class -- such as [Dixon]86-dixon . [Ellinor]73-ellinor did not easily take hints ; [every one]497-every one had spoken plain out to [her]73-ellinor hitherto ; so [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet had to say [his]81-mr. corbet meaning plain out at last . Then , for the first time , [he]81-mr. corbet saw [her]73-ellinor angry ; but [she]73-ellinor was too young , too childish , to have words at will to express [her]73-ellinor feelings ; [she]73-ellinor only could say broken beginnings of sentences , such as " What a shame ! Good , dear [Dixon]86-dixon , who is as loyal and true and kind as [any nobleman]2616-any nobleman . [I]73-ellinor like [him]86-dixon far better than [you]81-mr. corbet , [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet , and [I]73-ellinor shall talk to [him]86-dixon . "[73-ellinor] And then [she]73-ellinor burst into tears and ran away , and would not come to wish [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet good - bye , though [she]73-ellinor knew [she]73-ellinor should not see [him]81-mr. corbet again for a long time , as [he]81-mr. corbet was returning the next day to [[[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father 's house]639-his father 's house , from whence [he]81-mr. corbet would go to [Cambridge]14-cambridge . [He]81-mr. corbet was annoyed at this result of the good advice [he]81-mr. corbet had thought [himself]81-mr. corbet bound to give to [a motherless girl , who had [no one]385-no one to instruct [her]705-a motherless girl , who had no one to instruct her in the proprieties in which his own sisters were brought up in the proprieties in which [[his]81-mr. corbet own sisters]707-his own sisters were brought up]705-a motherless girl , who had no one to instruct her in the proprieties in which his own sisters were brought up ; [he]81-mr. corbet left [Hamley]1-hamley both sorry and displeased . As for [Ellinor]73-ellinor , when [she]73-ellinor found out the next day that [he]81-mr. corbet really was gone -- gone without even coming to [Ford Bank]15-ford bank again to see if [she]73-ellinor were not penitent for [her]73-ellinor angry words -- gone without saying or hearing a word of good - bye -- [she]73-ellinor shut [herself]73-ellinor up in [[her]73-ellinor room]708-her room , and cried more bitterly than ever , because anger against [herself]73-ellinor was mixed with [her]73-ellinor regret for [his]81-mr. corbet loss . Luckily , [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father was dining out , or [he]398-her father would have inquired what was the matter with [[his]398-her father darling]500-his darling ; and [she]73-ellinor would have had to try to explain what could not be explained . As it was , [she]73-ellinor sat with [her]73-ellinor back to the light during the schoolroom tea , and afterwards , when [Miss Monro]77-miss monro had settled down to [her]77-miss monro study of the Spanish language , [Ellinor]73-ellinor stole out into [the garden]711-the garden , meaning to have a fresh cry over [her]73-ellinor own naughtiness and [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's departure ; but the August evening was still and calm , and put [her]73-ellinor passionate grief to shame , hushing [her]73-ellinor up , as it were , with [the other young creatures , who were being soothed to rest by the serene time of day , and the subdued light of the twilight sky]712-the other young creatures , who were being soothed to rest by the serene time of day , and the subdued light of the twilight sky . There was a piece of ground surrounding [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden , which was not shrubbery , nor wood , nor [kitchen garden]714-kitchen garden -- only a grassy bit , out of which a group of old forest trees sprang . [Their]715-their roots were heaved above ground ; their leaves fell in autumn so profusely that the turf was ragged and bare in spring ; but , to make up for this , there never was such a place for snowdrops . The roots of these old trees were [[Ellinor]73-ellinor 's favourite play - place]716-ellinor 's favourite play - place ; this space between these two was [[her]73-ellinor doll 's kitchen]717-her doll 's kitchen , that [[its]717-her doll 's kitchen drawing - room]718-its drawing - room , and so on . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet rather despised [her]73-ellinor contrivances for doll 's furniture , so [she]73-ellinor had not often brought [him]81-mr. corbet [here]719-here ; but [Dixon]86-dixon delighted in them , and contrived and planned with the eagerness of six years old rather than forty . To - night [Ellinor]73-ellinor went to [this place]720-this place , and there were all a new collection of ornaments for [[Miss Dolly]88-miss dolly 's sitting - room]721-miss dolly 's sitting - room made out of fir - bobs , in the prettiest and most ingenious way . [She]73-ellinor knew it was [Dixon]86-dixon 's doing and rushed off in search of [him]86-dixon to thank [him]86-dixon . " What 's the matter with [[my]86-dixon pretty]2617-my pretty ? "[86-dixon] asked [Dixon]86-dixon , as soon as the pleasant excitement of thanking and being thanked was over , and [he]86-dixon had leisure to look at [her]73-ellinor tear - stained face . " Oh , [I]73-ellinor do n't know ! Never mind , "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor , reddening . [Dixon]86-dixon was silent for a minute or two , while [she]73-ellinor tried to turn off [his]86-dixon attention by [her]73-ellinor hurried prattle . " There 's no trouble afoot that [I]86-dixon can mend ? "[86-dixon] asked [he]86-dixon , in a minute or two . " Oh , no ! It 's really nothing -- nothing at all , "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor . " It 's only that [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet went away without saying good - bye to [me]73-ellinor , that 's all . "[73-ellinor] And [she]73-ellinor looked as if [she]73-ellinor should have liked to cry again . " That was not manners , "[86-dixon] said [Dixon]86-dixon , decisively . " But it was [my]73-ellinor fault , "[73-ellinor] replied [Ellinor]73-ellinor , pleading against the condemnation . [Dixon]86-dixon looked at [her]73-ellinor pretty sharply from under [his]86-dixon ragged bushy eyebrows . " [He]81-mr. corbet had been giving [me]86-dixon a lecture , and saying [I]86-dixon did n't do what [[his]81-mr. corbet sisters]2618-his sisters did -- just as if [I]86-dixon were to be always trying to be like [somebody else]2619-somebody else -- and [I]86-dixon was cross and ran away . "[86-dixon] " Then it was [Missy]89-missy who would n't say good - bye . That was not manners in [Missy]89-missy . "[86-dixon] " But , [Dixon]86-dixon , [I]86-dixon do n't like being lectured ! "[86-dixon] " [I]86-dixon reckon [you]86-dixon do n't get much of it . But , indeed , [[my]86-dixon pretty]2617-my pretty , [I]86-dixon daresay [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet was in the right ; for , [you]86-dixon see , [master]2621-master is busy , and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro is so dreadful learned , and [[your]86-dixon poor mother]2622-your poor mother is dead and gone , and [you]86-dixon have [no one]385-no one to teach [you]86-dixon how [young ladies]2624-young ladies go on ; and by all accounts [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet comes of [a good family]2625-a good family . [I]86-dixon 've heard say [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father had [the best stud - farm in [all Shropshire]2628-all shropshire]2627-the best stud - farm in all shropshire , and spared no money upon [it]2627-the best stud - farm in all shropshire ; and [the young ladies [[his]81-mr. corbet sisters]2618-his sisters]2629-the young ladies his sisters will have been taught the best of manners ; it might be well for [[my]86-dixon pretty]2617-my pretty to hear how [they]2629-the young ladies his sisters go on . "[86-dixon] " [You]86-dixon dear old [Dixon]86-dixon , [you]86-dixon do n't know anything about [my]86-dixon lecture , and [I]86-dixon 'm not going to tell [you]86-dixon . Only [I]86-dixon daresay [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet might be a little bit right , though [I]86-dixon 'm sure [he]81-mr. corbet was a great deal wrong . "[86-dixon] " But [you]86-dixon 'll not go on a - fretting -- [you]86-dixon wo n't now , there 's [a good young lady]2632-a good young lady -- for [master]2621-master wo n't like it , and it 'll make [him]2621-master uneasy , and [he]2621-master 's enough of trouble without [your]86-dixon red eyes , bless them . "[86-dixon] " Trouble -- [papa]2614-papa , trouble ! Oh , [Dixon]86-dixon ! what do [you]86-dixon mean ? "[73-ellinor] exclaimed [Ellinor]73-ellinor , [her]73-ellinor face taking all [a woman]585-a woman 's intensity of expression in a minute . " Nay , [I]86-dixon know nought , "[86-dixon] said [Dixon]86-dixon , evasively . " Only [that Dunster fellow]2635-that dunster fellow is not to [my]86-dixon mind , and [I]86-dixon think [he]2635-that dunster fellow potters [the master]2636-the master sadly with [his]2635-that dunster fellow fid- fad ways . "[86-dixon] " [I]73-ellinor hate [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster ! "[73-ellinor] said [Ellinor]73-ellinor , vehemently . " [I]73-ellinor wo n't speak a word to [him]2635-that dunster fellow the next time [he]2635-that dunster fellow comes to dine with [papa]2614-papa . "[73-ellinor] " [Missy]89-missy will do what [papa]2614-papa likes best , "[86-dixon] said [Dixon]86-dixon , admonishingly ; and with this [the pair of " friends]2639-the pair of " friends "[73-ellinor] parted , CHAPTER IV . The summer afterwards [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet came again to read with [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness . [He]81-mr. corbet did not perceive any alteration in [himself]81-mr. corbet , and indeed [his]81-mr. corbet early - matured character had hardly made progress during the last twelve months whatever intellectual acquirements [he]81-mr. corbet might have made . Therefore it was astonishing to [him]81-mr. corbet to see the alteration in [Ellinor Wilkins]73-ellinor . [She]73-ellinor had shot up from [a rather puny girl]723-a rather puny girl to [a tall , slight young lady]724-a tall , slight young lady , with promise of great beauty in the face , which a year ago had only been remarkable for the fineness of the eyes . [Her]73-ellinor complexion was clear now , although colourless -- twelve months ago [he]81-mr. corbet would have called it sallow -- [her]73-ellinor delicate cheek was smooth as marble , [her]73-ellinor teeth were even and white , and [her]73-ellinor rare smiles called out a lovely dimple . [She]73-ellinor met [[her]73-ellinor former friend]725-her former friend and [lecturer]726-lecturer with a grave shyness , for [she]73-ellinor remembered well how [they]727-they had parted , and thought [he]81-mr. corbet could hardly have forgiven , much less forgotten , [her]73-ellinor passionate flinging away from [him]81-mr. corbet . But the truth was , after the first few hours of offended displeasure , [he]81-mr. corbet had ceased to think of it at all . [She]73-ellinor , [poor child]728-poor child , by way of proving [her]73-ellinor repentance , had tried hard to reform [her]73-ellinor boisterous tom - boy manners , in order to show [him]81-mr. corbet that , although [she]73-ellinor would not give up [[her]73-ellinor dear old friend]729-her dear old friend [Dixon]86-dixon , at [his]81-mr. corbet or [anyone]503-anyone 's bidding , [she]73-ellinor would strive to profit by [his]81-mr. corbet lectures in all things reasonable . The consequence was , that [she]73-ellinor suddenly appeared to [him]81-mr. corbet as [an elegant dignified young lady]731-an elegant dignified young lady , instead of [the rough little girl [he]81-mr. corbet remembered]732-the rough little girl he remembered . Still below [her]73-ellinor somewhat formal manners there lurked [the old wild spirit]733-the old wild spirit , as [he]81-mr. corbet could plainly see after a little more watching ; and [he]81-mr. corbet began to wish to call this out , and to strive , by reminding [her]73-ellinor of old days , and all [her]73-ellinor childish frolics , to flavour [her]73-ellinor subdued manners and speech with a little of the former originality . In this [he]81-mr. corbet succeeded . [No one]385-no one , neither [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , nor [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , nor [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , saw what [this young couple]735-this young couple were about -- [they]735-this young couple did not know it [themselves]735-this young couple ; but before the summer was over [they]735-this young couple were desperately in love with [each other]523-each other , or perhaps [I]0-i should rather say , [Ellinor]73-ellinor was desperately in love with [him]81-mr. corbet -- [he]81-mr. corbet , as passionately as [he]81-mr. corbet could be with [anyone]503-anyone ; but in [him]81-mr. corbet the intellect was superior in strength to either affections or passions . The causes of the blindness of [those around [them]735-this young couple]738-those around them were these : [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins still considered [Ellinor]73-ellinor as [a little girl]739-a little girl , as [his]66-mr. wilkins own pet , [[his]66-mr. wilkins darling]500-his darling , but nothing more . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro was anxious about [her]77-miss monro own improvement . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness was deep in a new edition of " Horace , "[80-mr. ness] which [he]80-mr. ness was going to bring out with notes . [I]0-i believe [Dixon]86-dixon would have been keener sighted , but [Ellinor]73-ellinor kept [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet and [Dixon]86-dixon apart for obvious reasons -- [they]735-this young couple were each [[her]73-ellinor dear friends]741-her dear friends , but [she]73-ellinor knew that [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet did not like [Dixon]86-dixon , and suspected that the feeling was mutual . The only change of circumstances between this year and the previous one consisted in this development of attachment between [the young people]742-the young people . Otherwise , everything went on apparently as usual . With [Ellinor]73-ellinor the course of the day was something like this : up early and into [the garden]711-the garden until breakfast time , when [she]73-ellinor made tea for [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro in [the dining - room]745-the dining - room , always taking care to lay a little nosegay of freshly- gathered flowers by [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's plate . After breakfast , when the conversation had been on general and indifferent subjects , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins withdrew into [the little study so often mentioned]747-the little study so often mentioned . It opened out of [a passage that ran between [the dining - room]745-the dining - room and [the kitchen]750-the kitchen , on the left hand of [the hall]751-the hall]748-a passage that ran between the dining - room and the kitchen , on the left hand of the hall . Corresponding to [the dining - room]745-the dining - room on the other side of [the hall]751-the hall was [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room , with [its]573-the drawing - room side - window serving as a door into [a conservatory]755-a conservatory , and this again opened into [the library]756-the library . [Old Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had added a semicircular projection to [the library]756-the library , which was lighted by a dome above , and showed off [[his]66-mr. wilkins son]239-his son 's Italian purchases of sculpture . [The library]756-the library was by far [the most striking and agreeable room in [the house]761-the house]760-the most striking and agreeable room in the house ; and the consequence was that [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room was seldom used , and had the aspect of cold discomfort common to [apartments]763-apartments rarely occupied . [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's study]764-mr. wilkins 's study , on [the other side of [the house]761-the house]765-the other side of the house , was also an afterthought , built only a few years ago , and projecting from the regularity of the outside wall ; a little stone passage led to [it]764-mr. wilkins 's study from [the hall]751-the hall , small , narrow , and dark , and out of which no other door opened . [The study]768-the study itself was a hexagon , one side window , one fireplace , and the remaining four sides occupied with doors , two of which have been already mentioned , another at the foot of the narrow winding stairs which led straight into [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's bedroom]769-mr. wilkins 's bedroom over [the dining - room]745-the dining - room , and the fourth opening into a path through the shrubbery to the right of [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden as [you]772-you looked from [the house]761-the house . [This path]774-this path led through [the stable - yard]775-the stable - yard , and then by a short cut right into [Hamley]1-hamley , and brought [you]772-you out close to [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's office]776-mr. wilkins 's office ; it was by this way [he]66-mr. wilkins always went and returned to [[his]66-mr. wilkins business]777-his business . [He]66-mr. wilkins used [the study]768-the study for [a smoking and lounging room]779-a smoking and lounging room principally , although [he]66-mr. wilkins always spoke of [it]768-the study as a convenient place for holding confidential communications with such of [[his]66-mr. wilkins clients]229-his clients as did not like discussing [their]229-his clients business within the possible hearing of [all the clerks in [[his]66-mr. wilkins office]628-his office]781-all the clerks in his office . By the outer door [he]66-mr. wilkins could also pass to [the stables]783-the stables , and see that proper care was taken at all times of [his]66-mr. wilkins favourite and valuable horses . Into [this study]784-this study [Ellinor]73-ellinor would follow [him]66-mr. wilkins of a morning , helping [him]66-mr. wilkins on with [his]66-mr. wilkins great - coat , mending [his]66-mr. wilkins gloves , talking an infinite deal of merry fond nothing ; and then , clinging to [his]66-mr. wilkins arm , [she]73-ellinor would accompany [him]66-mr. wilkins in [his]66-mr. wilkins visits to [the stables]783-the stables , going up to the shyest horses , and petting them , and patting them , and feeding [them]786-them with bread all the time that [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father held converse with [Dixon]86-dixon . When [he]66-mr. wilkins was finally gone -- and sometimes it was a long time first -- [she]73-ellinor returned to [the schoolroom]788-the schoolroom to [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , and tried to set [herself]73-ellinor hard at work on [her]73-ellinor lessons . But [she]73-ellinor had not much time for steady application ; if [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father had cared for [her]73-ellinor progress in anything , [she]73-ellinor would and could have worked hard at that study or accomplishment ; but [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , [the ease and pleasure loving man]790-the ease and pleasure loving man , did not wish to make [himself]66-mr. wilkins into the pedagogue , as [he]66-mr. wilkins would have considered it , if [he]66-mr. wilkins had ever questioned [Ellinor]73-ellinor with a real steady purpose of ascertaining [her]73-ellinor intellectual progress . It was quite enough for [him]66-mr. wilkins that [her]73-ellinor general intelligence and variety of desultory and miscellaneous reading made [her]73-ellinor a pleasant and agreeable companion for [his]66-mr. wilkins hours of relaxation . At twelve o'clock , [Ellinor]73-ellinor put away [her]73-ellinor books with joyful eagerness , kissed [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , asked [her]77-miss monro if [they]791-they should go a regular walk , and was always rather thankful when it was decided that it would be better to stroll in [the garden]711-the garden -- a decision very often come to , for [Miss Monro]77-miss monro hated fatigue , hated dirt , hated scrambling , and dreaded rain ; all of which are evils , the chances of which are never far distant from country walks . So [Ellinor]73-ellinor danced out into [the garden]711-the garden , worked away among [her]73-ellinor flowers , played at the old games among the roots of the trees , and , when [she]73-ellinor could , seduced [Dixon]86-dixon into [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden to have a little consultation as to the horses and dogs . For it was one of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's few strict rules that [Ellinor]73-ellinor was never to go into [the stable - yard]775-the stable - yard unless [he]66-mr. wilkins were with [her]73-ellinor ; so these _ tete - a - tetes _ with [Dixon]86-dixon were always held in [the flower- garden]797-the flower- garden , or bit of [forest ground surrounding]798-forest ground surrounding [it]797-the flower- garden . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro sat and basked in the sun , close to the dial , which made the centre of the gay flower - beds , upon which [the dining - room]745-the dining - room and study windows looked . At one o'clock , [Ellinor]73-ellinor and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro dined . An hour was allowed for [Miss Monro]77-miss monro 's digestion , which [Ellinor]73-ellinor again spent out of doors , and at three , lessons began again and lasted till five . At that time [they]800-they went to dress preparatory for the schoolroom tea at half - past five . After tea [Ellinor]73-ellinor tried to prepare [her]73-ellinor lessons for the next day ; but all the time [she]73-ellinor was listening for [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's footstep -- the moment [she]73-ellinor heard that , [she]73-ellinor dashed down [her]73-ellinor book , and flew out of [the room]479-the room to welcome and kiss [him]398-her father . Seven was [his]398-her father dinner - hour ; [he]398-her father hardly ever dined alone ; indeed , [he]398-her father often dined from [home]230-home four days out of seven , and when [he]398-her father had no engagement to take [him]398-her father out [he]398-her father liked to have some one to keep [him]398-her father company : [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness very often , [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet along with [him]398-her father if [he]398-her father was in [Hamley]1-hamley , [a stranger friend]804-a stranger friend , or [one of [[his]398-her father clients]229-his clients]805-one of his clients . Sometimes , reluctantly , and when [he]398-her father fancied [he]398-her father could not avoid the attention without giving offence , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins would ask [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster , and then [the two]807-the two would always follow [Ellinor]73-ellinor into [the library]756-the library at a very early hour , as if [[their]807-the two subjects for _ tete - a - tete _ conversation]809-their subjects for _ tete - a - tete _ conversation were quite exhausted . With all [[his]398-her father other visitors]810-his other visitors , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins sat long -- yes , and yearly longer ; with [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , because [they]807-the two became interested in [each other]523-each other 's conversation ; with some of [the others]812-the others , because the wine was good , and [the host]813-the host hated to spare it . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet used to leave [[his]398-her father tutor]575-his tutor and [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins and saunter into [the library]756-the library . There sat [Ellinor]73-ellinor and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , each busy with [their]807-the two embroidery . [He]398-her father would bring a stool to [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's side , question and tease [her]73-ellinor , interest [her]73-ellinor , and [they]807-the two would become entirely absorbed in [each other]523-each other , [Miss Monro]77-miss monro 's sense of propriety being entirely set at rest by the consideration that [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins must know what [he]66-mr. wilkins was about in allowing [a young man]543-a young man to become thus intimate with [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter , who , after all , was but [a child]584-a child . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet had lately fallen into the habit of walking up to [Ford Bank]15-ford bank for _ The Times _ every day , near twelve o'clock , and lounging about in [the garden]711-the garden until one ; not exactly with either [Ellinor]73-ellinor or [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , but certainly far more at the beck and call of [the one]524-the one than of [the other]525-the other . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro used to think [he]66-mr. wilkins would have been glad to stay and lunch at [their]807-the two early dinner , but [she]77-miss monro never gave the invitation , and [he]66-mr. wilkins could not well stay without [her]77-miss monro expressed sanction . [He]66-mr. wilkins told [Ellinor]73-ellinor all about [[his]66-mr. wilkins mother]269-his mother and [sisters]605-sisters , and [their]807-the two ways of going on , and spoke of [them]807-the two and of [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father as of people [she]73-ellinor was one day certain to know , and to know intimately ; and [she]73-ellinor did not question or doubt this view of things ; [she]73-ellinor simply acquiesced . [He]66-mr. wilkins had some discussion with [himself]66-mr. wilkins as to whether [he]66-mr. wilkins should speak to [her]73-ellinor , and so secure [her]73-ellinor promise to be [his]66-mr. wilkins before returning to [Cambridge]14-cambridge or not . [He]66-mr. wilkins did not like the formality of an application to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , which would , after all , have been the proper and straightforward course to pursue with [a girl of [her]73-ellinor age]826-a girl of her age -- [she]73-ellinor was barely sixteen . Not that [he]66-mr. wilkins anticipated any difficulty on [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's part ; [his]66-mr. wilkins approval of the intimacy which at [their]827-their respective ages was pretty sure to lead to an attachment , was made as evident as could be by actions without words . But there would have to be reference to [[his]66-mr. wilkins own father]636-his own father , who had no notion of the whole affair , and would be sure to treat it as a boyish fancy ; as if at twenty - one [Ralph]81-mr. corbet was not [a man]286-a man , as clear and deliberative in knowing [his]81-mr. corbet own mind , as resolute as [he]81-mr. corbet ever would be in deciding upon the course of exertion that should lead [him]81-mr. corbet to independence and fame , if such were to be attained by clear intellect and a strong will . No ; to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins [he]66-mr. wilkins would not speak for another year or two . But should [he]66-mr. wilkins tell [Ellinor]73-ellinor in direct terms of [his]66-mr. wilkins love -- [his]66-mr. wilkins intention to marry [her]73-ellinor ? Again [he]66-mr. wilkins inclined to the more prudent course of silence . [He]66-mr. wilkins was not afraid of any change in [his]66-mr. wilkins own inclinations : of [them]830-them [he]66-mr. wilkins was sure . But [he]66-mr. wilkins looked upon it in this way : If [he]66-mr. wilkins made a regular declaration to [her]73-ellinor [she]73-ellinor would be bound to tell it to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father . [He]66-mr. wilkins should not respect [her]73-ellinor or like [her]73-ellinor so much if [she]73-ellinor did not . And yet this course would lead to all the conversations , and discussions , and references to [[his]66-mr. wilkins own father]636-his own father , which made [his]66-mr. wilkins own direct appeal to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins appear a premature step to [him]66-mr. wilkins . Whereas [he]66-mr. wilkins was as sure of [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's love for [him]66-mr. wilkins as if [she]73-ellinor had uttered all the vows that [women]833-women ever spoke ; [he]66-mr. wilkins knew even better than [she]73-ellinor did how fully and entirely that innocent girlish heart was [his]66-mr. wilkins own . [He]66-mr. wilkins was too proud to dread [her]73-ellinor inconstancy for an instant ; " besides , "[66-mr. wilkins] as [he]66-mr. wilkins went on to [himself]66-mr. wilkins , as if to make assurance doubly sure , " whom does [she]73-ellinor see ? [Those stupid Holsters]2640-those stupid holsters , who ought to be only too proud of having [such a girl for [[their]2640-those stupid holsters cousin]2642-their cousin]2641-such a girl for their cousin , ignore [her]73-ellinor existence , and spoke slightingly of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father only the very last time [I]66-mr. wilkins dined [there]538-there . [The country people in this precisely Boeotian ---shire]2645-the country people in this precisely boeotian ---shire clutch at [me]66-mr. wilkins because [[my]66-mr. wilkins father]2646-my father goes up to the Plantagenets for [his]2646-my father pedigree -- not one whit for [myself]66-mr. wilkins -- and neglect [Ellinor]73-ellinor ; and only condescend to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father because [old Wilkins]73-ellinor was [[nobody-]2648-nobody- knows - who 's son]2649-nobody- knows - who 's son . So much the worse for [them]2645-the country people in this precisely boeotian ---shire , but so much the better for [me]66-mr. wilkins in this case . [I]66-mr. wilkins 'm above [their]2645-the country people in this precisely boeotian ---shire silly antiquated prejudices , and shall be only too glad when the fitting time comes to make [Ellinor]73-ellinor [[my]66-mr. wilkins wife]2650-my wife . After all , [[a prosperous attorney]2651-a prosperous attorney 's daughter]2652-a prosperous attorney 's daughter may not be considered an unsuitable match for [me]66-mr. wilkins -- younger son as [I]66-mr. wilkins am . [Ellinor]73-ellinor will make [a glorious woman]2653-a glorious woman three or four years hence ; just the style [[my]66-mr. wilkins father]2646-my father admires -- [such a figure , such limbs]2655-such a figure , such limbs . [I]66-mr. wilkins 'll be patient , and bide [my]66-mr. wilkins time , and watch [my]66-mr. wilkins opportunities , and all will come right . "[66-mr. wilkins] So [he]834-he bade [Ellinor]73-ellinor farewell in a most reluctant and affectionate manner , although [his]834-he words might have been spoken out in [Hamley market - place]835-hamley market - place , and were little different from what [he]834-he said to [Miss Monro]77-miss monro . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins half expected a disclosure to [himself]66-mr. wilkins of the love which [he]66-mr. wilkins suspected in [the young man]309-the young man ; and when that did not come , [he]66-mr. wilkins prepared [himself]66-mr. wilkins for a confidence from [Ellinor]73-ellinor . But [she]73-ellinor had nothing to tell [him]66-mr. wilkins , as [he]66-mr. wilkins very well perceived from [the child]456-the child 's open unembarrassed manner when [they]838-they were left alone together after dinner . [He]66-mr. wilkins had refused an invitation , and shaken off [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , in order to have this confidential _ tete - a - tete _ with [[his]66-mr. wilkins motherless girl]839-his motherless girl ; and there was nothing to make confidence of . [He]66-mr. wilkins was half inclined to be angry ; but then [he]66-mr. wilkins saw that , although sad , [she]73-ellinor was so much at peace with [herself]73-ellinor and with [the world]609-the world , that [he]66-mr. wilkins , always [an optimist]841-an optimist , began to think [the young man]309-the young man had done wisely in not tearing open the rosebud of [her]73-ellinor feelings too prematurely . The next two years passed over in much the same way -- or [a careless spectator]843-a careless spectator might have thought so . [I]0-i have heard [people]446-people say , that if [you]845-you look at [a regiment advancing with steady step]846-a regiment advancing with steady step over [a plain]847-a plain on a review- day , [you]845-you can hardly tell that [they]446-people are not merely marking time on [one spot of ground]848-one spot of ground , unless [you]845-you compare [their]446-people position with some other object by which to mark [their]446-people progress , so even is the repetition of the movement . And thus the sad events of the future life of [this father]849-this father and [daughter]484-daughter were hardly perceived in [their]446-people steady advance , and yet over the monotony and flat uniformity of [their]446-people days sorrow came marching down upon [them]446-people like [an armed man]851-an armed man . Long before [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had recognised its shape , it was approaching [him]66-mr. wilkins in the distance -- as , in fact , it is approaching all of [us]852-our at this very time ; [you]845-you , [reader]853-reader , [I]0-i , [writer]854-writer , have each [our]852-our great sorrow bearing down upon [us]852-our . It may be yet beyond the dimmest point of [our]852-our horizon , but in the stillness of the night [our]852-our hearts shrink at the sound of its coming footstep . Well is it for [those who fall into the hands of [the Lord]856-the lord rather than into the hands of [men]857-men]855-those who fall into the hands of the lord rather than into the hands of men ; but worst of all is it for [him]858-him who has hereafter to mingle the gall of remorse with the cup held out to [him]858-him by [his]858-him doom . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins took [his]66-mr. wilkins ease and [his]66-mr. wilkins pleasure yet more and more every year of [his]66-mr. wilkins life ; nor did the quality of [his]66-mr. wilkins ease and [his]66-mr. wilkins pleasure improve ; it seldom does with [self - indulgent people]859-self - indulgent people . [He]66-mr. wilkins cared less for any books that strained [his]66-mr. wilkins faculties a little -- less for engravings and sculptures -- perhaps more for pictures . [He]66-mr. wilkins spent extravagantly on [his]66-mr. wilkins horses ; " thought of eating and drinking . "[66-mr. wilkins] There was no open vice in all this , so that any awful temptation to crime should come down upon [him]66-mr. wilkins , and startle [him]66-mr. wilkins out of [his]66-mr. wilkins mode of thinking and living ; [half the people about [him]66-mr. wilkins]860-half the people about him did much the same , as far as [their]860-half the people about him lives were patent to [his]66-mr. wilkins unreflecting observation . But most of [[his]66-mr. wilkins associates]861-his associates had [their]860-half the people about him duties to do , and did [them]860-half the people about him with a heart and a will , in the hours when [he]66-mr. wilkins was not in [their]860-half the people about him company . Yes ! [I]0-i call [them]860-half the people about him duties , though some of them might be self - imposed and purely social ; they were engagements [they]860-half the people about him had entered into , either tacitly or with words , and that [they]860-half the people about him fulfilled . From [Mr. Hetherington]92-mr. hetherington , [the Master of the Hounds]862-the master of the hounds , who was up at -- [no one]385-no one knows what hour , to go down to [the kennel]864-the kennel and see that [the men]865-the men did [their]865-the men work well and thoroughly , to [stern old Sir Lionel Playfair]93-stern old sir lionel playfair , [the upright magistrate]866-the upright magistrate , [the thoughtful , conscientious landlord]867-the thoughtful , conscientious landlord -- [they]865-the men did [their]865-the men work according to [their]865-the men lights ; there were [few laggards among those with whom [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins associated in [the field]869-the field or at the dinner - table]868-few laggards among those with whom mr. wilkins associated in the field or at the dinner - table . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness -- though as [a clergyman]870-a clergyman [he]80-mr. ness was not so active as [he]80-mr. ness might have been -- yet even [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness fagged away with [[his]80-mr. ness pupils]871-his pupils and [his]80-mr. ness new edition of one of the classics . Only [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , dissatisfied with [his]66-mr. wilkins position , neglected to fulfil the duties thereof . [He]66-mr. wilkins imitated the pleasures , and longed for the fancied leisure of [those about [him]66-mr. wilkins]872-those about him ; leisure that [he]66-mr. wilkins imagined would be so much more valuable in the hands of [a man like [himself]66-mr. wilkins]873-a man like himself , full of intellectual tastes and accomplishments , than frittered away by [dull boors of untravelled , uncultivated squires]874-dull boors of untravelled , uncultivated squires -- whose company , however , be it said by the way , [he]66-mr. wilkins never refused . And yet [daily Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was sinking from the intellectually to [the sensually self - indulgent man]875-the sensually self - indulgent man . [He]66-mr. wilkins lay late in bed , and hated [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster for [his]84-mr. dunster significant glance at [the office]580-the office - clock when [he]84-mr. dunster announced to [[his]84-mr. dunster master]480-his master that such and [such a client]878-such a client had been waiting more than an hour to keep an appointment . " Why did n't [you]84-mr. dunster see [him]878-such a client [yourself]84-mr. dunster , [Dunster]84-mr. dunster ? [I]66-mr. wilkins 'm sure [you]84-mr. dunster would have done quite as well as [me]66-mr. wilkins , "[66-mr. wilkins] [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins sometimes replied , partly with a view of saying something pleasant to [the man whom [he]66-mr. wilkins disliked and feared]879-the man whom he disliked and feared . [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster always replied , in a meek matter - of- fact tone , " Oh , [sir]2656-sir , [they]881-importunate clients would n't like to talk over [their]881-importunate clients affairs with [a subordinate]2657-a subordinate . "[84-mr. dunster] And every time [he]66-mr. wilkins said this , or some speech of the same kind , the idea came more and more clearly into [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's head , of how pleasant it would be to [himself]66-mr. wilkins to take [Dunster]84-mr. dunster into partnership , and thus throw all the responsibility of the real work and drudgery upon [[his]66-mr. wilkins clerk]880-his clerk 's shoulders . [Importunate clients]881-importunate clients , who would make appointments at unseasonable hours and would keep to [them]881-importunate clients , might confide in [the partner]882-the partner , though [they]881-importunate clients would not in [the clerk]883-the clerk . The great objections to this course were , first and foremost , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's strong dislike to [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster -- [his]84-mr. dunster repugnance to [[his]84-mr. dunster company]884-his company , [his]84-mr. dunster dress , [his]84-mr. dunster voice , [his]84-mr. dunster ways -- all of which irritated [[his]84-mr. dunster employer]675-his employer , till [his]84-mr. dunster state of feeling towards [Dunster]84-mr. dunster might be called antipathy ; next , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was fully aware of the fact that all [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's actions and words were carefully and thoughtfully pre- arranged to further the great unspoken desire of [his]84-mr. dunster life -- that of being made [a partner]886-a partner where [he]84-mr. dunster now was only [a servant]700-a servant . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins took a malicious pleasure in tantalizing [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster by such speeches as the one [I]0-i have just mentioned , which always seemed like an opening to the desired end , but still for a long time never led any further . Yet all the while that end was becoming more and more certain , and at last it was reached . [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster always suspected that the final push was given by some circumstance from without ; some reprimand for neglect -- some threat of withdrawal of business which [[his]84-mr. dunster employer]675-his employer had received ; but of this [he]84-mr. dunster could not be certain ; all [he]84-mr. dunster knew was , that [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins proposed the partnership to [him]84-mr. dunster in about as ungracious a way as such an offer could be made ; an ungraciousness which , after all , had so little effect on the real matter in hand , that [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster could pass over it with a private sneer , while taking all possible advantage of the tangible benefit it was now in [his]84-mr. dunster power to accept . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's attachment to [Ellinor]73-ellinor had been formally disclosed to [her]73-ellinor just before this time . [He]84-mr. dunster had left college , entered at [the Middle Temple]889-the middle temple , and was fagging away at law , and feeling success in [his]84-mr. dunster own power ; [Ellinor]73-ellinor was to " come out "[73-ellinor] at the next [Hamley]1-hamley assemblies ; and [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover began to be jealous of the possible admirers [her]73-ellinor striking appearance and piquant conversation might attract , and thought it a good time to make the success of [his]84-mr. dunster suit certain by spoken words and promises . [He]84-mr. dunster needed not have alarmed [himself]84-mr. dunster even enough to make [him]84-mr. dunster take this step , if [he]84-mr. dunster had been capable of understanding [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's heart as fully as [he]84-mr. dunster did [her]73-ellinor appearance and conversation . [She]73-ellinor never missed the absence of formal words and promises . [She]73-ellinor considered [herself]73-ellinor as fully engaged to [him]84-mr. dunster , as much pledged to marry [him]84-mr. dunster and [no one else]891-no one else , before [he]84-mr. dunster had asked the final question , as afterwards . "[81-mr. corbet] " Well , "[66-mr. wilkins] said [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins -- [he]66-mr. wilkins had resumed [his]66-mr. wilkins cigar , partly to conceal [his]66-mr. wilkins agitation at what [he]66-mr. wilkins knew was coming--"I believe [I]66-mr. wilkins have had [my]66-mr. wilkins suspicions . "[66-mr. wilkins] [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins did not speak for a little while -- a touch , a thought , a word more would have brought [him]66-mr. wilkins to tears ; for at the last [he]66-mr. wilkins found it hard to give the consent which would part [him]66-mr. wilkins from [[his]66-mr. wilkins only child]899-his only child . CHAPTER V. A few days afterwards , [[Ellinor]73-ellinor 's father]908-ellinor 's father bethought [himself]908-ellinor 's father that same further communication ought to take place between [him]908-ellinor 's father and [[[his]908-ellinor 's father daughter]520-his daughter 's lover]910-his daughter 's lover regarding the approval of the family of [the latter]271-the latter to [the young man]309-the young man 's engagement , and [he]908-ellinor 's father accordingly wrote a very gentlemanly letter , saying that of course [he]908-ellinor 's father trusted that [Ralph]81-mr. corbet had informed [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father of [his]81-mr. corbet engagement ; that [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet was well known to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins by reputation , holding the position which [he]81-mr. corbet did in [Shropshire]17-shropshire , but that as [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins did not pretend to be in the same station of life , [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet might possibly never even have heard of [his]66-mr. wilkins name , although in [[his]66-mr. wilkins own county]914-his own county it was well known as having been for generations that of [the principal conveyancer and land - agent of [---shire]6----shire]915-the principal conveyancer and land - agent of ---shire ; that [[his]66-mr. wilkins wife]227-his wife had been [a member of [the old knightly family of Holsters]918-the old knightly family of holsters]917-a member of the old knightly family of holsters , and that [he]66-mr. wilkins [himself]66-mr. wilkins was descended from [a younger branch of [the South Wales De Wintons]95-the south wales de wintons]919-a younger branch of the south wales de wintons , or [Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins ; that [Ellinor]73-ellinor , as [[his]66-mr. wilkins only child]899-his only child , would naturally inherit all [his]66-mr. wilkins property , but that in the meantime , of course , some settlement upon [her]73-ellinor would be made , the nature of which might be decided nearer the time of the marriage . It was a very good straightforward letter and well fitted for the purpose to which [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins knew it would be applied -- of being forwarded to [[the young man]309-the young man 's father]922-the young man 's father . One would have thought that it was not an engagement so disproportionate in point of station as to cause any great opposition on that score ; but , unluckily , [Captain Corbet]96-captain corbet , [the heir and eldest son]923-the heir and eldest son , had just formed a similar engagement with [Lady Maria Brabant]97-lady maria , [the daughter of one of [the proudest earls in [---shire]6----shire , who had always resented [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's appearance on [the field]869-the field as an insult to [the county]311-the county , and ignored [his]66-mr. wilkins presence at every dinner - table where [they]928-they met]925-the proudest earls in ---shire , who had always resented mr. wilkins 's appearance on the field as an insult to the county , and ignored his presence at every dinner - table where they met]924-the daughter of one of the proudest earls in ---shire , who had always resented mr. wilkins 's appearance on the field as an insult to the county , and ignored his presence at every dinner - table where they met . [Lady Maria]97-lady maria was visiting [the Corbets]98-the corbets at the very time when [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's letter , enclosing [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's , reached [the paternal halls]929-the paternal halls , and [she]97-lady maria merely repeated [[her]97-lady maria father]398-her father 's opinions when [Mrs. Corbet]99-mrs. corbet and [[her]99-mrs. corbet daughters]313-her daughters naturally questioned [her]97-lady maria as to who [these Wilkinses]932-these wilkinses were ; [they]932-these wilkinses remembered the name in [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's letters formerly ; [the father]462-the father was [some friend of [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness 's , [the clergyman with whom [Ralph]81-mr. corbet had read]935-the clergyman with whom ralph had read]934-some friend of mr. ness 's , the clergyman with whom ralph had read ; [they]932-these wilkinses believed [Ralph]81-mr. corbet used to dine with [these Wilkinses]932-these wilkinses sometimes , along with [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness . [Lady Maria]97-lady maria was [a goodnatured girl]937-a goodnatured girl , and meant no harm in repeating [[her]97-lady maria father]398-her father 's words ; touched up , it is true , by some of the dislike [she]97-lady maria [herself]97-lady maria felt to the intimate alliance proposed , which would make [[her]97-lady maria sister - in - law]939-her sister - in - law to [the daughter of [an " upstart attorney]2669-an " upstart attorney]2668-the daughter of an " upstart attorney , "[937-a goodnatured girl] " not received in [the county]311-the county , "[937-a goodnatured girl] " always trying to push [his]81-mr. corbet way into the set above [him]81-mr. corbet , "[937-a goodnatured girl] " claiming connection with [the De Wintons of --- Castle , who , as [she]97-lady maria well knew , only laughed when [he]81-mr. corbet was spoken of , and said [they]2671-they were more rich in relations than [they]2671-they were aware of"--"not[937-a goodnatured girl] people papa would ever like [her]97-lady maria to know , whatever might be the family connection]100-the de wintons of --- castle , who , as she well knew , only laughed when he was spoken of , and said they were more rich in relations than they were aware of"--"not people papa would ever like her to know , whatever might be the family connection . " These little speeches told in a way which [the girl who uttered them]2672-the girl who uttered them did not intend [they]2671-they should . [Mrs. Corbet]99-mrs. corbet and [[her]99-mrs. corbet daughters]313-her daughters set [themselves]2671-they violently against this foolish entanglement of [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's ; [they]2671-they would not call it an engagement . [They]2671-they argued , and [they]2671-they urged , and [they]2671-they pleaded , till [the squire]570-the squire , anxious for peace at any price , and always more under the sway of [the people who were with [him]570-the squire]2675-the people who were with him , however unreasonable [they]2675-the people who were with him might be , than of [the absent]2676-the absent , even though these had the wisdom of [Solomon]101-solomon or the prudence and sagacity of [[his]570-the squire son]239-his son [Ralph]81-mr. corbet , wrote an angry letter , saying that , as [Ralph]81-mr. corbet was of age , of course [he]81-mr. corbet had a right to please [himself]81-mr. corbet , therefore all [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father could say was , that the engagement was not at all what either [he]570-the squire or [[Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's mother]2679-ralph 's mother had expected or hoped ; that it was a degradation to [the family]2680-the family just going to ally [themselves]2680-the family with [a peer of James the First]2681-a peer of james the first 's creation ; that of course [Ralph]81-mr. corbet must do what [he]81-mr. corbet liked , but that if [he]81-mr. corbet married [this girl]2682-this girl [he]81-mr. corbet must never expect to have [her]2682-this girl received by [the Corbets of [Corbet Hall]18-corbet hall]2683-the corbets of corbet hall as [a daughter]2684-a daughter . [The squire]570-the squire was rather satisfied with [his]570-the squire production , and took it to show it to [[his]570-the squire wife]227-his wife ; but [she]227-his wife did not think it was strong enough , and added a little postscript "[102-dear ralph] [DEAR RALPH]102-dear ralph , " Though , as [second son]2687-second son , [you]102-dear ralph are entitled to [Bromley]103-bromley at [my]102-dear ralph death , yet [I]102-dear ralph can do much to make the estate worthless . Hitherto , regard for [you]102-dear ralph has prevented [my]102-dear ralph taking steps as to sale of timber , & amp;c . , which would materially increase [[your]102-dear ralph sisters]2688-your sisters ' portions ; this just measure [I]102-dear ralph shall infallibly take if [I]102-dear ralph find [you]102-dear ralph persevere in keeping to this silly engagement . [[Your]102-dear ralph father]2658-your father 's disapproval is always a sufficient reason to allege . "[102-dear ralph] [Ralph]102-dear ralph was annoyed at the receipt of these letters , though [he]102-dear ralph only smiled as [he]102-dear ralph locked them up in [his]102-dear ralph desk . " [Dear old father]2690-dear old father ! how [he]2658-your father blusters ! As to [[my]102-dear ralph mother]2691-my mother , [she]2691-my mother is reasonable when [I]102-dear ralph talk to [her]2691-my mother . Once give [her]2691-my mother a definite idea of what [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's fortune will be , and let [her]2691-my mother , if [she]2691-my mother chooses , cut down [her]2691-my mother timber -- a threat [she]2691-my mother has held over [me]102-dear ralph ever since [I]102-dear ralph knew what a rocking - horse was , and which [I]102-dear ralph have known to be illegal these ten years past -- and [she]2691-my mother 'll come round . [I]102-dear ralph know better than [they]2692-they do how [Reginald]104-reginald has run up post - obits , and as for [that vulgar high - born [Lady Maria]97-lady maria]2693-that vulgar high - born lady maria [they]2692-they are all so full of , why , [she]2693-that vulgar high - born lady maria is [a Flanders mare to [[my]102-dear ralph Ellinor]2660-my ellinor]2694-a flanders mare to my ellinor , and has not a silver penny to cross [herself]2693-that vulgar high - born lady maria with , besides ! [I]102-dear ralph bide [my]102-dear ralph time , [you dear good people]2696-you dear good people ! "[102-dear ralph] [He]940-he did not think it necessary to reply to these letters immediately , nor did [he]940-he even allude to their contents in [his]940-he to [Ellinor]73-ellinor . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , who had been very well satisfied with [his]66-mr. wilkins own letter to [the young man]309-the young man , and had thought that it must be equally agreeable to [every one]497-every one , was not at all suspicious of any disapproval , because the fact of a distinct sanction on the part of [[Mr. Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's friends]943-mr. ralph corbet 's friends to [his]940-he engagement was not communicated to [him]940-he . As for [Ellinor]73-ellinor , [she]73-ellinor trembled all over with happiness . Such a summer for the blossoming of flowers and ripening of fruit had not been known for years ; it seemed to [her]73-ellinor as if bountiful loving [Nature]105-nature wanted to fill the cup of [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's joy to overflowing , and as if everything , animate and inanimate , sympathised with [her]73-ellinor happiness . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father was well , and apparently content . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro was very kind . [Dixon]86-dixon 's lameness was quite gone off . [Only Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster came creeping about [the house]761-the house , on pretence of business , seeking out [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , and disturbing all [his]398-her father leisure with [his]398-her father dust - coloured parchment - skinned careworn face , and seeming to disturb the smooth current of [her]73-ellinor daily life whenever [she]73-ellinor saw [him]398-her father . [Ellinor]73-ellinor made [her]73-ellinor appearance at [the Hamley assemblies]343-the hamley assemblies , but with less _ eclat _ than either [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father or [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover expected . [Her]73-ellinor beauty and natural grace were admired by those who could discriminate ; but to the greater number there was ( what [they]950-they called ) " a want of style"--want[950-they] of elegance there certainly was not , for [her]73-ellinor figure was perfect , and though [she]73-ellinor moved shyly , [she]73-ellinor moved well . Perhaps it was not a good place for a correct appreciation of [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins ; [some of [the old dowagers]952-the old dowagers]951-some of the old dowagers thought it a piece of presumption in [her]73-ellinor to be there at all -- but [the Lady Holster of the day]953-the lady holster of the day ( who remembered [[her]953-the lady holster of the day husband]407-her husband 's quarrel with [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , and looked away whenever [Ellinor]73-ellinor came near ) resented this opinion . " [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins is descended from [[Sir Frank]68-sir frank holster 's family]2697-sir frank 's family , [one of [the oldest in [the county]311-the county]2699-the oldest in the county]2698-one of the oldest in the county ; the objection might have been made years ago to [the father]462-the father , but as [he]462-the father had been received , [she]106-miss wilkins did not know why [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins was to be alluded to as out of [her]106-miss wilkins place . "[73-ellinor] [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's greatest enjoyment in the evening was to hear [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father say , after all was over , and [they]956-they were driving home-- " Well , [I]398-her father thought [my]398-her father Nelly [the prettiest girl there]2702-the prettiest girl there , and [I]398-her father think [I]398-her father know [some other people who would have said the same if [they]2703-some other people who would have said the same if they could have spoken out could have spoken out]2703-some other people who would have said the same if they could have spoken out . "[398-her father] " Thank [you]398-her father , [papa]2614-papa , "[73-ellinor] said [Ellinor]73-ellinor , squeezing [his]398-her father hand , which [she]73-ellinor held . [She]73-ellinor thought [he]398-her father alluded to [the absent Ralph]957-the absent ralph as [the person who would have agreed with [him]398-her father , had [he]398-her father had the opportunity of seeing [her]73-ellinor]958-the person who would have agreed with him , had he had the opportunity of seeing her ; but no , [he]398-her father seldom thought much of the absent ; but had been rather flattered by seeing [Lord Hildebrand]107-lord hildebrand take up [his]107-lord hildebrand glass for the apparent purpose of watching [Ellinor]73-ellinor . " [Your]73-ellinor pearls , too , were as handsome as any in [the room]479-the room , [child]466-child -- but [we]2707-we must have them re - set ; the sprays are old - fashioned now . Let [me]107-lord hildebrand have them to - morrow to send up to [Hancock]108-hancock . "[107-lord hildebrand] " [Papa]109-papa , please , [I]398-her father had rather keep them as they are -- as [mamma]2708-mamma wore them . "[398-her father] [He]398-her father was touched in a minute . " Very well , [darling]2659-darling . God bless [you]73-ellinor for thinking of it ! "[398-her father] But [he]398-her father ordered [her]73-ellinor a set of sapphires instead , for the next assembly . These balls were not such as to intoxicate [Ellinor]73-ellinor with success , and make [her]73-ellinor in love with gaiety . [Large parties]959-large parties came from [the different country- houses in [the neighbourhood]961-the neighbourhood]960-the different country- houses in the neighbourhood , and danced with [each other]523-each other . When [they]959-large parties had exhausted the resources [they]959-large parties brought with [them]959-large parties , [they]959-large parties had generally a few dances to spare for [friends of the same standing with whom]963-friends of the same standing with whom [they]959-large parties were most intimate . [Ellinor]73-ellinor came with [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , and joined [an old card - playing dowager]965-an old card - playing dowager , by way of [a chaperone]966-a chaperone -- [the said dowager]967-the said dowager being under old business obligations to [the firm of [Wilkins]73-ellinor and [Son]969-son]968-the firm of wilkins and son , and apologizing to all [[her]967-the said dowager acquaintances]970-her acquaintances for [her]967-the said dowager own weak condescension to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's foible in wishing to introduce [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter into society above [her]967-the said dowager natural sphere . It was upon [this lady]972-this lady , after [she]972-this lady had uttered some such speech as the one [I]0-i have just mentioned , that [Lady Holster]76-lady holster had come down with the pedigree of [[Ellinor]73-ellinor 's mother]973-ellinor 's mother . But though [the old dowager]974-the old dowager had drawn back a little discomfited at [[my]0-i lady]975-my lady 's reply , [she]974-the old dowager was not more attentive to [Ellinor]73-ellinor in consequence . [She]974-the old dowager allowed [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins to bring in [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter and place [her]520-his daughter on the crimson sofa beside [her]974-the old dowager ; spoke to [her]974-the old dowager occasionally in the interval that elapsed before the rubbers could be properly arranged in [the card - room]977-the card - room ; invited [the girl]527-the girl to accompany [her]974-the old dowager to that sober amusement , and on [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's declining , and preferring to remain with [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , [the dowager]980-the dowager left [her]73-ellinor with a sweet smile on [her]73-ellinor plump countenance , and an approving conscience somewhere within [her]73-ellinor portly frame , assuring [her]73-ellinor that [she]73-ellinor had done all that could possibly have been expected from [her]73-ellinor towards " [that good [[Wilkins]73-ellinor 's daughter]2711-wilkins 's daughter]2710-that good wilkins 's daughter . "[73-ellinor] [Ellinor]73-ellinor stood by [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father watching the dances , and thankful for the occasional chance of a dance . While [she]73-ellinor had been sitting by [[her]73-ellinor chaperone]982-her chaperone , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had made the tour of [the room]479-the room , dropping out the little fact of [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter 's being present wherever [he]66-mr. wilkins thought the seed likely to bring forth the fruit of [partners]985-partners . And [some]986-some came because [they]986-some liked [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , and [some]986-some asked [Ellinor]73-ellinor because [they]986-some had done [their]986-some duty dances to [[their]986-some own party]988-their own party , and might please [themselves]986-some . So that [she]73-ellinor usually had an average of one invitation to every three dances ; and this principally towards the end of the evening . But considering [her]73-ellinor real beauty , and the care which [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father always took about [her]73-ellinor appearance , [she]73-ellinor met with far less than [her]73-ellinor due of admiration . Admiration [she]73-ellinor did not care for ; [partners]985-partners [she]73-ellinor did ; and sometimes felt mortified when [she]73-ellinor had to sit or stand quiet during all the first part of the evening . If it had not been for [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's wishes [she]73-ellinor would much rather have stayed at [home]230-home ; but , nevertheless , [she]73-ellinor talked even to [the irresponsive old dowager]993-the irresponsive old dowager , and fairly chatted to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father when [she]73-ellinor got beside [him]398-her father , because [she]73-ellinor did not like [him]398-her father to fancy that [she]73-ellinor was not enjoying [herself]73-ellinor . And , indeed , [she]73-ellinor had so much happiness in the daily course of this part of [her]73-ellinor life , that , on looking back upon it afterwards , [she]73-ellinor could not imagine anything brighter than it had been . The delight of receiving [[her]73-ellinor [lover]996-lover]890-her lover 's letters -- the anxious happiness of replying to them ( always a little bit fearful lest [she]73-ellinor should not express [herself]73-ellinor and [her]73-ellinor love in the precisely happy medium becoming [a maiden)--the father]997-a maiden)--the father 's love and satisfaction in [her]73-ellinor -- the calm prosperity of [the whole household]998-the whole household -- was delightful at the time , and , looking back upon it , it was dreamlike . [Occasionally Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet came down to see [her]73-ellinor . [He]398-her father always slept on these occasions at [[Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness 's]999-mr. ness 's ; but [he]398-her father was at [Ford Bank]15-ford bank the greater part of the one day between two nights that [he]398-her father allowed [himself]398-her father for the length of [his]398-her father visits . And even these short peeps were not frequently taken .
