[He]398-her father was working hard at law : fagging at it tooth and nail ; arranging [his]398-her father whole life so as best to promote the ends of [his]398-her father ambition ; feeling a delight in surpassing and mastering [[his]398-her father fellows]243-his fellows -- [those who started in the race at the same time]1001-those who started in the race at the same time . [He]398-her father read [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's letters over and over again ; nothing else beside law - books . [He]398-her father perceived the repressed love hidden away in subdued expressions in [her]73-ellinor communications , with an amused pleasure at the attempt at concealment . [He]398-her father was glad that [her]73-ellinor gaieties were not more gay ; [he]398-her father was glad that [she]73-ellinor was not too much admired , although a little indignant at the want of taste on the part of [the ---shire gentlemen]1002-the ---shire gentlemen . But if [other admirers]1003-other admirers had come prominently forward , [he]398-her father would have had to take some more decided steps to assert [his]398-her father rights than [he]398-her father had hitherto done ; for [he]398-her father had caused [Ellinor]73-ellinor to express a wish to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father that [her]73-ellinor engagement should not be too much talked about until nearer the time when it would be prudent for [him]398-her father to marry [her]73-ellinor . [He]398-her father thought that the knowledge of this , the only imprudently hasty step [he]398-her father ever meant to take in [his]398-her father life , might go against [his]398-her father character for wisdom , if the fact became known while [he]398-her father was as yet only [a student]1005-a student . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins wondered a little ; but acceded , as [he]66-mr. wilkins always did , to any of [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's requests . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness was [a confidant]1006-a confidant , of course , and [some of [[Lady Maria]97-lady maria 's connections]1008-lady maria 's connections]1007-some of lady maria 's connections heard of it , and forgot it again very soon ; and , as it happened , [no one else]891-no one else was sufficiently interested in [Ellinor]73-ellinor to care to ascertain the fact . All this time , [Mr. Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet maintained a very quietly decided attitude towards [[his]81-mr. corbet own family]1010-his own family . [He]81-mr. corbet was engaged to [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins ; and all [he]81-mr. corbet could say was , [he]81-mr. corbet felt sorry that [they]1010-his own family disapproved of it . [He]81-mr. corbet was not able to marry just at present , and before the time for [his]81-mr. corbet marriage arrived , [he]81-mr. corbet trusted that [[his]81-mr. corbet family]1011-his family would take a more reasonable view of things , and be willing to receive [her]73-ellinor as [[his]81-mr. corbet wife]227-his wife with all becoming respect or affection . This was the substance of what [he]81-mr. corbet repeated in different forms in reply to [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father 's angry letters . At length , [his]81-mr. corbet invariable determination made way with [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father ; the paternal thunderings were subdued to a distant rumbling in the sky ; and presently the inquiry was broached as to how much fortune [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins would have ; how much down on [her]106-miss wilkins marriage ; what were the eventual probabilities . Now this was a point which [Mr. Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet [himself]81-mr. corbet wished to be informed upon . [He]81-mr. corbet had not thought much about it in making the engagement ; [he]81-mr. corbet had been too young , or too much in love . But [an only child of [a wealthy attorney]1016-a wealthy attorney]1015-an only child of a wealthy attorney ought to have something considerable ; and an allowance so as to enable [the young couple]1017-the young couple to start housekeeping in [a moderately good part of [town]2661-town]1018-a moderately good part of town , would be an advantage to [him]81-mr. corbet in [his]81-mr. corbet profession . So [he]81-mr. corbet replied to [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father , adroitly suggesting that a letter containing certain modifications of the inquiry which had been rather roughly put in [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's last , should be sent to [him]81-mr. corbet , in order that [he]81-mr. corbet might [himself]81-mr. corbet ascertain from [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins what were [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's prospects as regarded fortune . The desired letter came ; but not in such a form that [he]81-mr. corbet could pass it on to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins ; [he]81-mr. corbet preferred to make quotations , and even these quotations were a little altered and dressed before [he]81-mr. corbet sent them on . The gist of [his]81-mr. corbet letter to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was this . [He]81-mr. corbet stated that [he]81-mr. corbet hoped soon to be in a position to offer [Ellinor]73-ellinor a [home]230-home ; that [he]81-mr. corbet anticipated a steady progress in [his]81-mr. corbet profession , and consequently in [his]81-mr. corbet income ; but that contingencies might arise , as [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father suggested , which would deprive [him]81-mr. corbet of the power of earning a livelihood , perhaps when it might be more required than it would be at first ; that it was true that , after [[his]81-mr. corbet mother]269-his mother 's death [a small estate in [Shropshire]17-shropshire]1024-a small estate in shropshire would come to [him]81-mr. corbet as [second son]2687-second son , and of course [Ellinor]73-ellinor would receive the benefit of [this property]1026-this property , secured to [her]269-his mother legally as [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins thought best -- that being a matter for after discussion -- but that at present [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father was anxious , as might be seen from the extract to ascertain whether [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins could secure [him]222-his father from the contingency of having [[his]222-his father son]239-his son 's widow and [possible children]1029-possible children thrown upon [his]222-his father hands , by giving [Ellinor]73-ellinor a dowry ; and if so , it was gently insinuated , what would be the amount of the same . When [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins received this letter it startled [him]66-mr. wilkins out of a happy day- dream . [He]66-mr. wilkins liked [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet and the whole connection quite well enough to give [his]66-mr. wilkins consent to an engagement ; and sometimes even [he]66-mr. wilkins was glad to think that [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's future was assured , and that [she]73-ellinor would have [a protector]1030-a protector and [friends]1031-friends after [he]66-mr. wilkins was dead and gone . But [he]66-mr. wilkins did not want [them]1032-them to assume [their]1032-them responsibilities so soon . [He]66-mr. wilkins had not distinctly contemplated [her]73-ellinor marriage as an event likely to happen before [his]66-mr. wilkins death . [He]66-mr. wilkins could not understand how [his]66-mr. wilkins own life would go on without [her]73-ellinor : or indeed why [she]73-ellinor and [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet could not continue just as [they]1032-them were at present . [He]66-mr. wilkins came down to breakfast with the letter in [his]66-mr. wilkins hand . By [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's blushes , as [she]73-ellinor glanced at the handwriting , [he]66-mr. wilkins knew that [she]73-ellinor had heard from [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover by the same post ; by [her]73-ellinor tender caresses -- caresses given as if to make up for the pain which the prospect of [her]73-ellinor leaving [him]66-mr. wilkins was sure to cause [him]66-mr. wilkins -- [he]66-mr. wilkins was certain that [she]73-ellinor was aware of the contents of the letter . Yet [he]66-mr. wilkins put it in [his]66-mr. wilkins pocket , and tried to forget it . [He]66-mr. wilkins did this not merely from [his]66-mr. wilkins reluctance to complete any arrangements which might facilitate [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's marriage . There was a further annoyance connected with the affair . [His]66-mr. wilkins money matters had been for some time in an involved state ; [he]66-mr. wilkins had been living beyond [his]66-mr. wilkins income , even reckoning that , as [he]66-mr. wilkins always did , at the highest point which it ever touched . [He]66-mr. wilkins kept no regular accounts , reasoning with [himself]66-mr. wilkins -- or , perhaps , [I]0-i should rather say persuading [himself]66-mr. wilkins -- that there was no great occasion for regular accounts , when [he]66-mr. wilkins had a steady income arising from [his]66-mr. wilkins profession , as well as the interest of a good sum of money left [him]66-mr. wilkins by [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father ; and when , living in [[his]66-mr. wilkins own house]1035-his own house near [a country town]1036-a country town where provisions were cheap , [his]66-mr. wilkins expenditure for [[his]66-mr. wilkins small family]1037-his small family -- [only one child]1038-only one child -- could never amount to anything like [his]66-mr. wilkins incomings from the above- mentioned sources . But [servants]1039-servants and horses , and choice wines and rare fruit - trees , and a habit of purchasing any book or engraving that may take the fancy , irrespective of the price , run away with money , even though there be but [one child]1040-one child . A year or two ago , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had been startled into a system of exaggerated retrenchment -- retrenchment which only lasted about six weeks -- by the sudden bursting of a bubble speculation in which [he]66-mr. wilkins had invested a part of [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's savings . But as soon as the change in [his]66-mr. wilkins habits , necessitated by [his]66-mr. wilkins new economies , became irksome , [he]66-mr. wilkins had comforted [himself]66-mr. wilkins for [his]66-mr. wilkins relapse into [his]66-mr. wilkins former easy extravagance of living by remembering the fact that [Ellinor]73-ellinor was engaged to [the son of [a man of large property]1043-a man of large property]1042-the son of a man of large property : and that though [Ralph]81-mr. corbet was only [the second son]1044-the second son , yet [[his]81-mr. corbet mother]269-his mother 's estate must come to [him]81-mr. corbet , as [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness had already mentioned , on first hearing of [her]73-ellinor engagement . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins did not doubt that [he]66-mr. wilkins could easily make [Ellinor]73-ellinor a fitting allowance , or even pay down a requisite dowry ; but the doing so would involve an examination into the real state of [his]66-mr. wilkins affairs , and this involved distasteful trouble . [He]66-mr. wilkins had no idea how much more than mere temporary annoyance would arise out of the investigation . Until it was made , [he]66-mr. wilkins decided in [his]66-mr. wilkins own mind that [he]66-mr. wilkins would not speak to [Ellinor]73-ellinor on the subject of [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover 's letter . So for the next few days [she]73-ellinor was kept in suspense , seeing little of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father ; and during the short times [she]73-ellinor was with [him]398-her father [she]73-ellinor was made aware that [he]398-her father was nervously anxious to keep the conversation engaged on general topics rather than on the one which [she]73-ellinor had at heart . As [I]0-i have already said , [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet had written to [her]73-ellinor by the same post as that on which [he]81-mr. corbet sent the letter to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , telling [her]73-ellinor of its contents , and begging [her]73-ellinor ( in all those sweet words which [lovers]1049-lovers know how to use ) to urge [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father to compliance for [his]398-her father sake -- [his]398-her father , [[her]73-ellinor lover's]1051-her lover's -- who was pining and lonely in all the crowds of [London]4-london , since [her]73-ellinor loved presence was not there . [He]398-her father did not care for money , save as a means of hastening [their]1052-their marriage ; indeed , if there were only some income fixed , however small -- some time for [their]1052-their marriage fixed , however distant -- [he]398-her father could be patient . [He]398-her father did not want superfluity of wealth ; [his]398-her father habits were simple , as [she]73-ellinor well knew ; and money enough would be theirs in time , both from [her]73-ellinor share of contingencies , and the certainty of [his]398-her father finally possessing [Bromley]103-bromley . [Ellinor]73-ellinor delayed replying to this letter until [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father should have spoken to [her]73-ellinor on the subject . But as [she]73-ellinor perceived that [he]398-her father avoided all such conversation , [the young girl]1054-the young girl 's heart failed [her]73-ellinor . [She]73-ellinor began to blame [herself]73-ellinor for wishing to leave [him]398-her father , to reproach [herself]73-ellinor for being accessory to any step which made [him]398-her father shun being alone with [her]73-ellinor , and look distressed and full of care as [he]398-her father did now . It was the usual struggle between [father]474-father and [lover]996-lover for the possession of love , instead of the natural and graceful resignation of [the parent]1057-the parent to the prescribed course of things ; and , as usual , it was [the poor girl]1058-the poor girl who bore the suffering for no fault of [her]1058-the poor girl own : although [she]1058-the poor girl blamed [herself]1058-the poor girl for being [the cause of the disturbance in the previous order of affairs]1059-the cause of the disturbance in the previous order of affairs . [Ellinor]73-ellinor had [no one]385-no one to speak to confidentially but [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father and [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover , and when [they]1063-they were at issue [she]73-ellinor could talk openly to [neither]1064-neither , so [she]73-ellinor brooded over [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's unanswered letter , and [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's silence , and became pale and dispirited . Once or twice [she]73-ellinor looked up suddenly , and caught [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's eye gazing upon [her]73-ellinor with a certain wistful anxiety ; but the instant [she]73-ellinor saw this [he]398-her father pulled [himself]398-her father up , as it were , and would begin talking gaily about the small topics of the day . At length [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet grew impatient at not hearing either from [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins or [Ellinor]73-ellinor , and wrote urgently to [the former]1067-the former , making known to [him]1067-the former a new proposal suggested to [him]1067-the former by [[his]1067-the former father]222-his father , which was , that a certain sum should be paid down by [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins to be applied , under the management of [trustees]1069-trustees , to the improvement of [the Bromley estate]1070-the bromley estate , out of the profits of which , or other sources in [the elder Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's hands , a heavy rate of interest should be paid on this advance , which would secure an income to [the young couple]1017-the young couple immediately , and considerably increase the value of the estate upon which [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's settlement was to be made . The terms offered for this laying down of ready money were so advantageous , that [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was strongly tempted to accede to [them]1072-them at once ; as [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's pale cheek and want of appetite had only that very morning smote upon [his]398-her father conscience , and this immediate transfer of ready money was as a sacrifice , a soothing balm to [his]398-her father self - reproach , and laziness and dislike to immediate unpleasantness of action had its counterbalancing weakness in imprudence . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins made some rough calculations on a piece of paper -- deeds , and all such tests of accuracy , being down at [the office]580-the office ; discovered that [he]66-mr. wilkins could pay down the sum required ; wrote a letter agreeing to the proposal , and before [he]66-mr. wilkins sealed it called [Ellinor]73-ellinor into [[his]66-mr. wilkins study]469-his study , and bade [her]73-ellinor read what [he]66-mr. wilkins had been writing and tell [him]66-mr. wilkins what [she]73-ellinor thought of it . [He]66-mr. wilkins watched the colour come rushing into [her]73-ellinor white face , [her]73-ellinor lips quiver and tremble , and even before the letter was ended [she]73-ellinor was in [his]66-mr. wilkins arms kissing [him]66-mr. wilkins , and thanking [him]66-mr. wilkins with blushing caresses rather than words . " There , there ! "[66-mr. wilkins] said [he]66-mr. wilkins , smiling and sighing ; " that will do . Why , [I]66-mr. wilkins do believe [you]73-ellinor took [me]66-mr. wilkins for [a hard - hearted father]2712-a hard - hearted father , just like [[a heroine]2713-a heroine 's father]2714-a heroine 's father in a book . [You]73-ellinor 've looked as woe - begone this week past as [Ophelia]110-ophelia . One ca n't make up [one]2715-one 's mind in a day about such sums of money as this , [little woman]2716-little woman ; and [you]73-ellinor should have let [[your]73-ellinor old father]2717-your old father have time to consider . "[66-mr. wilkins] " Oh , [papa]2614-papa ; [I]66-mr. wilkins was only afraid [you]2614-papa were angry . "[66-mr. wilkins] " Well , if [I]66-mr. wilkins was a bit perplexed , seeing [you]2614-papa look so ill and pining was not the way to bring [me]66-mr. wilkins round . [Old Corbet]81-mr. corbet , [I]66-mr. wilkins must say , is trying to make a good bargain for [[his]81-mr. corbet son]239-his son . It is well for [me]66-mr. wilkins that [I]66-mr. wilkins have never been [an extravagant man]233-an extravagant man . "[66-mr. wilkins] " But , [papa]2614-papa , [we]2722-we do n't want all this much . "[66-mr. wilkins] " Yes , yes ! it is all right . [You]73-ellinor shall go into [[their]2723-their family]2724-their family as [a well- portioned girl]2725-a well- portioned girl , if [you]73-ellinor ca n't go as [a Lady Maria]2726-a lady maria . Come , do n't trouble [your]73-ellinor little head any more about it . Give [me]66-mr. wilkins one more kiss , and then [we]2722-we 'll go and order the horses , and have a ride together , by way of keeping holiday . [I]66-mr. wilkins deserve a holiday , do n't [I]66-mr. wilkins , [Nelly]111-nelly ? "[66-mr. wilkins] [Some country people at work at the roadside]1075-some country people at work at the roadside , as [the father]462-the father and [daughter]484-daughter passed along , stopped to admire [their]1075-some country people at work at the roadside bright happy looks , and [one]2715-one spoke of the hereditary handsomeness of [the Wilkins family]1079-the wilkins family ( for [the old man]1080-the old man , [[the present Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's father]1081-the present mr. wilkins 's father , had been fine - looking in [his]1080-the old man drab breeches and gaiters , and usual assumption of [a yeoman]1082-a yeoman 's dress ) . [Another]1083-another said it was easy for [the rich]1084-the rich to be handsome ; [they]1084-the rich had always plenty to eat , and could ride when [they]1084-the rich were tired of walking , and had no care for the morrow to keep [them]1084-the rich from sleeping at nights . And , in sad acquiescence with [[their]1084-the rich contrasted lot]1085-their contrasted lot , [the men]865-the men went on with [their]1084-the rich hedging and ditching in silence . And yet , if [they]865-the men had known -- if [the poor]1087-the poor did know -- the troubles and temptations of [the rich]1084-the rich ; if [those men]1089-those men had foreseen the lot darkening over [the father]462-the father , and including [the daughter]1091-the daughter in its cloud ; if [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins [himself]66-mr. wilkins had even imagined such a future possible . . . Well , there was truth in [the old heathen]1092-the old heathen saying , " Let [no man]2727-no man be envied till [his]2727-no man death . "[1092-the old heathen] [Ellinor]73-ellinor had no more rides with [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father ; no , not ever again ; though [they]1094-they had stopped that afternoon at [the summit of [a breezy common]1096-a breezy common]1095-the summit of a breezy common , and looked at [a ruined hall]1097-a ruined hall , not so very far off ; and discussed whether [they]1094-they could reach [it]1097-a ruined hall that day , and decided that [it]1097-a ruined hall was too far away for anything but a hurried inspection , and that some day soon [they]1094-they would make [the old place]1098-the old place into the principal object of an excursion . But a rainy time came on , when no rides were possible ; and whether it was the influence of the weather , or some other care or trouble that oppressed [him]66-mr. wilkins , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins seemed to lose all wish for much active exercise , and rather sought a stimulus to [his]66-mr. wilkins spirits and circulation in wine . But of this [Ellinor]73-ellinor was innocently unaware . [He]66-mr. wilkins seemed dull and weary , and sat long , drowsing and drinking after dinner . If [the servants]1099-the servants had not been so fond of [him]66-mr. wilkins for much previous generosity and kindness , [they]1099-the servants would have complained now , and with reason , of [his]66-mr. wilkins irritability , for all sorts of things seemed to annoy [him]66-mr. wilkins . " [You]73-ellinor should get [the master]2636-the master to take a ride with [you]73-ellinor , [miss]2729-miss , "[86-dixon] said [Dixon]86-dixon , one day as [he]86-dixon was putting [Ellinor]73-ellinor on [her]73-ellinor horse . " [He]2636-the master 's not looking well , [he]2636-the master 's studying too much at [the office]580-the office . "[86-dixon] But when [Ellinor]73-ellinor named it to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , [he]66-mr. wilkins rather hastily replied that it was all very well for [women]833-women to ride out whenever [they]833-women liked -- [men]857-men had something else to do ; and then , as [he]66-mr. wilkins saw [her]73-ellinor look grave and puzzled , [he]66-mr. wilkins softened down [his]66-mr. wilkins abrupt saying by adding that [Dunster]84-mr. dunster had been making a fuss about [[his]84-mr. dunster partner]1103-his partner 's non - attendance , and altogether taking a good deal upon [himself]84-mr. dunster in a very offensive way , so that [he]66-mr. wilkins thought it better to go pretty regularly to [the office]580-the office , in order to show [him]84-mr. dunster who was [master]2621-master -- [senior partner]1106-senior partner , and head of the business , at any rate . [Ellinor]73-ellinor sighed a little over [her]73-ellinor disappointment at [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's preoccupation , and then forgot [her]73-ellinor own little regret in anger at [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster , who had seemed all along to be a thorn in [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's side , and had latterly gained some power and authority over [him]84-mr. dunster , the exercise of which , [Ellinor]73-ellinor could not help thinking , was a very impertinent line of conduct from [a junior partner]1109-a junior partner , so lately only [a paid clerk]1110-a paid clerk , to [[his]84-mr. dunster superior]1111-his superior . There was a sense of something wrong in [the Ford Bank household]1112-the ford bank household for many weeks about this time . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was not like [himself]66-mr. wilkins , and [his]66-mr. wilkins cheerful ways and careless genial speeches were missed , even on the days when [he]66-mr. wilkins was not irritable , and evidently uneasy with [himself]66-mr. wilkins and all about [him]66-mr. wilkins . The spring was late in coming , and cold rain and sleet made any kind of out - door exercise a trouble and discomfort rather than a bright natural event in the course of the day . All sound of winter gaieties , of assemblies and meets , and jovial dinners , had died away , and the summer pleasures were as yet unthought of . Still [Ellinor]73-ellinor had a secret perennial source of sunshine in [her]73-ellinor heart ; whenever [she]73-ellinor thought of [Ralph]81-mr. corbet [she]73-ellinor could not feel much oppression from the present unspoken and indistinct gloom . [He]81-mr. corbet loved [her]73-ellinor ; and oh , how [she]73-ellinor loved [him]81-mr. corbet ! and perhaps this very next autumn -- but that depended on [his]81-mr. corbet own success in [his]81-mr. corbet profession . After all , if it was not this autumn it would be the next ; and with the letters that [she]73-ellinor received weekly , and the occasional visits that [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover ran down to [Hamley]1-hamley to pay [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , [Ellinor]73-ellinor felt as if [she]73-ellinor would almost prefer the delay of the time when [she]73-ellinor must leave [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's for [a husband]402-a husband 's roof . CHAPTER VI . At Easter -- just when the heavens and earth were looking [their]1116-their dreariest , for Easter fell very early this year -- [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet came down . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was too busy to see much of [him]81-mr. corbet ; [they]1117-they were together even less than usual , although not less friendly when [they]1117-they did meet . But to [Ellinor]73-ellinor the visit was one of unmixed happiness . Hitherto [she]73-ellinor had always had a little fear mingled up with [her]73-ellinor love of [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet ; but [his]81-mr. corbet manners were softened , [his]81-mr. corbet opinions less decided and abrupt , and [his]81-mr. corbet whole treatment of [her]73-ellinor showed such tenderness , that [the young girl]1054-the young girl basked and revelled in it . One or two of [their]1117-they conversations had reference to [their]1117-they future married life in [London]4-london ; and [she]73-ellinor then perceived , although it did not jar against [her]73-ellinor , that [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover had not forgotten [his]890-her lover ambition in [his]890-her lover love . [He]81-mr. corbet tried to inoculate [her]73-ellinor with something of [his]81-mr. corbet own craving for success in life ; but it was all in vain : [she]73-ellinor nestled to [him]81-mr. corbet , and told [him]81-mr. corbet [she]73-ellinor did not care to be [[the Lord Chancellor]1120-the lord chancellor 's wife]1121-the lord chancellor 's wife -- wigs and wool - sacks were not in [her]73-ellinor line ; only if [he]81-mr. corbet wished it , [she]73-ellinor would wish it . The last two days of [his]81-mr. corbet stay the weather changed . Sudden heat burst forth , as it does occasionally for a few hours even in [our]1122-our chilly English spring . The grey - brown bushes and trees started almost with visible progress into the tender green shade which is the forerunner of the bursting leaves . The sky was of full cloudless blue . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was to come [home]230-home pretty early from [the office]580-the office to ride out with [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter and [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover ; but , after waiting some time for [him]66-mr. wilkins , it grew too late , and [they]1127-they were obliged to give up the project . Nothing would serve [Ellinor]73-ellinor , then , but that [she]73-ellinor must carry out a table and have tea in [the garden]711-the garden , on the sunny side of the tree , among the roots of which [she]73-ellinor used to play when [a child]584-a child . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro objected a little to this caprice of [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's , saying that it was too early for out - of - door meals ; but [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet overruled all objections , and helped [her]73-ellinor in [her]73-ellinor gay preparations . [She]73-ellinor always kept to the early hours of [her]73-ellinor childhood , although [she]73-ellinor , as then , regularly sat with [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father at [his]398-her father late dinner ; and this meal _ al fresco _ was to be a reality to [her]73-ellinor and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro . There was [a place arranged for [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father]1131-a place arranged for her father , and [she]73-ellinor seized upon [him]398-her father as [he]398-her father was coming from [the stable - yard]775-the stable - yard , by [the shrubbery path]1134-the shrubbery path , to [[his]398-her father study]469-his study , and with merry playfulness made [him]398-her father [a prisoner]1136-a prisoner , accusing [him]398-her father of disappointing [them]1137-them of [their]1137-them ride , and drawing [him]398-her father more than half unwilling , to [his]398-her father chair by the table . But [he]398-her father was silent , and almost sad : [his]398-her father presence damped [them]1137-them all ; [they]1137-them could hardly tell why , for [he]398-her father did not object to anything , though [he]398-her father seemed to enjoy nothing , and only to force a smile at [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's occasional sallies . These became more and more rare as [she]73-ellinor perceived [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's depression . [She]73-ellinor watched [him]398-her father anxiously . [He]398-her father perceived it , and said -- shivering in that strange unaccountable manner which is popularly explained by the expression that some one is passing over [the earth]1139-the earth that will one day form [your]1140-your grave--"Ellinor ! this is not a day for out - of - door tea . [I]398-her father never felt so chilly a spot in [my]398-her father life . [I]398-her father can not keep from shaking where [I]398-her father sit . [I]398-her father must leave [this place]720-this place , [[my]398-her father dear]2732-my dear , in spite of all [your]73-ellinor good tea . "[398-her father] " Oh , [papa]2614-papa ! [I]398-her father am so sorry . But look how full that hot sun 's rays come on this turf . [I]398-her father thought [I]398-her father had chosen such a capital spot ! "[398-her father] But [he]398-her father got up and persisted in leaving the table , although [he]398-her father was evidently sorry to spoil the little party . [He]398-her father walked up and down [the gravel walk]1141-the gravel walk , close by [them]1142-them , talking to [them]1142-them as [he]398-her father kept passing by and trying to cheer [them]1142-them up . " Are [you]2614-papa warmer now , [papa]2614-papa ? "[73-ellinor] asked [Ellinor]73-ellinor . " Oh , yes ! All right . It 's only that place that seems so chilly and damp . [I]73-ellinor 'm as warm as a toast now . "[73-ellinor] The next morning [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet left [them]1142-them . The unseasonably fine weather passed away too , and all things went back to [their]1143-their rather grey and dreary aspect ; but [Ellinor]73-ellinor was too happy to feel this much , knowing what absent love existed for [her]73-ellinor alone , and from this knowledge unconsciously trusting in the sun behind the clouds . [I]0-i have said that few or none in [the immediate neighbourhood of [Hamley]1-hamley]1144-the immediate neighbourhood of hamley , beside [[their]1142-them own household]1145-their own household and [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , knew of [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's engagement . At one of the rare dinner - parties to which [she]73-ellinor accompanied [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father -- it was at [[the old lady]1147-the old lady 's house]1148-the old lady 's house who chaperoned [her]73-ellinor to the assemblies -- [she]73-ellinor was taken in to dinner by [a young clergyman staying in [the neighbourhood]961-the neighbourhood]1149-a young clergyman staying in the neighbourhood . [He]1149-a young clergyman staying in the neighbourhood had just had a small living given to [him]1149-a young clergyman staying in the neighbourhood in [[his]1149-a young clergyman staying in the neighbourhood own county]914-his own county , and [he]1149-a young clergyman staying in the neighbourhood felt as if this was a great step in [his]1149-a young clergyman staying in the neighbourhood life . [He]1149-a young clergyman staying in the neighbourhood was good , innocent , and rather boyish in appearance . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was happy and at [her]73-ellinor ease , and chatted away to [this Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone on many little points of interest which [they]1152-they found [they]1152-they had in common : church music , and the difficulty [they]1152-they had in getting [people]446-people to sing in parts ; [Salisbury Cathedral]19-salisbury cathedral , which [they]1152-they had both seen ; styles of church architecture , [Ruskin]113-ruskin 's works , and [parish schools]1154-parish schools , in which [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone was somewhat shocked to find that [Ellinor]73-ellinor took no great interest . When [the gentleman]1155-the gentleman came in from [the dining - room]745-the dining - room , it struck [Ellinor]73-ellinor , for the first time in [her]73-ellinor life , that [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father had taken more wine than was good for [him]398-her father . Indeed , this had rather become a habit with [him]398-her father of late ; but as [he]398-her father always tried to go quietly off to [[his]398-her father own room]1158-his own room when such had been the case , [[his]398-her father daughter]520-his daughter had never been aware of it before , and the perception of it now made [her]520-his daughter cheeks hot with shame . [She]520-his daughter thought that [everyone]593-everyone must be as conscious of [his]398-her father altered manner and way of speaking as [she]520-his daughter was , and after a pause of sick silence , during which [she]520-his daughter could not say a word , [she]520-his daughter set to and talked to [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone about [parish schools]1154-parish schools , anything , with redoubled vigour and apparent interest , in order to keep one or two of [the company]1162-the company , at least , from noticing what was to [her]520-his daughter so painfully obvious . The effect of [her]520-his daughter behaviour was far more than [she]520-his daughter had intended . [She]520-his daughter kept [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone , it is true , from observing [[her]520-his daughter father]398-her father , but [she]520-his daughter also riveted [his]112-mr. livingstone attention on [herself]520-his daughter . [He]112-mr. livingstone had thought [her]520-his daughter very pretty and agreeable during dinner : but after dinner [he]112-mr. livingstone considered [her]520-his daughter bewitching , irresistible . [He]112-mr. livingstone dreamed of [her]520-his daughter all night , and wakened up the next morning to a calculation of how far [his]112-mr. livingstone income would allow [him]112-mr. livingstone to furnish [[his]112-mr. livingstone pretty new parsonage]1164-his pretty new parsonage with that crowning blessing , [a wife]1165-a wife . For a day or two [he]112-mr. livingstone did up little sums , and sighed , and thought of [Ellinor]73-ellinor , [her]73-ellinor face listening with admiring interest to [his]112-mr. livingstone sermons , [her]73-ellinor arm passed into [his]112-mr. livingstone as [they]1166-they went together round [the parish]1167-the parish ; [her]73-ellinor sweet voice instructing classes in [[his]112-mr. livingstone schools]1168-his schools -- turn where [he]112-mr. livingstone would , in [his]112-mr. livingstone imagination [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's presence rose up before [him]112-mr. livingstone . The consequence was that [he]112-mr. livingstone wrote an offer , which [he]112-mr. livingstone found a far more perplexing piece of composition than a sermon ; a real hearty expression of love , going on , over all obstacles , to a straightforward explanation of [his]112-mr. livingstone present prospects and future hopes , and winding up with the information that on the succeeding morning [he]112-mr. livingstone would call to know whether [he]112-mr. livingstone might speak to [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins on the subject of this letter . It was given to [Ellinor]73-ellinor in the evening , as [she]73-ellinor was sitting with [Miss Monro]77-miss monro in [the library]756-the library . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was dining out , [she]73-ellinor hardly knew where , as it was a sudden engagement , of which [he]112-mr. livingstone had sent word from [the office]580-the office -- [a gentleman]560-a gentleman 's dinner - party , [she]73-ellinor supposed , as [he]112-mr. livingstone had dressed in [Hamley]1-hamley without coming [home]230-home . [Ellinor]73-ellinor turned over the letter when it was brought to [her]73-ellinor , as [some people]648-some people do when [they]648-some people can not recognise the handwriting , as if to discover from paper or seal what two moments would assure [them]648-some people of , if [they]648-some people opened the letter and looked at the signature . [Ellinor]73-ellinor could not guess who had written it by any outward sign ; but the moment [she]73-ellinor saw the name " [Herbert Livingstone]114-herbert livingstone , "[73-ellinor] the meaning of the letter flashed upon [her]73-ellinor and [she]73-ellinor coloured all over . [She]73-ellinor put the letter away , unread , for a few minutes , and then made some excuse for leaving [the room]479-the room and going [upstairs]1175-upstairs . When safe in [[her]73-ellinor bed - chamber]1176-her bed - chamber , [she]73-ellinor read [the young man]309-the young man 's eager words with a sense of self - reproach . How must [she]73-ellinor , engaged to [one man]1178-one man , have been behaving to another , if this was the result of a single evening 's interview ? The self - reproach was unjustly bestowed ; but with that [we]1179-we have nothing to do . [She]73-ellinor made [herself]73-ellinor very miserable ; and at last went down with a heavy heart to go on with [Dante]115-dante , and rummage up words in the dictionary . All the time [she]73-ellinor seemed to [Miss Monro]77-miss monro to be plodding on with [her]73-ellinor Italian more diligently and sedately than usual , [she]73-ellinor was planning in [her]73-ellinor own mind to speak to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father as soon as [he]398-her father returned ( and [he]398-her father had said that [he]398-her father should not be late ) , and beg [him]398-her father to undo the mischief [she]73-ellinor had done by seeing [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone the next morning , and frankly explaining the real state of affairs to [him]398-her father . But [she]73-ellinor wanted to read [her]73-ellinor letter again , and think it all over in peace ; and so , at an early hour , [she]73-ellinor wished [Miss Monro]77-miss monro good - night , and went up into [[her]73-ellinor own room]1181-her own room above [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room , and overlooking [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden and shrubbery - path to [the stable - yard]775-the stable - yard , by which [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father was sure to return . [She]73-ellinor went [upstairs]1175-upstairs and studied [her]73-ellinor letter well , and tried to recall all [her]73-ellinor speeches and conduct on that miserable evening -- as [she]73-ellinor thought it then -- not knowing what true misery was . [Her]73-ellinor head ached , and [she]73-ellinor put out the candle , and went and sat on the window - seat , looking out into [the moonlit garden]1187-the moonlit garden , watching for [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father . [She]73-ellinor opened the window ; partly to cool [her]73-ellinor forehead , partly to enable [her]73-ellinor to call down softly when [she]73-ellinor should see [him]398-her father coming along . By - and - by the door from [the stable- yard]1189-the stable- yard into the shrubbery clicked and opened , and in a moment [she]73-ellinor saw [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins moving through the bushes ; but not alone , [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster was with [him]398-her father , and [the two]807-the two were talking together in rather excited tones , immediately lost to hearing , however , as [they]807-the two entered [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's study]764-mr. wilkins 's study by the outer door . " [They]807-the two have been dining together somewhere . Probably at [Mr. Hanbury]116-mr. hanbury 's "[1192-the hamley brewer] ( [the Hamley brewer]1192-the hamley brewer ) , thought [Ellinor]73-ellinor . " But how provoking that [he]66-mr. wilkins should have come [home]230-home with [papa]2614-papa this night of all nights ! "[1192-the hamley brewer] Two or three times before [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster had called on [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins in the evening , as [Ellinor]73-ellinor knew ; but [she]73-ellinor was not quite aware of the reason for such late visits , and had never put together the two facts--(as cause and consequence)--that on such occasions [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father had been absent from [the office]580-the office all day , and that there might be necessary business for [him]398-her father to transact , the urgency of which was the motive for [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's visits . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins always seemed to be annoyed by [his]66-mr. wilkins coming at so late an hour , and spoke of it , resenting the intrusion upon [his]66-mr. wilkins leisure ; and [Ellinor]73-ellinor , without consideration , adopted [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's mode of speaking and thinking on the subject , and was rather more angry than [he]398-her father was whenever [the obnoxious partner]1196-the obnoxious partner came on business in the evening . This night was , of all nights , the most ill - purposed time ( so [Ellinor]73-ellinor thought ) for a _ tete - a- tete _ with [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father ! However , there was no doubt in [her]73-ellinor mind as to what [she]73-ellinor had to do . So late as it was , [the unwelcome visitor]1198-the unwelcome visitor could not stop long ; and then [she]73-ellinor would go down and have [her]73-ellinor little confidence with [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , and beg [him]398-her father to see [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone when [he]398-her father came next morning , and dismiss [him]398-her father as gently as might be . [She]73-ellinor sat on in the window - seat ; dreaming waking dreams of future happiness . [She]73-ellinor kept losing [herself]73-ellinor in such thoughts , and became almost afraid of forgetting why [she]73-ellinor sat there . Presently [she]73-ellinor felt cold , and got up to fetch a shawl , in which [she]73-ellinor muffled [herself]73-ellinor and resumed [her]73-ellinor place . It seemed to [her]73-ellinor growing very late ; the moonlight was coming fuller and fuller into [the garden]711-the garden and the blackness of the shadow was more concentrated and stronger . Surely [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster could not have gone away along [the dark shrubbery - path]1201-the dark shrubbery - path so noiselessly but what [she]73-ellinor must have heard [him]398-her father ? No ! there was the swell of voices coming up through the window from [[[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's study]1203-her father 's study : angry voices they were ; and [her]73-ellinor anger rose sympathetically , as [she]73-ellinor knew that [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father was being irritated . There was a sudden movement , as of chairs pushed hastily aside , and then a mysterious unaccountable noise -- heavy , sudden ; and then a slight movement as of chairs again ; and then a profound stillness . [Ellinor]73-ellinor leaned [her]73-ellinor head against the side of the window to listen more intently , for some mysterious instinct made [her]73-ellinor sick and faint . No sound -- no noise . Only by - and - by [she]73-ellinor heard , what [we]1205-we have all heard at such times of intent listening , the beating of the pulses of [her]73-ellinor heart , and then the whirling rush of blood through [her]73-ellinor head . How long did this last ? [She]73-ellinor never knew . By - and - by [she]73-ellinor heard [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's hurried footstep in [[his]398-her father bedroom]1207-his bedroom , next to [hers]73-ellinor ; but when [she]73-ellinor ran thither to speak to [him]398-her father , and ask [him]398-her father what was amiss -- if anything had been -- if [she]73-ellinor might come to [him]398-her father now about [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone 's letter , [she]73-ellinor found that [he]398-her father had gone down again to [[his]398-her father study]469-his study , and almost at the same moment [she]73-ellinor heard [the little private outer door of [that room]1210-that room]1209-the little private outer door of that room open ; [some one]1211-some one went out , and then there were hurried footsteps along [the shrubbery - path]1212-the shrubbery - path . [She]73-ellinor thought , of course , that it was [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster leaving [the house]761-the house ; and went back for [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone 's letter . Having found it , [she]73-ellinor passed through [[[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's room]1215-her father 's room to the private staircase , thinking that if [she]73-ellinor went by the more regular way , [she]73-ellinor would have run the risk of disturbing [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , and perhaps of being questioned in the morning . Even in passing down [this remote staircase]1216-this remote staircase , [she]73-ellinor trod softly for fear of being overheard . When [she]73-ellinor entered [the room]479-the room , the full light of the candles dazzled [her]73-ellinor for an instant , coming out of the darkness . They were flaring wildly in the draught that came in through the open door , by which the outer air was admitted ; for a moment there seemed [no one]385-no one in [the room]479-the room , and then [she]73-ellinor saw , with strange sick horror , the legs of [some one lying on the carpet behind the table]1220-some one lying on the carpet behind the table . As if compelled , even while [she]73-ellinor shrank from doing it , [she]73-ellinor went round to see who it was that lay there , so still and motionless as never to stir at [her]73-ellinor sudden coming . It was [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster ; [his]84-mr. dunster head propped on chair - cushions , [his]84-mr. dunster eyes open , staring , distended . There was a strong smell of brandy and hartshorn in [the room]479-the room ; a smell so powerful as not to be neutralized by the free current of night air that blew through the two open doors . [Ellinor]73-ellinor could not have told whether it was reason or instinct that made [her]73-ellinor act as [she]73-ellinor did during this awful night . In thinking of it afterwards , with shuddering avoidance of the haunting memory that would come and overshadow [her]73-ellinor during many , many years of [her]73-ellinor life , [she]73-ellinor grew to believe that the powerful smell of the spilt brandy absolutely intoxicated [her]73-ellinor -- [an unconscious Rechabite]1222-an unconscious rechabite in practice . But something gave [her]73-ellinor a presence of mind and a courage not [her]73-ellinor own . And though [she]73-ellinor learnt to think afterwards that [she]73-ellinor had acted unwisely , if not wrongly and wickedly , yet [she]73-ellinor marvelled , in recalling that time , how [she]73-ellinor could have then behaved as [she]73-ellinor did . First of all [she]73-ellinor lifted [herself]73-ellinor up from [her]73-ellinor fascinated gaze at [the dead man]1223-the dead man , and went to the staircase door , by which [she]73-ellinor had entered [the study]768-the study , and shut it softly . Then [she]73-ellinor went back -- looked again ; took the brandy - bottle , and knelt down , and tried to pour some into the mouth ; but this [she]73-ellinor found [she]73-ellinor could not do . Then [she]73-ellinor wetted [her]73-ellinor handkerchief with the spirit , and moistened the lips ; all to no purpose ; for , as [I]0-i have said before , [the man]1225-the man was dead -- killed by rupture of a vessel of the brain ; how occasioned [I]0-i must tell by - and - by . Of course , all [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's little cares and efforts produced no effect ; [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father had tried them before -- vain endeavours all , to bring back the precious breath of life ! [The poor girl]1058-the poor girl could not bear the look of those open eyes , and softly , tenderly , tried to close them , although unconscious that in so doing [she]73-ellinor was rendering the pious offices of some beloved hand to [a dead man]1228-a dead man . [She]73-ellinor was sitting by the body on the floor when [she]73-ellinor heard steps coming with rushing and yet cautious tread , through the shrubbery ; [she]73-ellinor had no fear , although it might be the tread of [robbers]1229-robbers and [murderers]1230-murderers . The awfulness of the hour raised [her]73-ellinor above common fears ; though [she]73-ellinor did not go through the usual process of reasoning , and by it feel assured that the feet which were coming so softly and swiftly along were the same which [she]73-ellinor had heard leaving [the room]479-the room in like manner only a quarter of an hour before . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father entered , and started back , almost upsetting [some one behind [him]398-her father by [his]398-her father recoil , on seeing [[his]398-her father daughter]520-his daughter in [her]1058-the poor girl motionless attitude by [the dead man]1223-the dead man]1233-some one behind him by his recoil , on seeing his daughter in her motionless attitude by the dead man . " [[My]398-her father God]2737-my god , [Ellinor]73-ellinor ! what has brought [you]73-ellinor [here]719-here ? "[398-her father] [he]398-her father said , almost fiercely . But [she]73-ellinor answered as one stupefied , " [I]398-her father do n't know . Is [he]1223-the dead man dead ? "[398-her father] " Hush , hush , [child]466-child ; it can not be helped . "[73-ellinor] [She]73-ellinor raised [her]73-ellinor eyes to the solemn , pitying , awe - stricken face behind [[her]73-ellinor father's]1236-her father's -- the countenance of [Dixon]86-dixon . " Is [he]1223-the dead man dead ? "[73-ellinor] [she]73-ellinor asked of [him]398-her father . [The man]1225-the man stepped forwards , respectfully pushing [[his]1225-the man master]480-his master on one side as [he]1225-the man did so . [He]1225-the man bent down over the corpse , and looked , and listened and then reaching a candle off the table , [he]1225-the man signed [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins to close the door . And [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins obeyed , and looked with an intensity of eagerness almost amounting to faintness on the experiment , and yet [he]1225-the man could not hope . The flame was steady -- steady and pitilessly unstirred , even when it was adjusted close to mouth and nostril ; the head was raised up by one of [Dixon]86-dixon 's stalwart arms , while [he]398-her father held the candle in the other hand . [Ellinor]73-ellinor fancied that there was some trembling on [Dixon]86-dixon 's part , and grasped [his]398-her father wrist tightly in order to give it the requisite motionless firmness . All in vain . The head was placed again on the cushions , [the servant]1239-the servant rose and stood by [[his]1239-the servant master]480-his master , looked sadly on [the dead man]1223-the dead man , whom , living , none of [them]1242-them had liked or cared for , and [Ellinor]73-ellinor sat on , quiet and tearless , as one in a trance . " How was it , [father]474-father ? "[73-ellinor] at length [she]73-ellinor asked . [He]1225-the man would fain have had [her]73-ellinor ignorant of all , but so questioned by [her]73-ellinor lips , so adjured by [her]73-ellinor eyes in the very presence of death , [he]1225-the man could not choose but speak the truth ; [he]1225-the man spoke it in convulsive gasps , each sentence an effort : " [He]1223-the dead man taunted [me]1225-the man -- [he]1223-the dead man was insolent , beyond [my]1225-the man patience -- [I]1225-the man could not bear it . [I]1225-the man struck [him]1223-the dead man -- [I]1225-the man ca n't tell how it was . [He]1223-the dead man must have hit [his]1223-the dead man head in falling . Oh , [[my]1225-the man God]2737-my god ! one little hour a go [I]1225-the man was innocent of [this man]2742-this man 's blood ! "[1225-the man] [He]1225-the man covered [his]1225-the man face with [his]1225-the man hands . [Ellinor]73-ellinor took the candle again ; kneeling behind [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's head , [she]73-ellinor tried the futile experiment once more . " Could not [a doctor]2743-a doctor do some good ? "[73-ellinor] [she]73-ellinor asked of [Dixon]86-dixon , in a hopeless voice . " No ! "[86-dixon] said [he]86-dixon , shaking [his]86-dixon head , and looking with a sidelong glance at [[his]86-dixon master]480-his master , [who seemed to shrivel up and to shrink away at the bare suggestion]1244-who seemed to shrivel up and to shrink away at the bare suggestion . " [Doctors]2744-doctors can do nought , [I]86-dixon 'm afeard . All that [a doctor]2743-a doctor could do , [I]86-dixon take it , would be to open a vein , and that [I]86-dixon could do along with the best of [them]2744-doctors , if [I]86-dixon had but [my]86-dixon fleam here . "[86-dixon] [He]86-dixon fumbled in [his]86-dixon pockets as [he]86-dixon spoke , and , as chance would it , the " fleam "[86-dixon] ( or cattle lancet ) was somewhere about [his]86-dixon dress . [He]86-dixon drew it out , smoothed and tried it on [his]86-dixon finger . [Ellinor]73-ellinor tried to bare the arm , but turned sick as [she]73-ellinor did so . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father started eagerly forwards , and did what was necessary with hurried trembling hands . If [they]1246-they had cared less about the result , [they]1246-they might have been more afraid of the consequences of the operation in the hands of [one so ignorant as [Dixon]86-dixon]1247-one so ignorant as dixon . But , vein or artery , it signified little ; no living blood gushed out ; only a little watery moisture followed the cut of the fleam . [They]1246-they laid [him]398-her father back on [his]398-her father strange sad death - couch . [Dixon]86-dixon spoke next . " [Master Ned]66-mr. wilkins ! "[86-dixon] said [he]86-dixon -- for [he]86-dixon had known [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins in [his]86-dixon days of bright careless boyhood , and almost was carried back to [them]1246-they by the sense of charge and protection which [the servant]1239-the servant 's presence of mind and sharpened senses gave [him]86-dixon over [[his]86-dixon master]480-his master on this dreary night--"Master [Ned]66-mr. wilkins ! [we]2746-we must do summut . "[385-no one] [No one]385-no one spoke . What was to be done ? " Did [any folk]2747-any folk see [him]398-her father come [here]719-here ? "[86-dixon] [Dixon]86-dixon asked , after a time . [Ellinor]73-ellinor looked up to hear [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's answer , a wild hope coming into [her]73-ellinor mind that all might be concealed somehow ; [she]73-ellinor did not know how , nor did [she]73-ellinor think of any consequences except saving [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father from the vague dread , trouble , and punishment that [she]73-ellinor was aware would await [him]398-her father if all were known . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins did not seem to hear ; in fact , [he]66-mr. wilkins did not hear anything but the unspoken echo of [his]66-mr. wilkins own last words , that went booming through [his]66-mr. wilkins heart : " An hour ago [I]86-dixon was innocent of [this man]2742-this man 's blood ! Only an hour ago ! "[86-dixon] [Dixon]86-dixon got up and poured out half a tumblerful of raw spirit from the brandy - bottle that stood on the table . " Drink this , [Master Ned]66-mr. wilkins ! "[86-dixon] putting it to [[his]86-dixon master]480-his master 's lips . " [Nay"--to[86-dixon] Ellinor--"it]2750-nay"--to ellinor--"it will do [him]2742-this man no harm ; only bring back [his]2742-this man senses , which , [poor gentleman]2751-poor gentleman , are scared away . [We]2752-we shall need all [our]2752-we wits . Now , [sir]2656-sir , please answer [my]86-dixon question . Did [anyone]503-anyone see [Measter]2742-this man [Dunster]84-mr. dunster come [here]719-here ? "[86-dixon] " [I]66-mr. wilkins do n't know , "[66-mr. wilkins] said [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , recovering [his]66-mr. wilkins speech . " It all seems in a mist . [He]2742-this man offered to walk [home]230-home with [me]66-mr. wilkins ; [I]66-mr. wilkins did not want [him]2742-this man . [I]66-mr. wilkins was almost rude to [him]2742-this man to keep [him]2742-this man off . [I]66-mr. wilkins did not want to talk of business ; [I]66-mr. wilkins had taken too much wine to be very clear and some things at [the office]580-the office were not quite in order , and [he]2742-this man had found it out . If [anyone]503-anyone heard [our]2759-we conversation , [they]503-anyone must know [I]66-mr. wilkins did not want [him]2742-this man to come with [me]66-mr. wilkins . Oh ! why would [he]2742-this man come ? [He]2742-this man was as obstinate -- [he]2742-this man would come -- and here it has been [his]2742-this man death ! "[66-mr. wilkins] " Well , [sir]2656-sir , what 's done ca n't be undone , and [I]66-mr. wilkins 'm sure [we]2759-we 'd any of [us]2759-we bring [him]2742-this man back to life if [we]2759-we could , even by cutting off [our]2759-we hands , though [he]2742-this man was [a mighty plaguey chap]2761-a mighty plaguey chap while [he]2742-this man 'd breath in [him]2742-this man . But what [I]66-mr. wilkins 'm thinking is this : it 'll maybe go awkward with [you]2656-sir , [sir]2656-sir , if [he]2742-this man 's found [here]719-here . One ca n't say . But do n't [you]2656-sir think , [miss]2729-miss , as [he]2742-this man 's neither [kith]2765-kith nor [kin]2766-kin to miss [him]2742-this man , [we]2759-we might just bury [him]2742-this man away before morning , somewhere ? There 's better nor four hours of dark . [I]66-mr. wilkins wish [we]2759-we could put [him]2742-this man [i]66-mr. wilkins ' [the churchyard]2767-the churchyard , but that ca n't be ; but , to [my]66-mr. wilkins mind , the sooner [we]2759-we set about digging a place for [him]2742-this man to lie in , [poor fellow]2768-poor fellow , the better it 'll be for [us]2759-we all in the end . [I]66-mr. wilkins can pare a piece of turf up where it 'll never be missed , and if [master'll]2769-master'll take one spade , and [I]66-mr. wilkins another , why [we]2759-we 'll lay [him]2742-this man softly down , and cover [him]2742-this man up , and [no one'll]2770-no one'll be the wiser . "[66-mr. wilkins] There was no reply from either for a minute or so . Then [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins said : " If [[my]66-mr. wilkins father]2646-my father could have known of [my]66-mr. wilkins living to this ! Why , [they]2646-my father will try [me]66-mr. wilkins as [a criminal]2772-a criminal ; and [you]86-dixon , [Ellinor]73-ellinor ? [Dixon]86-dixon , [you]86-dixon are right . [We]2759-we must conceal it , or [I]66-mr. wilkins must cut [my]66-mr. wilkins throat , for [I]66-mr. wilkins never could live through it . One minute of passion , and [my]66-mr. wilkins life blasted ! "[66-mr. wilkins] " Come along , [sir]2656-sir , "[86-dixon] said [Dixon]86-dixon ; " there 's no time to lose . "[86-dixon] And [they]1254-them went out in search of tools ; [Ellinor]73-ellinor following [them]1254-them , shivering all over , but begging that [she]73-ellinor might be with [them]1254-them , and not have to remain in [the study]768-the study with-- [She]73-ellinor would not be bidden into [[her]73-ellinor own room]1181-her own room ; [she]73-ellinor dreaded inaction and solitude . [She]73-ellinor made [herself]73-ellinor busy with carrying heavy baskets of turf , and straining [her]73-ellinor strength to the utmost ; fetching all that was wanted , with soft swift steps . Once , as [she]73-ellinor passed near the open study door , [she]73-ellinor thought that [she]73-ellinor heard a rustling , and a flash of hope came across [her]73-ellinor . Could [he]1257-he be reviving ? [She]73-ellinor entered , but a moment was enough to undeceive [her]73-ellinor ; it had only been a night rustle among the trees . Of hope , life , there was none . [They]1254-them dug the hole deep and well ; working with fierce energy to quench thought and remorse . Once or twice [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father asked for brandy , which [Ellinor]73-ellinor , reassured by the apparently good effect of the first dose , brought to [him]398-her father without a word ; and once at [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's suggestion [she]73-ellinor brought food , such as [she]73-ellinor could find in [the dining - room]745-the dining - room without disturbing [the household]1261-the household , for [Dixon]86-dixon . When all was ready for the reception of the body in its unblessed grave , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins bade [Ellinor]73-ellinor go up to [[her]73-ellinor own room]1181-her own room -- [she]73-ellinor had done all [she]73-ellinor could to help [them]1254-them ; the rest must be done by [them]1254-them alone . [She]73-ellinor felt that it must ; and indeed both [her]73-ellinor nerves and [her]73-ellinor bodily strength were giving way . [She]73-ellinor would have kissed [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , as [he]398-her father sat wearily at the head of [the grave]1264-the grave -- [Dixon]86-dixon had gone in to make some arrangement for carrying the corpse -- but [he]398-her father pushed [her]73-ellinor away quietly , but resolutely-- " No , [Nelly]111-nelly , [you]111-nelly must never kiss [me]398-her father again ; [I]398-her father am [a murderer]2774-a murderer . "[398-her father] " But [I]73-ellinor will , [[my]73-ellinor own darling papa]2775-my own darling papa , "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor , throwing [her]73-ellinor arms passionately round [his]398-her father neck , and covering [his]398-her father face with kisses . " [I]73-ellinor love [you]111-nelly , and [I]73-ellinor do n't care what [you]111-nelly are , if [you]111-nelly were twenty times [a murderer]2774-a murderer , which [you]111-nelly are not ; [I]73-ellinor am sure it was only an accident . "[73-ellinor] " Go in , [[my]73-ellinor child]2777-my child , go in , and try to get some rest . But go in , for [we]2778-we must finish as fast as [we]2778-we can . The moon is down ; it will soon be daylight . What a blessing there are [no rooms on one side of [the house]761-the house]2779-no rooms on one side of the house . Go , [Nelly]111-nelly . "[73-ellinor] And [she]73-ellinor went ; straining [herself]73-ellinor up to move noiselessly , with eyes averted , through [the room which [she]73-ellinor shuddered at as [the place of hasty and unhallowed death]1266-the place of hasty and unhallowed death]1265-the room which she shuddered at as the place of hasty and unhallowed death . Once in [[her]73-ellinor own room]1181-her own room [she]73-ellinor bolted the door on the inside , and then stole to the window , as if some fascination impelled [her]73-ellinor to watch all the proceedings to the end . But [her]73-ellinor aching eyes could hardly penetrate through the thick darkness , which , at the time of the year of which [I]0-i am speaking , so closely precedes the dawn . [She]73-ellinor could discern the tops of the trees against the sky , and could single out the well - known one , at a little distance from the stem of which [the grave]1264-the grave was made , in the very piece of turf over which so lately [she]73-ellinor and [Ralph]81-mr. corbet had had [their]1269-their merry little tea - making ; and where [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , as [she]73-ellinor now remembered , had shuddered and shivered , as if the ground on which [his]398-her father seat had then been placed was fateful and ominous to [him]398-her father . [Those below]1271-those below moved softly and quietly in all [they]1271-those below did ; but every sound had a significant and terrible interpretation to [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's ears . Before [they]1271-those below had ended , the little birds had begun to pipe out their gay _ reveillee _ to the dawn . Then doors closed , and all was profoundly still . [Ellinor]73-ellinor threw [herself]73-ellinor , in [her]73-ellinor clothes , on the bed ; and was thankful for the intense weary physical pain which took off something of the anguish of thought -- anguish that [she]73-ellinor fancied from time to time was leading to insanity . By - and - by the morning cold made [her]73-ellinor instinctively creep between the blankets ; and , once there , [she]73-ellinor fell into a dead heavy sleep . CHAPTER VII . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was awakened by a rapping at [her]73-ellinor door : it was [[her]73-ellinor maid]1272-her maid . [She]73-ellinor was fully aroused in a moment , for [she]73-ellinor had fallen asleep with one clearly defined plan in [her]73-ellinor mind , only one , for all thoughts and cares having no relation to the terrible event were as though they had never been . All [her]73-ellinor purpose was to shield [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father from suspicion . And to do this [she]73-ellinor must control [herself]73-ellinor -- heart , mind , and body must be ruled to this one end . So [she]73-ellinor said to [Mason]117-mason : " Let [me]73-ellinor lie half an hour longer ; and beg [Miss Monro]77-miss monro not to wait breakfast for [me]73-ellinor ; but in half an hour bring [me]73-ellinor up a cup of strong tea , for [I]73-ellinor have a bad headache . "[73-ellinor] [Mason]117-mason went away . [Ellinor]73-ellinor sprang up ; rapidly undressed [herself]73-ellinor , and got into bed again , so that when [[her]73-ellinor maid]1272-her maid returned with [her]1272-her maid breakfast , there was no appearance of the night having been passed in any unusual manner . " How ill [you]73-ellinor do look , [miss]2729-miss ! "[117-mason] said [Mason]117-mason . " [I]117-mason am sure [you]73-ellinor had better not get up yet . "[117-mason] [Ellinor]73-ellinor longed to ask if [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father had yet shown [himself]398-her father ; but this question -- so natural at any other time -- seemed to [her]73-ellinor so suspicious under the circumstances , that [she]73-ellinor could not bring [her]73-ellinor lips to frame it . At any rate , [she]73-ellinor must get up and struggle to make the day like all other days . So [she]73-ellinor rose , confessing that [she]73-ellinor did not feel very well , but trying to make light of it , and when [she]73-ellinor could think of anything but the one awe , to say a trivial sentence or two . But [she]73-ellinor could not recollect how [she]73-ellinor behaved in general , for [her]73-ellinor life hitherto had been simple , and led without any consciousness of effect . Before [she]73-ellinor was dressed , a message came up to say that [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone was in [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room . [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone ! [He]112-mr. livingstone belonged to the old life of yesterday ! The billows of the night had swept over [his]112-mr. livingstone mark on the sands of [her]73-ellinor memory ; and it was only by a strong effort that [she]73-ellinor could remember who [he]112-mr. livingstone was -- what [he]112-mr. livingstone wanted . [She]73-ellinor sent [Mason]117-mason down to inquire from [the servant who admitted [him]117-mason whom it was that [he]117-mason had asked for]1277-the servant who admitted him whom it was that he had asked for . " [He]112-mr. livingstone asked for [master]2621-master first . But [master]2621-master has not rung for [his]112-mr. livingstone water yet , so [James]118-james told [him]112-mr. livingstone [he]112-mr. livingstone was not up . Then [he]112-mr. livingstone took thought for a while , and asked could [he]112-mr. livingstone speak to [you]73-ellinor , [he]112-mr. livingstone would wait if [you]73-ellinor were not at liberty but that [he]112-mr. livingstone wished particular to see either [master]2621-master , or [you]73-ellinor . So [James]118-james asked [him]112-mr. livingstone to sit down in [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room , and [he]112-mr. livingstone would let [you]73-ellinor know . "[117-mason] " [I]73-ellinor must go , "[73-ellinor] thought [Ellinor]73-ellinor . " [I]73-ellinor will send [him]112-mr. livingstone away directly ; to come , thinking of marriage to [a house like this]2786-a house like this -- to - day , too ! "[73-ellinor] And [she]73-ellinor went down hastily , and in a hard unsparing mood towards [a man , whose affection for [her]73-ellinor [she]73-ellinor thought]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought was like [a gourd , grown up in a night , and of no account , but as a piece of foolish , boyish excitement]1279-a gourd , grown up in a night , and of no account , but as a piece of foolish , boyish excitement . [She]73-ellinor never thought of [her]73-ellinor own appearance -- [she]73-ellinor had dressed without looking in the glass . [Her]73-ellinor only object was to dismiss [[her]73-ellinor would - be suitor]1280-her would - be suitor as speedily as possible . All feelings of shyness , awkwardness , or maiden modesty , were quenched and overcome . In [she]73-ellinor went . [He]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought was standing by the mantelpiece as [she]73-ellinor entered . [He]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought made a step or two forward to meet [her]73-ellinor ; and then stopped , petrified , as it were , at the sight of [her]73-ellinor hard white face . " [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins , [I]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought am afraid [you]106-miss wilkins are ill ! [I]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought have come too early . But [I]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought have to leave [Hamley]1-hamley in half an hour , and [I]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought thought -- Oh , [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins ! what have [I]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought done ? "[1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought] For [she]73-ellinor sank into the chair nearest to [her]73-ellinor , as if overcome by [his]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought words ; but , indeed , it was by the oppression of [her]73-ellinor own thoughts : [she]73-ellinor was hardly conscious of [his]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought presence . [He]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought came a step or two nearer , as if [he]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought longed to take [her]73-ellinor in [his]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought arms and comfort and shelter [her]73-ellinor ; but [she]73-ellinor stiffened [herself]73-ellinor and arose , and by an effort walked towards the fireplace , and there stood , as if awaiting what [he]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought would say next . But [he]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought was overwhelmed by [her]73-ellinor aspect of illness . [He]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought almost forgot [his]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought own wishes , [his]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought own suit , in [his]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought desire to relieve [her]73-ellinor from the pain , physical as [he]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought believed it , under which [she]73-ellinor was suffering . It was [she]73-ellinor who had to begin the subject . " [I]73-ellinor received [your]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought letter yesterday , [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone . [I]73-ellinor was anxious to see [you]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought to - day , in order that [I]73-ellinor might prevent [you]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought from speaking to [[my]73-ellinor father]2646-my father . [I]73-ellinor do not say anything of the kind of affection [you]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought can feel for [me]73-ellinor -- [me]73-ellinor , whom [you]1278-a man , whose affection for her she thought have only seen once . All [I]73-ellinor shall say is , that the sooner [we]2788-we both forget what [I]73-ellinor must call folly , the better . "[73-ellinor] [She]73-ellinor took the airs of [a woman considerably older and more experienced than [himself]1282-he]1281-a woman considerably older and more experienced than himself . [He]1282-he thought [her]73-ellinor haughty ; [she]73-ellinor was only miserable . " [You]73-ellinor are mistaken , "[1282-he] said [he]1282-he , more quietly and with more dignity than was likely from [his]1282-he previous conduct . " [I]1283-i will not allow [you]73-ellinor to characterise as folly what might be presumptuous on [my]1283-i part -- [I]1283-i had no business to express [myself]1283-i so soon -- but which in its foundation was true and sincere . That [I]1283-i can answer for most solemnly . It is possible , though it may not be a usual thing , for [a man]286-a man to feel so strongly attracted by the charms and qualities of [a woman]585-a woman , even at first sight , as to feel sure that [she]585-a woman , and [she]585-a woman alone , can make [his]286-a man happiness . [My]1283-i folly consisted -- there [you]73-ellinor are right -- in even dreaming that [you]73-ellinor could return [my]1283-i feelings in the slightest degree , when [you]73-ellinor had only seen [me]1283-i once : and [I]1283-i am most truly ashamed of [myself]1283-i . [I]1283-i can not tell [you]73-ellinor how sorry [I]1283-i am , when [I]1283-i see how [you]73-ellinor have compelled [yourself]73-ellinor to come and speak to [me]1283-i when [you]73-ellinor are so ill . "[1283-i] [She]1283-i staggered into a chair , for with all [her]1283-i wish for [his]1284-i speedy dismissal , [she]1283-i was obliged to be seated . [His]1284-i hand was upon the bell . " No , do n't ! "[1283-i] [she]1283-i said . " Wait a minute . "[1284-i] [His]1284-i eyes , bent upon [her]1283-i with a look of deep anxiety , touched [her]1283-i at that moment , and [she]1283-i was on the point of shedding tears ; but [she]1283-i checked [herself]1283-i , and rose again . " [I]1284-i will go , "[1284-i] said [he]1284-i . " It is the kindest thing [I]1284-i can do . Only , may [I]1284-i write ? May [I]1284-i venture to write and urge what [I]1284-i have to say more coherently ? "[1284-i] " No ! "[1283-i] said [she]1283-i . " Do n't write . "[1283-i] [The poor young man]1285-the poor young man 's face fell , and [he]1284-i became almost as white as [she]1283-i was for the instant . "[1284-i] And kissing [her]1283-i passive hand , [he]1284-i was gone and [she]1283-i was left sitting alone . But solitude was not what [she]1283-i could bear . "[77-miss monro] And then , without listening to [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's reply , [she]1283-i went on : " [Mrs. Jackson]120-mrs. jackson has been [here]719-here "[1283-i] ( it was at [[Mrs. Jackson]120-mrs. jackson 's house]1287-mrs. jackson 's house that [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster lodged ) , " wanting to know if [we]2799-we could tell [her]120-mrs. jackson where [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster was , for [he]84-mr. dunster never came [home]230-home last night at all . "[1283-i] " And did [papa]2614-papa ? "[73-ellinor] inquired [Ellinor]73-ellinor , [her]73-ellinor dry throat huskily forming the inquiry that seemed to be expected from [her]73-ellinor . "[73-ellinor] [Ellinor]73-ellinor had taken up [the _ Hamley Examiner _]1288-the _ hamley examiner _ , a daily paper , which lay on the table , to hide [her]73-ellinor face in the first instance ; but it served a second purpose , as [she]73-ellinor glanced languidly over the columns of the advertisements . " Oh ! here are [Colonel Macdonald]122-colonel macdonald 's orchideous plants to be sold . All the stock of hothouse and stove plants at [Hartwell Priory]21-hartwell priory .
