"[73-ellinor] " Oh , yes ; [he]118-james had better stay at [the little inn there]2826-the little inn there , to be on the spot . Three days , "[73-ellinor] and as [she]73-ellinor spoke , [she]73-ellinor ran out to [the gardener , who was sweeping up the newly - mown grass in the front of [the house]761-the house]1289-the gardener , who was sweeping up the newly - mown grass in the front of the house . [She]73-ellinor gave [him]1289-the gardener , who was sweeping up the newly - mown grass in the front of the house hasty and unlimited directions , only seeming intent -- if [any one]616-any one had been suspiciously watching [her]73-ellinor words and actions -- to hurry [him]1289-the gardener , who was sweeping up the newly - mown grass in the front of the house off to [the distant village]1292-the distant village , where the auction was to take place . When [he]1289-the gardener , who was sweeping up the newly - mown grass in the front of the house was once gone [she]73-ellinor breathed more freely . Now , [no one]385-no one but the three cognisant of the terrible reason of the disturbance of the turf under the trees in [a certain spot in the belt round [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden]1294-a certain spot in the belt round the flower - garden , would be likely to go into [the place]1296-the place . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro might wander round with a book in [her]77-miss monro hand ; but [she]77-miss monro never noticed anything , and was short - sighted into the bargain . Three days of this moist , warm , growing weather , and the green grass would spring , just as if life -- was what it had been twenty - four hours before . When all this was done and said , it seemed as if [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's strength and spirit sank down at once . [Her]73-ellinor voice became feeble , [her]73-ellinor aspect wan ; and although [she]73-ellinor told [Miss Monro]77-miss monro that nothing was the matter , yet it was impossible for [any one who loved [her]73-ellinor]1297-any one who loved her not to perceive that [she]73-ellinor was far from well . [The kind governess]1298-the kind governess placed [her]1298-the kind governess pupil on the sofa , covered [her]1298-the kind governess feet up warmly , darkened [the room]479-the room , and then stole out on tiptoe , fancying that [Ellinor]73-ellinor would sleep . [Her]73-ellinor eyes were , indeed , shut ; but try as much as [she]73-ellinor would to be quiet , [she]73-ellinor was up in less than five minutes after [Miss Monro]77-miss monro had left [the room]479-the room , and walking up and down in all the restless agony of body that arises from an overstrained mind . But soon [Miss Monro]77-miss monro reappeared , bringing with [her]73-ellinor a dose of soothing medicine of [her]73-ellinor own concocting , for [she]73-ellinor was great in domestic quackery . What the medicine was [Ellinor]73-ellinor did not care to know ; [she]73-ellinor drank it without any sign of [her]73-ellinor usual merry resistance to physic of [Miss Monro]77-miss monro 's ordering ; and as [the latter]271-the latter took up a book , and showed a set purpose of remaining with [[her]73-ellinor patient]1302-her patient , [Ellinor]73-ellinor was compelled to lie still , and presently fell asleep . [She]73-ellinor awakened late in the afternoon with a start . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father was standing over [her]73-ellinor , listening to [Miss Monro]77-miss monro 's account of [her]73-ellinor indisposition . [She]73-ellinor only caught one glimpse of [his]398-her father strangely altered countenance , and hid [her]73-ellinor head in the cushions -- hid it from memory , not from [him]398-her father . For in an instant [she]73-ellinor must have conjectured the interpretation [he]398-her father was likely to put upon [her]73-ellinor shrinking action , and [she]73-ellinor had turned towards [him]398-her father , and had thrown [her]73-ellinor arms round [his]398-her father neck , and was kissing [his]398-her father cold , passive face . Then [she]73-ellinor fell back . But all this time [their]1304-their sad eyes never met -- [they]1304-their dreaded the look of recollection that must be in [each other]523-each other 's gaze . " There , [[my]77-miss monro dear]2732-my dear ! "[77-miss monro] said [Miss Monro]77-miss monro . " Now [you]2732-my dear must lie still till [I]77-miss monro fetch [you]2732-my dear a little broth . [You]2732-my dear are better now , are not [you]2732-my dear ? "[77-miss monro] " [You]73-ellinor need not go for the broth , [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , "[66-mr. wilkins] said [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , ringing the bell . " [Fletcher]123-fletcher can surely bring it . "[66-mr. wilkins] [He]398-her father dreaded the being left alone with [[his]398-her father daughter]520-his daughter -- nor did [she]73-ellinor fear it less . [She]73-ellinor heard the strange alteration in [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's voice , hard and hoarse , as if it was an effort to speak . The physical signs of [his]398-her father suffering cut [her]73-ellinor to the heart ; and yet [she]73-ellinor wondered how it was that [they]1308-they could both be alive , or , if alive , [they]1308-they were not rending [their]1308-they garments and crying aloud . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins seemed to have lost the power of careless action and speech , it is true . [He]398-her father wished to leave [the room]479-the room now [his]398-her father anxiety about [[his]398-her father daughter]520-his daughter was relieved , but hardly knew how to set about it . [He]398-her father was obliged to think about the veriest trifle , in order that by an effort of reason [he]398-her father might understand how [he]398-her father should have spoken or acted if [he]398-her father had been free from blood - guiltiness . [Ellinor]73-ellinor understood all by intuition . But henceforward the unspoken comprehension of [each other]523-each other 's hidden motions made [their]1308-they mutual presence a burdensome anxiety to each . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro was a relief ; [they]1308-they were glad of [her]77-miss monro as [a third person]1312-a third person , unconscious of the secret which constrained [them]1308-they . This afternoon [her]77-miss monro unconsciousness gave present pain , although on after reflection [each]1313-each found in [her]77-miss monro speeches a cause of rejoicing . " And [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , has [he]66-mr. wilkins come [home]230-home yet ? "[66-mr. wilkins] A moment 's pause , in which [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins pumped the words out of [his]66-mr. wilkins husky throat : " [I]66-mr. wilkins have not heard . [I]66-mr. wilkins have been riding . [I]66-mr. wilkins went on business to [Mr. Estcourt]124-mr. estcourt 's . Perhaps [you]73-ellinor will be so kind as to send and inquire at [Mrs. Jackson]120-mrs. jackson 's . "[66-mr. wilkins] [Ellinor]73-ellinor sickened at the words . [She]73-ellinor had been all [her]73-ellinor life [a truthful plain - spoken girl]1314-a truthful plain - spoken girl . [She]73-ellinor held [herself]73-ellinor high above deceit . Yet , here came the necessity for deceit -- a snare spread around [her]73-ellinor . [She]73-ellinor had not revolted so much from the deed which brought unpremeditated death , as [she]73-ellinor did from these words of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's . The night before , in [her]73-ellinor mad fever of affright , [she]73-ellinor had fancied that to conceal the body was all that would be required ; [she]73-ellinor had not looked forward to the long , weary course of small lies , to be done and said , involved in that one mistaken action . Yet , while [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's words made [her]73-ellinor soul revolt , [his]398-her father appearance melted [her]73-ellinor heart , as [she]73-ellinor caught it , half turned away from [her]73-ellinor , neither looking straight at [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , nor at anything materially visible . [His]398-her father hollow sunken eye seemed to [Ellinor]73-ellinor to have a vision of [the dead man]1223-the dead man before it . [His]398-her father cheek was livid and worn , and its healthy colouring gained by years of hearty out - door exercise , was all gone into the wanness of age . [His]398-her father hair , even to [Ellinor]73-ellinor , seemed greyer for the past night of wretchedness . [He]398-her father stooped , and looked dreamily earthward , where formerly [he]398-her father had stood erect . It needed all the pity called forth by such observation to quench [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's passionate contempt for the course on which [she]73-ellinor and [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father were embarked , when [she]73-ellinor heard [him]398-her father repeat [his]398-her father words to [the servant who came with [her]73-ellinor broth]1319-the servant who came with her broth . " [Fletcher]123-fletcher ! go to [Mrs. Jackson]120-mrs. jackson 's and inquire if [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster is come [home]230-home yet . [I]398-her father want to speak to [him]84-mr. dunster . "[398-her father] " To [him]84-mr. dunster ! "[73-ellinor] lying dead where [he]398-her father had been laid ; killed by [the man who now asked for [his]398-her father presence]1320-the man who now asked for his presence . [Ellinor]73-ellinor shut [her]73-ellinor eyes , and lay back in despair . [She]73-ellinor wished [she]73-ellinor might die , and be out of this horrible tangle of events . Two minutes after , [she]73-ellinor was conscious of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro stealing softly out of [the room]479-the room . [They]1323-they thought that [she]73-ellinor slept . [She]73-ellinor sprang off the sofa and knelt down . " Oh , [God]119-god , "[73-ellinor] [she]73-ellinor prayed , " [Thou]119-god knowest ! Help [me]73-ellinor ! There is none other help but [Thee]119-god ! "[73-ellinor] [I]0-i suppose [she]73-ellinor fainted . For , an hour or more afterwards [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , coming in , found [her]73-ellinor lying insensible by the side of the sofa . [She]73-ellinor was carried to bed . [She]73-ellinor was not delirious , [she]73-ellinor was only in a stupor , which [they]1323-they feared might end in delirium . To obviate this , [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father sent far and wide for [skilful physicians]1325-skilful physicians , who tended [her]73-ellinor , almost at the rate of a guinea the minute . [People]446-people said how hard it was upon [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , that scarcely had [that wretch Dunster]84-mr. dunster gone off , with [no one]385-no one knows how much out of the trusts of [the firm]1328-the firm , before [[his]66-mr. wilkins only child]899-his only child fell ill . And , to tell the truth , [he]66-mr. wilkins [himself]66-mr. wilkins looked burnt and scared with affliction . [He]66-mr. wilkins had a startled look , [they]1323-they said , as if [he]66-mr. wilkins never could tell , after such experience , from which side the awful proofs of the uncertainty of [earth]1330-earth would appear , the terrible phantoms of unforeseen dread . Both rich and poor , [town]2661-town and [country]1332-country , sympathised with [him]66-mr. wilkins . [The rich]1084-the rich cared not to press [their]1084-the rich claims , or [their]1084-the rich business , at such a time ; and only wondered , in [their]1084-the rich superficial talk after dinner , how [such a good fellow]1334-such a good fellow as [Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins could ever have been deceived by [a man like [Dunster]84-mr. dunster]1335-a man like dunster . Even [Sir Frank Holster]68-sir frank holster and [[his]68-sir frank holster lady]1336-his lady forgot [their]1084-the rich old quarrel , and came to inquire after [Ellinor]73-ellinor , and sent [her]73-ellinor hothouse fruit by the bushel . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet behaved as [an anxious lover]1337-an anxious lover should do . [He]81-mr. corbet wrote daily to [Miss Monro]77-miss monro to beg for the most minute bulletins ; [he]81-mr. corbet procured everything in [town]2661-town that [any doctor even fancied might be of service]1339-any doctor even fancied might be of service , [he]81-mr. corbet came down as soon as there was the slightest hint of permission that [Ellinor]73-ellinor might see [him]81-mr. corbet . [He]81-mr. corbet overpowered [her]77-miss monro with tender words and caresses , till at last [she]77-miss monro shrank away from [them]1340-them , as from something too bewildering , and past all right comprehension . But one night before this , when all windows and doors stood open to admit the least breath that stirred the sultry July air , [a servant on velvet tiptoe]1341-a servant on velvet tiptoe had stolen up to [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's open door , and had beckoned out of the chamber of [the sleeper]1342-the sleeper [the ever watchful nurse]1343-the ever watchful nurse , [Miss Monro]77-miss monro . " [A gentleman]560-a gentleman wants [you]112-mr. livingstone , "[1344-the housemaid] were all the words [the housemaid]1344-the housemaid dared to say so close to [the bedroom]1345-the bedroom . And softly , softly [Miss Monro]77-miss monro stepped down the stairs , into [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room ; and there [she]77-miss monro saw [Mr. Livingstone]112-mr. livingstone . But [she]77-miss monro did not know [him]112-mr. livingstone ; [she]77-miss monro had never seen [him]112-mr. livingstone before . " [I]112-mr. livingstone have travelled all day . [I]112-mr. livingstone heard [she]73-ellinor was ill -- was dying . May [I]112-mr. livingstone just have one more look at [her]73-ellinor ? [I]112-mr. livingstone will not speak ; [I]112-mr. livingstone will hardly breathe . Only let [me]112-mr. livingstone see [her]73-ellinor once again ! "[112-mr. livingstone] " [I]112-mr. livingstone beg [your]112-mr. livingstone pardon , [sir]2656-sir , but [I]112-mr. livingstone do n't know who [you]112-mr. livingstone are ; and if [you]112-mr. livingstone mean [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins , by ' [her]73-ellinor , ' [she]73-ellinor is very ill , but [we]2832-we hope not dying . [She]73-ellinor was very ill , indeed , yesterday ; very dangerously ill , [I]112-mr. livingstone may say , but [she]73-ellinor is having a good sleep , in consequence of a soporific medicine , and [we]2832-we are really beginning to hope-- "[112-mr. livingstone] But just here [Miss Monro]77-miss monro 's hand was taken , and , to [her]77-miss monro infinite surprise , was kissed before [she]77-miss monro could remember how improper such behaviour was . " God bless [you]77-miss monro , [madam]2833-madam , for saying so . But if [she]73-ellinor sleeps , will [you]77-miss monro let [me]1347-i see [her]73-ellinor ? it can do no harm , for [I]1347-i will tread as if on egg shells ; and [I]1347-i have come so far -- if [I]1347-i might just look on [her]73-ellinor sweet face . Pray , [madam]2833-madam , let [me]1347-i just have one sight of [her]73-ellinor . [I]1347-i will not ask for more . "[1347-i] But [he]1347-i did ask for more after [he]1347-i had had [his]1347-i wish . [He]1347-i stole [upstairs]1175-upstairs after [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , who looked round reproachfully at [him]1347-i if even a nightingale sang , or an owl hooted in the trees outside the open windows , yet who paused to say [herself]77-miss monro , outside [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's chamber door , " [[[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's room]1215-her father 's room ; [he]398-her father has not been in bed for six nights , till to - night ; pray do not make a noise to waken [him]398-her father . "[77-miss monro] And on into the deep stillness of [the hushed room]1349-the hushed room , where one clear ray of hidden lamp - light shot athwart the door , where [a watcher , breathing softly]1350-a watcher , breathing softly , sat beside the bed -- where [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's dark head lay motionless on the white pillow , [her]73-ellinor face almost as white , [her]73-ellinor form almost as still . [You]1351-you might have heard a pin fall . After a while [he]1347-i moved to withdraw . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , jealous of every sound , followed [him]1347-i , with steps all the more heavy because [they]1352-they were taken with so much care , down [the stairs]1353-the stairs , back into [the drawing - room]573-the drawing - room . By the bed- candle flaring in the draught , [she]77-miss monro saw that there was the glittering mark of wet tears on [his]1347-i cheek ; and [she]77-miss monro felt , as [she]77-miss monro said afterwards , " sorry for [the young man]309-the young man . "[77-miss monro] And yet [she]77-miss monro urged [him]1347-i to go , for [she]77-miss monro knew that [she]77-miss monro might be wanted [upstairs]1175-upstairs . [He]1347-i took [her]77-miss monro hand , and wrung it hard . " Thank [you]77-miss monro . [She]77-miss monro looked so changed -- oh ! [she]77-miss monro looked as though [she]77-miss monro were dead . [You]77-miss monro will write -- [Herbert Livingstone]114-herbert livingstone , [Langham Vicarage]23-langham vicarage , [Yorkshire]24-yorkshire ; [you]77-miss monro will promise [me]1347-i to write . If [I]1347-i could do anything for [her]77-miss monro , but [I]1347-i can but pray . Oh , [[my]1347-i darling]2838-my darling ; [[my]1347-i darling]2838-my darling ! and [I]1347-i have no right to be with [her]77-miss monro . "[1347-i] " Go away , there 's [a good young man]2840-a good young man , "[77-miss monro] said [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , all the more pressing to hurry [him]1356-him out by the front door , because [she]77-miss monro was afraid of [his]1356-him emotion overmastering [him]1356-him , and making [him]1356-him noisy in [his]1356-him demonstrations . " Yes , [I]77-miss monro will write ; [I]77-miss monro will write , never fear ! "[77-miss monro] and [she]77-miss monro bolted the door behind [him]1356-him , and was thankful . Two minutes afterwards there was a low tap ; [she]77-miss monro undid the fastenings , and there [he]1356-him stood , pale in the moonlight . " Please do n't tell [her]77-miss monro [I]77-miss monro came to ask about [her]77-miss monro ; [she]77-miss monro might not like it . "[77-miss monro] " No , no ! not [I]1356-him ! [Poor creature]2841-poor creature , [she]77-miss monro 's not likely to care to hear anything this long while . [She]77-miss monro never roused at [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's name . "[1356-him] " [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's ! "[114-herbert livingstone] said [Livingstone]114-herbert livingstone , below [his]1356-him breath , and [he]1356-him turned and went away ; this time for good . But [Ellinor]73-ellinor recovered . [She]73-ellinor knew [she]73-ellinor was recovering , when day after day [she]73-ellinor felt involuntary strength and appetite return . [Her]73-ellinor body seemed stronger than [her]73-ellinor will ; for that would have induced [her]73-ellinor to creep into [her]73-ellinor grave , and shut [her]73-ellinor eyes for ever on [this world]1357-this world , so full of troubles . [She]73-ellinor lay , for the most part , with [her]73-ellinor eyes closed , very still and quiet ; but [she]73-ellinor thought with the intensity of [one who seeks for lost peace]1358-one who seeks for lost peace , and can not find it . [She]73-ellinor began to see that if in the mad impulses of that mad nightmare of horror , [they]1359-they had all strengthened [each other]523-each other , and dared to be frank and open , confessing a great fault , a greater disaster , a greater woe -- which in the first instance was hardly a crime -- [their]1359-they future course , though sad and sorrowful , would have been a simple and straightforward one to tread . But it was not for [her]73-ellinor to undo what was done , and to reveal the error and shame of [a father]1361-a father . Only [she]73-ellinor , turning anew to [God]119-god , in the solemn and quiet watches of the night , made a covenant , that in [her]73-ellinor conduct , [her]73-ellinor own personal individual life , [she]73-ellinor would act loyally and truthfully . And as for the future , and all the terrible chances involved in it , [she]73-ellinor would leave it in [His]1361-a father hands -- if , indeed ( and here came in the Tempter ) , [He]1361-a father would watch over [one whose life hereafter must seem based upon a lie]1362-one whose life hereafter must seem based upon a lie . [Her]73-ellinor only plea , offered " standing afar off "[73-ellinor] was , " The lie is said and done and over -- it was not for [my]73-ellinor own sake . Can filial piety be so overcome by the rights of justice and truth , as to demand of [me]73-ellinor that [I]73-ellinor should reveal [[my]73-ellinor father]2646-my father 's guilt . "[73-ellinor] [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's severe sharp punishment began . [He]398-her father knew why [she]73-ellinor suffered , what made [her]73-ellinor young strength falter and tremble , what made [her]73-ellinor life seem nigh about to be quenched in death . Yet [he]398-her father could not take [his]398-her father sorrow and care in the natural manner . [He]398-her father was obliged to think how every word and deed would be construed . [He]398-her father fancied that [people]446-people were watching [him]398-her father with suspicious eyes , when nothing was further from [their]446-people thoughts . For once let the " public "[446-people] of any place be possessed by an idea , it is more difficult to dislodge it than [any one imagines who has not tried]1365-any one imagines who has not tried . If [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had gone into [Hamley market - place]835-hamley market - place , and proclaimed [himself]66-mr. wilkins guilty of the manslaughter of [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster -- nay , if [he]66-mr. wilkins had detailed all the circumstances -- [the people]1367-the people would have exclaimed , " [Poor man]2843-poor man , [he]66-mr. wilkins is crazed by this discovery of the unworthiness of [the man [he]66-mr. wilkins trusted so]2844-the man he trusted so ; and no wonder -- it was such a thing to have done -- to have defrauded [[his]66-mr. wilkins partner]1103-his partner to such an extent , and then have made off to [America]25-america ! "[1367-the people] For many small circumstances , which [I]0-i do not stop to detail here , went far to prove this , as [we]1368-we know , unfounded supposition ; and [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , who was known , from [his]66-mr. wilkins handsome boyhood , through [his]66-mr. wilkins comely manhood , up to the present time , by all [the people in [Hamley]1-hamley]1369-the people in hamley , was an object of sympathy and respect to [every one who saw [him]66-mr. wilkins , as [he]66-mr. wilkins passed by , old , and lorn , and haggard before [his]66-mr. wilkins time , all through the evil conduct of one , [London]4-london - bred , who was as [a hard , unlovely stranger to the popular mind of [this little country town]1372-this little country town]1371-a hard , unlovely stranger to the popular mind of this little country town]1370-every one who saw him , as he passed by , old , and lorn , and haggard before his time , all through the evil conduct of one , london - bred , who was as a hard , unlovely stranger to the popular mind of this little country town . [[Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's own servants]1373-mr. wilkins 's own servants liked [him]66-mr. wilkins . The workings of [his]66-mr. wilkins temptations were such as [they]1373-mr. wilkins 's own servants could understand . If [he]66-mr. wilkins had been hot - tempered [he]66-mr. wilkins had also been generous , or [I]0-i should rather say careless and lavish with [his]66-mr. wilkins money . And now that [he]66-mr. wilkins was cheated and impoverished by [[his]66-mr. wilkins partner]1103-his partner 's delinquency , [they]1373-mr. wilkins 's own servants thought it no wonder that [he]66-mr. wilkins drank long and deep in the solitary evenings which [he]66-mr. wilkins passed at [home]230-home . It was not that [he]66-mr. wilkins was without invitations . [Every one]497-every one came forward to testify [their]497-every one respect for [him]66-mr. wilkins by asking [him]66-mr. wilkins to [[their]497-every one houses]1377-their houses . [He]66-mr. wilkins had probably never been so universally popular since [[his]66-mr. wilkins father]222-his father 's death . But , as [he]66-mr. wilkins said , [he]66-mr. wilkins did not care to go into society while [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter was so ill -- [he]66-mr. wilkins had no spirits for company . But if [any one]616-any one had cared to observe [his]66-mr. wilkins conduct at [home]230-home , and to draw conclusions from it , [they]497-every one could have noticed that , anxious as [he]66-mr. wilkins was about [Ellinor]73-ellinor , [he]66-mr. wilkins rather avoided than sought [her]73-ellinor presence , now that [her]73-ellinor consciousness and memory were restored . Nor did [she]73-ellinor ask for , or wish for [him]66-mr. wilkins . The presence of [each]1313-each was a burden to [the other]525-the other . Oh , sad and woeful night of May -- overshadowing the coming summer months with gloom and bitter remorse ! CHAPTER VIII . Still youth prevailed over all . [Ellinor]73-ellinor got well , as [I]0-i have said , even when [she]73-ellinor would fain have died . And the afternoon came when [she]73-ellinor left [[her]73-ellinor room]708-her room . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro would gladly have made a festival of [her]73-ellinor recovery , and have had [her]73-ellinor conveyed into [the unused drawing - room]1385-the unused drawing - room . But [Ellinor]73-ellinor begged that [she]73-ellinor might be taken into [the library]756-the library -- into [the schoolroom]788-the schoolroom -- anywhere ( thought [she]73-ellinor ) not looking on the side of [the house]761-the house on [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden , which [she]73-ellinor had felt in all [her]73-ellinor illness as a ghastly pressure lying within sight of those very windows , through which the morning sun streamed right upon [her]73-ellinor bed -- like the accusing angel , bringing all hidden things to light . And when [Ellinor]73-ellinor was better still , when the Bath - chair had been sent up for [her]73-ellinor use , by [some kindly old maid , out of [Hamley]1-hamley]1390-some kindly old maid , out of hamley , [she]73-ellinor still petitioned that it might be kept on [the lawn]1391-the lawn or town side of [the house]761-the house , away from [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden . One day [she]73-ellinor almost screamed , when , as [she]73-ellinor was going to the front door , [she]73-ellinor saw [Dixon]86-dixon standing ready to draw [her]73-ellinor , instead of [[Fletcher]123-fletcher the servant who usually went]1394-fletcher the servant who usually went . But [she]73-ellinor checked all demonstration of feeling ; although it was the first time [she]73-ellinor had seen [him]86-dixon since [he]86-dixon and [she]73-ellinor and one more had worked [their]1395-we hearts out in hard bodily labour . [He]86-dixon looked so stern and ill ! [Cross]125-cross , too , which [she]73-ellinor had never seen [him]86-dixon before . As soon as [they]1395-we were out of immediate sight of the windows , [she]73-ellinor asked [him]86-dixon to stop , forcing [herself]73-ellinor to speak to [him]86-dixon . " [Dixon]86-dixon , [you]86-dixon look very poorly , "[73-ellinor] [she]73-ellinor said , trembling as [she]73-ellinor spoke . " Ay ! "[86-dixon] said [he]86-dixon . " [We]1395-we did n't think much of it at the time , did [we]1395-we , [Miss Nelly]111-nelly ? But it 'll be the death on [us]1395-we , [I]86-dixon 'm thinking . It has aged [me]86-dixon above a bit . All [my]86-dixon fifty years afore were but as a forenoon of [child]466-child 's play to that night . [Measter]126-measter , too -- [I]86-dixon could a - bear a good deal , but [measter]126-measter cuts through [the stable - yard]775-the stable - yard , and past [me]86-dixon , wi'out a word , as if [I]86-dixon was poison , or a stinking foumart . It 's that as is worst , [Miss Nelly]111-nelly , it is . "[86-dixon] And [the poor man]1396-the poor man brushed some tears from [his]1396-the poor man eyes with the back of [his]1396-the poor man withered , furrowed hand . [Ellinor]73-ellinor caught the infection , and cried outright , sobbed like [a child]584-a child , even while [she]73-ellinor held out [her]73-ellinor little white thin hand to [his]1396-the poor man grasp . For as soon as [he]1396-the poor man saw [her]73-ellinor emotion , [he]1396-the poor man was penitent for what [he]1396-the poor man had said . " Do n't now -- don't , "[1396-the poor man] was all [he]1396-the poor man could think of to say . " [Dixon]86-dixon ! "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor at length , " [you]86-dixon must not mind it . [You]86-dixon must try not to mind it . [I]73-ellinor see [he]1396-the poor man does not like to be reminded of that , even by seeing [me]73-ellinor . [He]1396-the poor man tries never to be alone with [me]73-ellinor . [[My]73-ellinor poor old [Dixon]86-dixon]2848-my poor old dixon , it has spoilt [my]73-ellinor life for [me]73-ellinor ; for [I]73-ellinor do n't think [he]1396-the poor man loves [me]73-ellinor any more . "[73-ellinor] [She]73-ellinor sobbed as if [her]73-ellinor heart would break ; and now it was [Dixon]86-dixon 's turn to be comforter . " Ah , [dear]2849-dear , [my]1398-i blessing , [he]1396-the poor man loves [you]2849-dear above everything . It 's only [he]1396-the poor man ca n't a - bear the sight of [us]2850-us , as is but natural . And if [he]1396-the poor man does n't fancy being alone with [you]2849-dear , there 's always one as does , and that 's a comfort at the worst of times . And do n't [ye]2849-dear fret about what [I]1398-i said a minute ago . [I]1398-i were put out because [measter]1396-the poor man all but pushed [me]1398-i out of [his]1396-the poor man way this morning , without never a word . But [I]1398-i were [an old fool]2851-an old fool for telling [ye]2849-dear . And [I]1398-i 've really forgotten why [I]1398-i told [Fletcher]123-fletcher [I]1398-i 'd drag [ye]2849-dear a bit about to- day . [Th ' gardener]2852-th ' gardener is beginning for to wonder as [you]2849-dear do n't want to see th ' annuals and bedding - out things as [you]2849-dear were so particular about in [May]97-lady maria . And [I]1398-i thought [I]1398-i 'd just have a word wi ' [ye]2849-dear , and then if [you]2849-dear 'd let [me]1398-i , [we]2853-we 'd go together just once round [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden , just to say [you]2849-dear 've been , [you]2849-dear know , and to give [them chaps]2855-them chaps a bit of praise . [You]2849-dear 'll only have to look on the beds , [[my]1398-i pretty]2617-my pretty , and it must be done some time . So come along ! "[1398-i] [He]1398-i began to pull resolutely in the direction of [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden . [Ellinor]73-ellinor bit [her]73-ellinor lips to keep in the cry of repugnance that rose to [them]1400-them . As [Dixon]86-dixon stopped to unlock the door , [he]1398-i said : " It 's not hardness , nothing like it ; [I]1398-i 've waited till [I]1398-i heerd [you]73-ellinor were better ; but it 's in for a penny in for a pound wi ' [us]2853-we all ; and [folk]2857-folk may talk ; and bless [your]73-ellinor little brave heart , [you]73-ellinor 'll stand a deal for [[your]73-ellinor father]2658-your father 's sake , and so will [I]1398-i , though [I]1398-i do feel it above a bit , when [he]2658-your father puts out [his]2658-your father hand as if to keep [me]1398-i off , and [I]1398-i only going to speak to [him]2658-your father about [Clipper]127-clipper 's knees ; though [I]1398-i 'll own [I]1398-i had wondered many a day when [I]1398-i was to have [the good - morrow master]2859-the good - morrow master never missed sin ' [he]2859-the good - morrow master were [a boy]389-a boy till -- Well ! and now [you]73-ellinor 've seen the beds , and can say they looked mighty pretty , and is done all as [you]73-ellinor wished ; and [we]2861-we 're got out again , and breathing fresher air than yon sunbaked hole , with its smelling flowers , not half so wholesome to snuff at as good stable - dung . "[1398-i] So [the good man]1401-the good man chatted on ; not without the purpose of giving [Ellinor]73-ellinor time to recover [herself]73-ellinor ; and partly also to drown [his]1401-the good man own cares , which lay heavier on [his]1401-the good man heart than [he]1401-the good man could say . But [he]1401-the good man thought [himself]1401-the good man rewarded by [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's thanks , and warm pressure of [his]1401-the good man hard hand as [she]73-ellinor got out at the front door , and bade [him]1401-the good man good - by . The break to [her]73-ellinor days of weary monotony was the letters [she]73-ellinor constantly received from [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet . And yet here again lurked the sting . [He]1401-the good man was all astonishment and indignation at [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's disappearance , or rather flight , to [America]25-america . And now that [she]73-ellinor was growing stronger , [he]1401-the good man did not scruple to express curiosity respecting the details , never doubting but that [she]73-ellinor was perfectly acquainted with much that [he]1401-the good man wanted to know ; although [he]1401-the good man had too much delicacy to question [her]73-ellinor on the point which was most important of all in [his]1401-the good man eyes , namely , how far it had affected [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's worldly prospects ; for the report prevalent in [Hamley]1-hamley had reached [London]4-london , that [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster had made away with , or carried off , [trust property]1402-trust property to a considerable extent , for all which [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins would of course be liable . It was hard work for [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet to keep from seeking direct information on this head from [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , or , indeed , from [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins [himself]66-mr. wilkins . But [he]1401-the good man restrained [himself]1401-the good man , knowing that in August [he]1401-the good man should be able to make all these inquiries personally . Before the end of the long vacation [he]1401-the good man had hoped to marry [Ellinor]73-ellinor : that was the time which had been planned by [them]1403-them when [they]1403-them had met in the early spring before [her]73-ellinor illness and all this misfortune happened . But now , as [he]1401-the good man wrote to [[his]1401-the good man father]222-his father , nothing could be definitely arranged until [he]1401-the good man had paid [his]1401-the good man visit to [Hamley]1-hamley , and seen the state of affairs . Accordingly one Saturday in August , [he]1401-the good man came to [Ford Bank]15-ford bank , this time as [a visitor to [[Ellinor]73-ellinor 's home]1406-ellinor 's home]1405-a visitor to ellinor 's home , instead of to [[his]1401-the good man old quarters at [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness 's]1407-his old quarters at mr. ness 's . [The house]761-the house was still as if asleep in the full heat of the afternoon sun , as [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet drove up . The window - blinds were down ; the front door wide open , great stands of heliotrope and roses and geraniums stood just within the shadow of [the hall]751-the hall ; but through all the silence [his]1401-the good man approach seemed to excite no commotion . [He]1401-the good man thought it strange that [he]1401-the good man had not been watched for , that [Ellinor]73-ellinor did not come running out to meet [him]1401-the good man , that [she]73-ellinor allowed [Fletcher]123-fletcher to come and attend to [his]1401-the good man luggage , and usher [him]1401-the good man into [the library]756-the library just like [any common visitor]1411-any common visitor , [any morning - caller]1412-any morning - caller . [He]1401-the good man stiffened [himself]1401-the good man up into a moment 's indignant coldness of manner . But it vanished in an instant when , on the door being opened , [he]1401-the good man saw [Ellinor]73-ellinor standing holding by the table , looking for [his]1401-the good man appearance with almost panting anxiety . [He]1401-the good man thought of nothing then but [her]73-ellinor evident weakness , [her]73-ellinor changed looks , for which no account of [her]73-ellinor illness had prepared [him]1401-the good man . For [she]73-ellinor was deadly white , lips and all ; and [her]73-ellinor dark eyes seemed unnaturally enlarged , while the caves in which they were set were strangely deep and hollow . [Her]73-ellinor hair , too , had been cut off pretty closely ; [she]73-ellinor did not usually wear a cap , but with some faint idea of making [herself]73-ellinor look better in [his]1401-the good man eye , [she]73-ellinor had put on one this day , and the effect was that [she]73-ellinor seemed to be forty years of age ; but one instant after [he]1401-the good man had come in , [her]73-ellinor pale face was flooded with crimson , and [her]73-ellinor eyes were full of tears . [She]73-ellinor had hard work to keep [herself]73-ellinor from going into hysterics , but [she]73-ellinor instinctively knew how much [he]1401-the good man would hate a scene , and [she]73-ellinor checked [herself]73-ellinor in time . " Oh , "[73-ellinor] [she]73-ellinor murmured , " [I]73-ellinor am so glad to see [you]1401-the good man ; it is such a comfort , such an infinite pleasure . "[73-ellinor] And so [she]73-ellinor went on , cooing out words over [him]1401-the good man , and stroking [his]1401-the good man hair with [her]73-ellinor thin fingers ; while [he]1401-the good man rather tried to avert [his]1401-the good man eyes , [he]1401-the good man was so much afraid of betraying how much [he]1401-the good man thought [her]73-ellinor altered . But when [she]73-ellinor came down , dressed for dinner , this sense of [her]73-ellinor change was diminished to [him]1401-the good man . [Her]73-ellinor short brown hair had already a little wave , and was ornamented by some black lace ; [she]73-ellinor wore a large black lace shawl -- it had been [[her]73-ellinor mother]458-her mother 's of old -- over some delicate - coloured muslin dress ; [her]73-ellinor face was slightly flushed , and had the tints of a wild rose ; [her]73-ellinor lips kept pale and trembling with involuntary motion , it is true ; and as [the lovers]1414-the lovers stood together , hand in hand , by the window , [he]1401-the good man was aware of a little convulsive twitching at every noise , even while [she]73-ellinor seemed gazing in tranquil pleasure on the long smooth slope of [the newly - mown lawn]1415-the newly - mown lawn , stretching down to [the little brook that prattled merrily over the stones on its merry course to [Hamley town]1417-hamley town]1416-the little brook that prattled merrily over the stones on its merry course to hamley town . [He]1401-the good man felt a stronger twitch than ever before ; even while [his]1401-the good man ear , less delicate than [hers]73-ellinor , could distinguish no peculiar sound . About two minutes after [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins entered [the room]479-the room . [He]66-mr. wilkins came up to [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet with a warm welcome : some of it real , some of it assumed . [He]1401-the good man talked volubly to [him]66-mr. wilkins , taking little or no notice of [Ellinor]73-ellinor , who dropped into the background , and sat down on the sofa by [Miss Monro]77-miss monro ; for on this day [they]1414-the lovers were all to dine together . [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet thought that [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was aged ; but no wonder , after all [his]66-mr. wilkins anxiety of various kinds : [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's flight and reported defalcations , [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's illness , of the seriousness of which [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover was now convinced by [her]73-ellinor appearance . [He]66-mr. wilkins would fain have spoken more to [her]73-ellinor during the dinner that ensued , but [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins absorbed all [his]66-mr. wilkins attention , talking and questioning on subjects that left [the ladies]1420-the ladies out of the conversation almost perpetually . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet recognised [[his]81-mr. corbet host]1421-his host 's fine tact , even while [his]66-mr. wilkins persistence in talking annoyed [him]81-mr. corbet . [He]81-mr. corbet was quite sure that [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was anxious to spare [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter any exertion beyond that -- to which , indeed , [she]520-his daughter seemed scarely equal -- of sitting at the head of the table . And the more [[her]520-his daughter father]398-her father talked -- so fine [an observer]1424-an observer was [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet -- [the more silent and depressed]1425-the more silent and depressed [Ellinor]73-ellinor appeared . But by - and - by [he]81-mr. corbet accounted for this inverse ratio of gaiety , as [he]81-mr. corbet perceived how quickly [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins had [his]66-mr. wilkins glass replenished . And here , again , [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet drew [his]81-mr. corbet conclusions , from the silent way in which , without a word or a sign from [[his]81-mr. corbet master]480-his master , [Fletcher]123-fletcher gave [him]81-mr. corbet more wine continually -- wine that was drained off at once . " Six glasses of sherry before dessert , "[81-mr. corbet] thought [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet to [himself]81-mr. corbet . " Bad habit -- no wonder [Ellinor]73-ellinor looks grave . "[81-mr. corbet] And when [the gentlemen]1427-the gentlemen were left alone , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins helped [himself]66-mr. wilkins even still more freely ; yet without the slightest effect on the clearness and brilliancy of [his]66-mr. wilkins conversation . [He]66-mr. wilkins had always talked well and racily , that [Ralph]81-mr. corbet knew , and in this power [he]66-mr. wilkins now recognised a temptation to which [he]66-mr. wilkins feared that [[his]66-mr. wilkins future father - in - law]1428-his future father - in - law had succumbed . And yet , while [he]66-mr. wilkins perceived that this gift led into temptation , [he]66-mr. wilkins coveted it for [himself]66-mr. wilkins ; for [he]66-mr. wilkins was perfectly aware that this fluency , this happy choice of epithets , was the one thing [he]66-mr. wilkins should fail in when [he]66-mr. wilkins began to enter into the more active career of [his]66-mr. wilkins profession . But after some time spent in listening , and admiring , with this little feeling of envy lurking in the background , [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet became aware of [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's increasing confusion of ideas , and rather unnatural merriment ; and , with a sudden revulsion from admiration to disgust , [he]81-mr. corbet rose up to go into [the library]756-the library , where [Ellinor]73-ellinor and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro were sitting . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins accompanied [him]81-mr. corbet , laughing and talking somewhat loudly . Was [Ellinor]73-ellinor aware of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's state ? Of that [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet could not be sure . [She]73-ellinor looked up with grave sad eyes as [they]1431-they came into [the room]479-the room , but with no apparent sensation of surprise , annoyance , or shame . When [her]73-ellinor glance met [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's , [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet noticed that it seemed to sober [the latter]271-the latter immediately . [He]81-mr. corbet sat down near the open window , and did not speak , but sighed heavily from time to time . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro took up a book , in order to leave [the young people]742-the young people to [themselves]742-the young people ; and after a little low murmured conversation , [Ellinor]73-ellinor went [upstairs]1175-upstairs to put on [her]73-ellinor things for a stroll through [the meadows]1437-the meadows by [the river - side]1438-the river - side . [They]1431-they were sometimes sauntering along in the lovely summer twilight , now resting on [some grassy hedge - row bank]1439-some grassy hedge - row bank , or standing still , looking at [the great barges]1440-the great barges , with [their]1440-the great barges crimson sails , lazily floating down [the river]1441-the river , making ripples on the glassy opal surface of [the water]1442-the water . [They]1431-they did not talk very much ; [Ellinor]73-ellinor seemed disinclined for the exertion ; and [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover was thinking over [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's behaviour , with some surprise and distaste of the habit so evidently growing upon [him]66-mr. wilkins . [They]1431-they came [home]230-home , looking serious and tired : yet [they]1431-they could not account for [their]1431-they fatigue by the length of [their]1431-they walk , and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , forgetting [Autolycus]128-autolycus 's song , kept fidgeting about [Ellinor]73-ellinor , and wondering how it was [she]73-ellinor looked so pale , if [she]73-ellinor had only been as far as [the Ash Meadow]1445-the ash meadow . To escape from this wonder , [Ellinor]73-ellinor went early to bed . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was gone , [no one]385-no one knew where , and [Ralph]81-mr. corbet and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro were left to a half- hour 's _ tete - a - tete _ . [He]66-mr. wilkins thought [he]66-mr. wilkins could easily account for [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's languor , if , indeed , [she]73-ellinor had perceived as much as [he]66-mr. wilkins had done of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's state , when [they]1431-they had come into [the library]756-the library after dinner . But there were many details which [he]66-mr. wilkins was anxious to hear from [a comparatively indifferent person]1449-a comparatively indifferent person , and as soon as [he]66-mr. wilkins could , [he]66-mr. wilkins passed on from the conversation about [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's health , to inquiries as to the whole affair of [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's disappearance . Next to [her]77-miss monro anxiety about [Ellinor]73-ellinor , [Miss Monro]77-miss monro liked to dilate on the mystery connected with [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's flight ; for that was the word [she]77-miss monro employed without hesitation , as [she]77-miss monro gave [him]66-mr. wilkins the account of the event universally received and believed in by [the people of [Hamley]1-hamley]1450-the people of hamley . How [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster had never been liked by [any one]616-any one ; how [everybody]379-everybody remembered that [he]84-mr. dunster could never look [them]379-everybody straight in the face ; how [he]84-mr. dunster always seemed to be hiding something that [he]84-mr. dunster did not want to have known ; how [he]84-mr. dunster had drawn a large sum ( exact quantity unknown ) out of the county bank only the day before [he]84-mr. dunster left [Hamley]1-hamley , doubtless in preparation for [his]84-mr. dunster escape ; how [some one]1211-some one had told [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins [he]1211-some one had seen [a man just like [Dunster]84-mr. dunster lurking about [the docks]1455-the docks at [Liverpool]26-liverpool]1454-a man just like dunster lurking about the docks at liverpool , about two days after [he]84-mr. dunster had left [[his]84-mr. dunster lodgings]1456-his lodgings , but that [this some one , being in a hurry]1457-this some one , being in a hurry , had not cared to stop and speak to [the man]1225-the man ; how that the affairs in [the office]580-the office were discovered to be in such a sad state that it was no wonder that [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster had absconded -- [he]84-mr. dunster that had been so trusted by poor dear [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins . Money gone [no one]385-no one knew how or where . " But has [he]84-mr. dunster no friends who can explain [his]84-mr. dunster proceedings , and account for the missing money , in some way ? "[81-mr. corbet] asked [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet . " No , none . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins has written everywhere , right and left , [I]81-mr. corbet believe . [I]81-mr. corbet know [he]84-mr. dunster had a letter from [[Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's nearest relation]2862-mr. dunster 's nearest relation -- [a tradesman in [the City]2864-the city]2863-a tradesman in the city -- [a cousin]2865-a cousin , [I]81-mr. corbet think , and [he]84-mr. dunster could give no information in any way . [He]84-mr. dunster knew that about ten years ago [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster had had a great fancy for going to [America]25-america , and had read a great many travels -- all just what [a man]286-a man would do before going off to [a country]2867-a country . "[81-mr. corbet] " Ten years is a long time beforehand , "[81-mr. corbet] said [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet , half smiling ; " shows malice prepense with a vengeance . "[81-mr. corbet] But then , turning grave , [he]81-mr. corbet said : " Did [he]84-mr. dunster leave [Hamley]1-hamley in debt ? "[81-mr. corbet] " No ; [I]77-miss monro never heard of that , "[77-miss monro] said [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , rather unwillingly , for [she]77-miss monro considered it as a piece of loyalty to [the Wilkinses]85-the wilkinses , whom [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster had injured ( as [she]77-miss monro thought ) to blacken [his]84-mr. dunster character as much as was consistent with any degree of truth . " It is a strange story , "[81-mr. corbet] said [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet , musing . " Not at all , "[77-miss monro] [she]77-miss monro replied , quickly ; " [I]77-miss monro am sure , if [you]81-mr. corbet had seen [the man]1225-the man , with one or two side - locks of hair combed over [his]1225-the man baldness , as if [he]1225-the man were ashamed of it , and [his]1225-the man eyes that never looked at [you]81-mr. corbet , and [his]1225-the man way of eating with [his]1225-the man knife when [he]1225-the man thought [he]1225-the man was not observed -- oh , and numbers of things!--you would not think it strange . "[77-miss monro] [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet smiled . " [I]81-mr. corbet only meant that [he]1225-the man seems to have had no extravagant or vicious habits which would account for [his]1225-the man embezzlement of the money that is missing -- but , to be sure , money in itself is a temptation -- only [he]1225-the man , being [a partner]886-a partner , was in a fair way of making it without risk to [himself]1225-the man . Has [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins taken any steps to have [him]1225-the man arrested in [America]25-america ? [He]1225-the man might easily do that . "[81-mr. corbet] " Oh , [[my]77-miss monro dear]2732-my dear [Mr. Ralph]81-mr. corbet , [you]81-mr. corbet do n't know [[our]2871-our good [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins]2872-our good mr. wilkins ! [He]1225-the man would rather bear the loss , [I]77-miss monro am sure , and all this trouble and care which it has brought upon [him]1225-the man , than be revenged upon [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster . "[77-miss monro] " Revenged ! What nonsense ! It is simple justice -- justice to [himself]1225-the man and to [others]2873-others -- to see that villainy is so sufficiently punished as to deter [others]2873-others from entering upon such courses . But [I]77-miss monro have little doubt [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins has taken the right steps ; [he]66-mr. wilkins is not [the man to sit down quietly under such a loss]2875-the man to sit down quietly under such a loss . "[77-miss monro] " No , indeed ! [he]66-mr. wilkins had [him]66-mr. wilkins advertised in the _ Times _ and in the county papers , and offered a reward of twenty pounds for information concerning [him]66-mr. wilkins . "[81-mr. corbet] " Twenty pounds was too little . "[77-miss monro] " So [I]77-miss monro said . [I]77-miss monro told [Ellinor]73-ellinor that [I]77-miss monro would give twenty pounds [myself]77-miss monro to have [him]66-mr. wilkins apprehended , and [she]73-ellinor , [poor darling]2876-poor darling ! fell a - trembling , and said , ' [I]77-miss monro would give all [I]77-miss monro have -- [I]77-miss monro would give [my]77-miss monro life . ' And then [she]73-ellinor was in such distress , and sobbed so , [I]77-miss monro promised [her]73-ellinor [I]77-miss monro would never name it to [her]73-ellinor again . "[77-miss monro] " [Poor child]728-poor child -- [poor child]728-poor child ! [she]73-ellinor wants change of scene . [Her]73-ellinor nerves have been sadly shaken by [her]73-ellinor illness . "[77-miss monro] The next day was Sunday ; [Ellinor]73-ellinor was to go to [church]1461-church for the first time since [her]73-ellinor illness . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father had decided it for [her]73-ellinor , or else [she]73-ellinor would fain have stayed away -- [she]73-ellinor would hardly acknowledge why , even to [herself]73-ellinor , but it seemed to [her]73-ellinor as if the very words and presence of [God]119-god must there search [her]73-ellinor and find [her]73-ellinor out . [She]73-ellinor went early , leaning on the arm of [[her]73-ellinor lover]890-her lover , and trying to forget the past in the present . [They]1464-they walked slowly along between the rows of waving golden corn ripe for the harvest . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet gathered blue and scarlet flowers , and made up a little rustic nosegay for [her]73-ellinor . [She]73-ellinor took and stuck it in [her]73-ellinor girdle , smiling faintly as [she]73-ellinor did so . [Hamley Church]27-hamley church had , in former days , been collegiate , and was , in consequence , much larger and grander than [the majority of [country - town churches]1466-country - town churches]1465-the majority of country - town churches . [The Ford Bank pew]1467-the ford bank pew was [a square one]1468-a square one , [downstairs]1469-downstairs ; [the Ford Bank servants]1470-the ford bank servants sat in a front pew in [the gallery]1471-the gallery , right before [[their]1470-the ford bank servants master]1472-their master . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was " hardening [her]73-ellinor heart "[73-ellinor] not to listen , not to hearken to what might disturb the wound which was just being skinned over , when [she]73-ellinor caught [Dixon]86-dixon 's face up above . [He]86-dixon looked worn , sad , soured , and anxious to a miserable degree ; but [he]86-dixon was straining eyes and ears , heart and soul , to hear the solemn words read from the pulpit , as if in them alone [he]86-dixon could find help in [his]86-dixon strait . [Ellinor]73-ellinor felt rebuked and humbled . [She]73-ellinor was in a tumultuous state of mind when [they]1473-they left [church]1461-church ; [she]73-ellinor wished to do [her]73-ellinor duty , yet could not ascertain what it was . Who was to help [her]73-ellinor with wisdom and advice ? Assuredly [he]86-dixon to whom [her]73-ellinor future life was to be trusted . But the case must be stated in an impersonal form . [No one]385-no one , not even [[her]73-ellinor husband]407-her husband , must ever know anything against [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father from [her]73-ellinor . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was so artless [herself]73-ellinor , that [she]73-ellinor had little idea how quickly and easily [some people]648-some people can penetrate motives , and combine disjointed sentences . [She]73-ellinor began to speak to [Ralph]81-mr. corbet on [their]1473-they slow , sauntering walk homewards through [the quiet meadows]1479-the quiet meadows : " Suppose , [Ralph]81-mr. corbet , that [a girl]390-a girl was engaged to be married-- "[73-ellinor] " [I]81-mr. corbet can very easily suppose that , with [you]73-ellinor by [me]81-mr. corbet , "[81-mr. corbet] said [he]81-mr. corbet , filling up [her]73-ellinor pause . " Oh ! but [I]73-ellinor do n't mean [myself]73-ellinor at all , "[73-ellinor] replied [she]73-ellinor , reddening . " [I]73-ellinor am only thinking of what might happen ; and suppose that [this girl]2682-this girl knew of [some one belonging to [her]2682-this girl]2881-some one belonging to her -- [we]1473-they will call it [a brother]2882-a brother -- who had done something wrong , that would bring disgrace upon [the whole family]2883-the whole family if it was known -- though , indeed , it might not have been so very wrong as it seemed , and as it would look to [the world]609-the world -- ought [she]2682-this girl to break off [her]2682-this girl engagement for fear of involving [[her]2682-this girl lover]890-her lover in the disgrace ? "[73-ellinor] " Certainly not , without telling [him]1480-i [her]2682-this girl reason for doing so . "[73-ellinor] " Ah ! but suppose [she]2682-this girl could not . [She]2682-this girl might not be at liberty to do so . "[73-ellinor] " [I]1480-i ca n't answer supposititious cases . "[1480-i] asked [he]1480-i , rather abruptly . " Oh , of [no one]385-no one , "[1481-you] [she]1481-you answered in affright . " Why should [I]1481-you be thinking of [any one]616-any one ? [I]1481-you often try to plan out what [I]1481-you should do , or what [I]1481-you ought to do , if such and such a thing happened , just as [you]1481-you recollect [I]1481-you used to wonder if [I]1481-you should have presence of mind in case of fire . "[73-ellinor] " Yes , [I]1481-you suppose so , "[1481-you] said [she]1481-you , a little annoyed at having betrayed any personal interest in the affair . [He]1480-i was silent , meditating . " Something has happened which has suggested these questions . Are [you]1481-you putting [yourself]1481-you in the place of any one about whom [you]1481-you have been hearing lately ? "[1480-i] " No ; it was a very foolish question of [mine]1480-i , and [I]551-the clergyman ought not to have said anything about it . See ! here is [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness overtaking [us]1483-them . "[551-the clergyman] [The clergyman]551-the clergyman joined [them]1483-them on the broad walk that ran by [the river - side]1438-the river - side , and the talk became general . It was a relief to [Ellinor]73-ellinor , who had not attained [her]73-ellinor end , but who had gone far towards betraying something of [her]73-ellinor own individual interest in the question [she]73-ellinor had asked . [Ralph]81-mr. corbet had been more struck even by [her]73-ellinor manner than [her]73-ellinor words . [He]81-mr. corbet was sure that something lurked behind , and had an idea of [his]81-mr. corbet own that it was connected with [Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's disappearance . But [he]81-mr. corbet was glad that [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness 's joining [them]1483-them gave [him]81-mr. corbet leisure to consider a little . The end of [his]81-mr. corbet reflections was , that the next day , Monday , [he]81-mr. corbet went into [the town]277-the town , and artfully learnt all [he]81-mr. corbet could hear about [Mr Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's character and mode of going on ; and with still more skill [he]81-mr. corbet extracted the popular opinion as to the embarrassed nature of [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's affairs -- embarrassment which was generally attributed to [Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's disappearance with a good large sum belonging to [the firm in [his]81-mr. corbet possession]1486-the firm in his possession . But [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet thought otherwise ; [he]81-mr. corbet had accustomed [himself]81-mr. corbet to seek out the baser motives for [men]857-men 's conduct , and to call the result of these researches wisdom . [He]81-mr. corbet imagined that [Dunster]84-mr. dunster had been well paid by [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins for [his]84-mr. dunster disappearance , which was an easy way of accounting for the derangement of accounts and loss of money that arose , in fact , from [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's extravagance of habits and growing intemperance . On the Monday afternoon [he]81-mr. corbet said to [Ellinor]73-ellinor , " [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness interrupted [us]2891-us yesterday in a very interesting conversation . Do [you]73-ellinor remember , [love]2892-love ? "[81-mr. corbet] [Ellinor]73-ellinor reddened and kept [her]73-ellinor head still more intently bent over a sketch [she]73-ellinor was making . " Yes ; [I]73-ellinor recollect . "[73-ellinor] " [I]81-mr. corbet have been thinking about it . "[81-mr. corbet] " Oh ! but , [Ralph]81-mr. corbet , it might perhaps be something [she]73-ellinor ought not to tell , whatever came of [her]73-ellinor silence .
