It had the desired effect . [Ellinor]73-ellinor laid down [her]73-ellinor brush , and covered [her]73-ellinor face with [her]73-ellinor hand . After a pause , [she]73-ellinor turned towards [him]1488-you and said : " [I]73-ellinor will tell [you]1488-you this ; and more [you]1488-you must not ask [me]73-ellinor . [I]73-ellinor know [you]1488-you are as safe as can be . [I]73-ellinor am [the girl]527-the girl , [you]1488-you are [the lover]2896-the lover , and possible shame hangs over [[my]73-ellinor father]2646-my father , if something -- oh , so dreadful "[73-ellinor] ( here [she]73-ellinor blanched ) , " but not so very much [his]2646-my father fault , is ever found out . "[73-ellinor] Though this was nothing more than [he]1488-you expected , though [Ralph]81-mr. corbet thought that [he]81-mr. corbet was aware what the dreadful something might be , yet , when it was acknowledged in words , [his]81-mr. corbet heart contracted , and for a moment [he]81-mr. corbet forgot the intent , wistful , beautiful face , creeping close to [his]1488-you to read [his]1488-you expression aright . But after that [his]81-mr. corbet presence of mind came in aid . [He]81-mr. corbet took [her]73-ellinor in [his]81-mr. corbet arms and kissed [her]73-ellinor ; murmuring fond words of sympathy , and promises of faith , nay , even of greater love than before , since greater need [she]73-ellinor might have of that love . But somehow [he]81-mr. corbet was glad when the dressing - bell rang , and in the solitude of [[his]81-mr. corbet own room]1158-his own room [he]81-mr. corbet could reflect on what [he]81-mr. corbet had heard ; for the intelligence had been a great shock to [him]81-mr. corbet , although [he]81-mr. corbet had fancied that [his]81-mr. corbet morning 's inquiries had prepared [him]81-mr. corbet for it . CHAPTER IX . [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet found it a very difficult thing to keep down [his]81-mr. corbet curiosity during the next few days . It was a miserable thing to have [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's unspoken secret severing them like a phantom . But [he]81-mr. corbet had given [her]73-ellinor [his]81-mr. corbet word that [he]81-mr. corbet would make no further inquiries from [her]73-ellinor . Indeed , [he]81-mr. corbet thought [he]81-mr. corbet could well enough make out the outline of past events ; still , there was too much left to conjecture for [his]81-mr. corbet mind not to be always busy on the subject . [He]81-mr. corbet felt inclined to probe [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins in [their]1490-their after- dinner conversation , in which [[his]81-mr. corbet host]1421-his host was frank and lax enough on many subjects . But once touch on the name of [Dunster]84-mr. dunster and [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins sank into a kind of suspicious depression of spirits ; talking little , and with evident caution ; and from time to time shooting furtive glances at [[his]81-mr. corbet interlocutor]1492-his interlocutor 's face . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was resolutely impervious to any attempts of [his]81-mr. corbet to bring [his]81-mr. corbet conversation with [her]73-ellinor back to the subject which more and more engrossed [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's mind . [She]73-ellinor had done [her]73-ellinor duty , as [she]73-ellinor understood it ; and had received assurances which [she]73-ellinor was only too glad to believe fondly with all the tender faith of [her]73-ellinor heart . Whatever came to pass , [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's love would still be [hers]73-ellinor ; nor was [he]81-mr. corbet unwarned of what might come to pass in some dread future day . So [she]73-ellinor shut [her]73-ellinor eyes to what might be in store for [her]73-ellinor ( and , after all , the chances were immeasurably in [her]73-ellinor favour ) ; and [she]73-ellinor bent [herself]73-ellinor with [her]73-ellinor whole strength into enjoying the present . Day by day [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's spirits flagged . [He]81-mr. corbet was , however , so generally uniform in the tenor of [his]81-mr. corbet talk -- never very merry , and always avoiding any subject that might call out deep feeling either on [his]81-mr. corbet own or [any one else]1493-any one else 's part , that [few people]1494-few people were aware of [his]81-mr. corbet changes of mood . [Ellinor]73-ellinor felt them , though [she]73-ellinor would not acknowledge [them]1495-them : it was bringing [her]73-ellinor too much face to face with the great terror of [her]73-ellinor life . One morning [he]81-mr. corbet announced the fact of [[his]81-mr. corbet brother]1496-his brother 's approaching marriage ; the wedding was hastened on account of some impending event in [[the duke]1497-the duke 's family]1498-the duke 's family ; and the home letter [he]81-mr. corbet had received that day was to bid [his]81-mr. corbet presence at [Stokely Castle]28-stokely castle , and also to desire [him]81-mr. corbet to be at [home]230-home by a certain time not very distant , in order to look over the requisite legal papers , and to give [his]81-mr. corbet assent to some of them . [He]81-mr. corbet gave many reasons why this unlooked - for departure of [his]81-mr. corbet was absolutely necessary ; but [no one]385-no one doubted it . [He]81-mr. corbet need not have alleged such reiterated excuses . The truth was , [he]81-mr. corbet was restrained and uncomfortable at [Ford Bank]15-ford bank ever since [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's confidence . [He]81-mr. corbet could not rightly calculate on the most desirable course for [his]81-mr. corbet own interests , while [his]81-mr. corbet love for [her]73-ellinor was constantly being renewed by [her]73-ellinor sweet presence . Away from [her]73-ellinor , [he]81-mr. corbet could judge more wisely . Nor did [he]81-mr. corbet allege any false reasons for [his]81-mr. corbet departure ; but the sense of relief to [himself]81-mr. corbet was so great at [his]81-mr. corbet recall [home]230-home , that [he]81-mr. corbet was afraid of having it perceived by [others]2873-others ; and so took the very way which , if [others]2873-others had been as penetrating as [himself]81-mr. corbet , would have betrayed [him]81-mr. corbet . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , too , had begun to feel the restraint of [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's grave watchful presence . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was not strong enough to be married ; nor was the promised money forthcoming if [she]73-ellinor had been . And to have [a fellow]1504-a fellow dawdling about [the house]761-the house all day , sauntering into [the flower - garden]713-the flower - garden , peering about everywhere , and having a kind of right to put all manner of unexpected questions , was anything but agreeable . It was only [Ellinor]73-ellinor that clung to [his]81-mr. corbet presence -- clung as though some shadow of what might happen before [they]1507-they met again had fallen on [her]73-ellinor spirit . As soon as [he]81-mr. corbet had left [the house]761-the house [she]73-ellinor flew up to [a spare bedroom]1509-a spare bedroom window , to watch for the last glimpse of the fly which was taking [him]81-mr. corbet into [the town]277-the town . And then [she]73-ellinor kissed the part of the pane on which [his]81-mr. corbet figure , waving an arm out of the carriage window , had last appeared ; and went down slowly to gather together all the things [he]81-mr. corbet had last touched -- the pen [he]81-mr. corbet had mended , the flower [he]81-mr. corbet had played with , and to lock them up in the little quaint cabinet that had held [her]73-ellinor treasures since [she]73-ellinor was [a tiny child]1511-a tiny child . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro was , perhaps , very wise in proposing the translation of a difficult part of [Dante]115-dante for a distraction to [Ellinor]73-ellinor . [The girl]527-the girl went meekly , if reluctantly , to the task set [her]527-the girl by [[her]527-the girl good governess]1513-her good governess , and by- and - by [her]527-the girl mind became braced by the exertion . [[Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's people]1514-ralph 's people were not very slow in discovering that something had not gone on quite smoothly with [him]81-mr. corbet at [Ford Bank]15-ford bank . [They]1514-ralph 's people knew [his]81-mr. corbet ways and looks with family intuition , and could easily be certain thus far . But not even [[his]81-mr. corbet mother]269-his mother 's skilfulest wiles , nor [[his]81-mr. corbet favourite sister]1516-his favourite sister 's coaxing , could obtain a word or a hint ; and when [[his]81-mr. corbet father]222-his father , [[the squire]570-the squire , who had heard the opinions of [the female part of [the family on this head]1521-the family on this head]1520-the female part of the family on this head]1519-the squire , who had heard the opinions of the female part of the family on this head , began , in [his]81-mr. corbet honest blustering way , in [their]1514-ralph 's people _ tete - a - tetes _ after dinner , to hope that [Ralph]81-mr. corbet was thinking better than to run [his]81-mr. corbet head into [[that confounded Hamley attorney]1522-that confounded hamley attorney 's noose]1523-that confounded hamley attorney 's noose , [Ralph]81-mr. corbet gravely required [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet to explain [his]81-mr. corbet meaning , which [he]81-mr. corbet professed not to understand so worded . And when [the squire]570-the squire had , with much perplexity , put it into the plain terms of hoping that [[his]570-the squire son]239-his son was thinking of breaking off [his]239-his son engagement to [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins , [Ralph]81-mr. corbet coolly asked [him]239-his son if [he]239-his son was aware that , in that case , [he]239-his son should lose all title to being [a man of honour]1526-a man of honour , and might have an action brought against [him]239-his son for breach of promise ? Yet not the less for all this was the idea in [his]81-mr. corbet mind as a future possibility . Before very long [the Corbet family]1527-the corbet family moved _ en masse _ to [Stokely Castle]28-stokely castle for the wedding . Of course , [Ralph]81-mr. corbet associated on equal terms with [the magnates of [the county]311-the county]1528-the magnates of the county , who were [the employers of [[Ellinor]73-ellinor 's father]908-ellinor 's father]1530-the employers of ellinor 's father , and spoke of [him]81-mr. corbet always as " [Wilkins]73-ellinor , "[1528-the magnates of the county] just as [they]1528-the magnates of the county spoke of [the butler]1532-the butler as " [Simmons]129-simmons . "[1532-the butler] Here , too , among [a class of men high above local gossip]1533-a class of men high above local gossip , and thus unaware of [his]81-mr. corbet engagement , [he]81-mr. corbet learnt the popular opinion respecting [[his]81-mr. corbet future father - in - law]1428-his future father - in - law ; an opinion not entirely respectful , though intermingled with a good deal of personal liking . " [Poor Wilkins]130-poor wilkins , "[1528-the magnates of the county] as [they]1528-the magnates of the county called [him]81-mr. corbet , " was sadly extravagant for [a man in [his]81-mr. corbet position]2898-a man in his position ; had no right to spend money , and act as if [he]81-mr. corbet were [a man of independent fortune]2899-a man of independent fortune . "[1528-the magnates of the county] [His]81-mr. corbet habits of life were criticised ; and pity , not free from blame , was bestowed upon [him]81-mr. corbet for the losses [he]81-mr. corbet had sustained from [[his]81-mr. corbet late clerk]1535-his late clerk 's disappearance and defalcation . But what could be expected if [a man]286-a man did not choose to attend to [his]286-a man own business ? The wedding went by , as grand weddings do , without let or hindrance , according to the approved pattern . [A Cabinet minister]1537-a cabinet minister honoured it with [his]1537-a cabinet minister presence , and , being [a distant relation of [the Brabants]131-the brabants]1538-a distant relation of the brabants , remained for a few days after the grand occasion . During this time [he]1537-a cabinet minister became rather intimate with [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet ; many of [their]1539-they tastes were in common . [Ralph]81-mr. corbet took a great interest in the manner of working out political questions ; in the balance and state of parties ; and had the right appreciation of the exact qualities on which [the minister]1540-the minister piqued [himself]1540-the minister . In return , [the latter]271-the latter was always on the look - out for [promising young men , who , either by [their]1542-promising young men , who , either by their capability of speech - making or article - writing , might advance the views of his party capability of speech - making or article - writing , might advance the views of [[his]81-mr. corbet party]1543-his party]1542-promising young men , who , either by their capability of speech - making or article - writing , might advance the views of his party . Recognising the powers [he]1537-a cabinet minister most valued in [Ralph]81-mr. corbet , [he]1537-a cabinet minister spared no pains to attach [him]81-mr. corbet to [his]1537-a cabinet minister own political set . When [they]1539-they separated , it was with the full understanding that [they]1539-they were to see a good deal of each other in [London]4-london . The holiday [Ralph]81-mr. corbet allowed [himself]81-mr. corbet was passing rapidly away ; but , before [he]81-mr. corbet returned to [[his]81-mr. corbet chambers]1544-his chambers and [his]81-mr. corbet hard work , [he]81-mr. corbet had promised to spend a few more days with [Ellinor]73-ellinor ; and it suited [him]81-mr. corbet to go straight from [[the duke]1497-the duke 's to [Ford Bank]15-ford bank]1546-the duke 's to ford bank . [He]81-mr. corbet left [the castle]1547-the castle soon after breakfast -- the luxurious , elegant breakfast , served by [domestics who performed [their]1548-domestics who performed their work with the accuracy and perfection of machines work with the accuracy and perfection of machines]1548-domestics who performed their work with the accuracy and perfection of machines . [He]81-mr. corbet arrived at [Ford Bank]15-ford bank before [the man - servant]1549-the man - servant had quite finished the dirtier part of [his]81-mr. corbet morning 's work , and [he]81-mr. corbet came to the glass - door in [his]81-mr. corbet striped cotton jacket , a little soiled , and rolling up [his]81-mr. corbet working apron . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was not yet strong enough to get up and go out and gather flowers for [the rooms]1550-the rooms , so those left from yesterday were rather faded ; in short , the contrast from entire completeness and exquisite freshness of arrangement struck forcibly upon [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's perceptions , which were critical rather than appreciative ; and , as [his]81-mr. corbet affections were always subdued to [his]81-mr. corbet intellect , [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's lovely face and graceful figure flying to meet [him]81-mr. corbet did not gain [his]81-mr. corbet full approval , because [her]73-ellinor hair was dressed in an old- fashioned way , [her]73-ellinor waist was either too long or too short , [her]73-ellinor sleeves too full or too tight for the standard of fashion to which [his]81-mr. corbet eye had been accustomed while scanning [the bridesmaids]1551-the bridesmaids and [various highborn ladies at [Stokely Castle]28-stokely castle]1552-various highborn ladies at stokely castle . But , as [he]81-mr. corbet had always piqued [himself]81-mr. corbet upon being able to put on one side all superficial worldliness in [his]81-mr. corbet chase after power , it did not do for [him]81-mr. corbet to shrink from seeing and facing the incompleteness of moderate means . Only marriage upon moderate means was gradually becoming more distasteful to [him]81-mr. corbet . Nor did [his]81-mr. corbet subsequent intercourse with [Lord Bolton]132-lord bolton , [the Cabinet minister before mentioned]1553-the cabinet minister before mentioned , tend to reconcile [him]81-mr. corbet to early matrimony . At [[Lord Bolton]132-lord bolton 's house]1554-lord bolton 's house [he]81-mr. corbet met polished and intellectual society , and all that smoothness in ministering to the lower wants in eating and drinking which seems to provide that the right thing shall always be at the right place at the right time , so that the want of it shall never impede for an instant the feast of wit or reason ; while , if [he]81-mr. corbet went to [the houses of [[his]81-mr. corbet friends]1556-his friends]1555-the houses of his friends , [men of the same college and standing]1557-men of the same college and standing as [himself]81-mr. corbet , [who had been seduced into early marriages]1558-who had been seduced into early marriages , [he]81-mr. corbet was uncomfortably aware of numerous inconsistencies and hitches in [their]1559-their _ menages _ . Besides , the idea of the possible disgrace that might befall [the family with which [he]81-mr. corbet thought of allying [himself]81-mr. corbet]1560-the family with which he thought of allying himself haunted [him]81-mr. corbet with the tenacity and also with the exaggeration of a nightmare , whenever [he]81-mr. corbet had overworked [himself]81-mr. corbet in [his]81-mr. corbet search after available and profitable knowledge , or had a fit of indigestion after the exquisite dinners [he]81-mr. corbet was learning so well to appreciate . [Christmas]133-christmas was , of course , to be devoted to [[his]81-mr. corbet own family]1010-his own family ; it was an unavoidable necessity , as [he]81-mr. corbet told [Ellinor]73-ellinor , while , in reality , [he]81-mr. corbet was beginning to find absence from [[his]81-mr. corbet betrothed]1562-his betrothed something of a relief . Yet the wranglings and folly of [[his]81-mr. corbet home]1563-his home , even blessed by the presence of [a Lady Maria]2726-a lady maria , made [him]81-mr. corbet look forward to Easter at [Ford Bank]15-ford bank with something of the old pleasure . [Ellinor]73-ellinor , with the fine tact which love gives , had discovered [his]81-mr. corbet annoyance at various little incongruities in [the household]1261-the household at the time of [his]81-mr. corbet second visit in the previous autumn , and had laboured to make all as perfect as [she]73-ellinor could before [his]81-mr. corbet return . But [she]73-ellinor had much to struggle against . For the first time in [her]73-ellinor life there was a great want of ready money ; [she]73-ellinor could scarcely obtain the servants ' wages ; and the bill for the spring seeds was a heavy weight on [her]73-ellinor conscience . For [Miss Monro]77-miss monro 's methodical habits had taught [her]77-miss monro pupil great exactitude as to all money matters . Then [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's temper had become very uncertain . [He]398-her father avoided being alone with [her]73-ellinor whenever [he]398-her father possibly could ; and the consciousness of this , and of the terrible mutual secret which was the cause of this estrangement , were the reasons why [Ellinor]73-ellinor never recovered [her]73-ellinor pretty youthful bloom after [her]73-ellinor illness . Of course it was to this that [the outside world]1567-the outside world attributed [her]73-ellinor changed appearance . [They]1568-they would shake [their]1568-they heads and say , " Ah , [poor Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins ! What [a lovely creature]2900-a lovely creature [she]73-ellinor was before that fever ! "[1568-they] But youth is youth , and will assert itself in a certain elasticity of body and spirits ; and at times [Ellinor]73-ellinor forgot that fearful night for several hours together . Even when [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's averted eye brought it all once more before [her]73-ellinor , [she]73-ellinor had learnt to form excuses and palliations , and to regard [Mr. Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's death as only the consequence of an unfortunate accident . But [she]73-ellinor tried to put the miserable remembrance entirely out of [her]73-ellinor mind ; to go on from day to day thinking only of the day , and how to arrange it so as to cause the least irritation to [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father . [She]73-ellinor would so gladly have spoken to [him]398-her father on the one subject which overshadowed all [their]1571-their intercourse ; [she]73-ellinor fancied that by speaking [she]73-ellinor might have been able to banish the phantom , or reduce its terror to what [she]73-ellinor believed to be the due proportion . But [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father was evidently determined to show that [he]398-her father was never more to be spoken to on that subject ; and all [she]73-ellinor could do was to follow [his]398-her father lead on the rare occasions that [they]1571-their fell into something like the old confidential intercourse . As yet , to [her]73-ellinor , [he]398-her father had never given way to anger ; but before [her]73-ellinor [he]398-her father had often spoken in a manner which both pained and terrified [her]73-ellinor . Sometimes [his]398-her father eye in the midst of [his]398-her father passion caught on [her]73-ellinor face of affright and dismay , and then [he]398-her father would stop , and make such an effort to control [himself]398-her father as sometimes ended in tears . [Ellinor]73-ellinor did not understand that both these phases were owing to [his]398-her father increasing habit of drinking more than [he]398-her father ought to have done . [She]73-ellinor set them down as the direct effects of a sorely burdened conscience ; and strove more and more to plan for [his]398-her father daily life at [home]230-home , how it should go on with oiled wheels , neither a jerk nor a jar . It was no wonder [she]73-ellinor looked wistful , and careworn , and old . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro was [her]73-ellinor great comfort ; the total unconsciousness on [that lady]1574-that lady 's part of anything below the surface , and yet [her]73-ellinor full and delicate recognition of all the little daily cares and trials , made [her]73-ellinor sympathy most valuable to [Ellinor]73-ellinor , while there was no need to fear that it would ever give [Miss Monro]77-miss monro that power of seeing into the heart of things which it frequently confers upon [imaginative people]1575-imaginative people , who are deeply attached to [some one in sorrow]1576-some one in sorrow . There was a strong bond between [Ellinor]73-ellinor and [Dixon]86-dixon , although [they]1577-they scarcely ever exchanged a word save on the most common - place subjects ; but [their]1577-they silence was based on different feelings from that which separated [Ellinor]73-ellinor from [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father . [Ellinor]73-ellinor and [Dixon]86-dixon could not speak freely , because [their]1577-they hearts were full of pity for [the faulty man whom [they]1577-they both loved so well , and tried so hard to respect]1579-the faulty man whom they both loved so well , and tried so hard to respect . This was the state of [the household to which [Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet came down at [Easter]29-easter]1580-the household to which ralph corbet came down at easter . [He]81-mr. corbet might have been known in [London]4-london as [a brilliant diner - out]1581-a brilliant diner - out by this time ; but [he]81-mr. corbet could not afford to throw [his]81-mr. corbet life away in fireworks ; [he]81-mr. corbet calculated [his]81-mr. corbet forces , and condensed [their]1582-their power as much as might be , only visiting where [he]81-mr. corbet was likely to meet [men who could help in [his]81-mr. corbet future career]1583-men who could help in his future career . [He]81-mr. corbet had been invited to spend the Easter vacation at [a certain country house which would be full of such human stepping - stones]1584-a certain country house which would be full of such human stepping - stones ; and [he]81-mr. corbet declined in order to keep [his]81-mr. corbet word to [Ellinor]73-ellinor , and go to [Ford Bank]15-ford bank . But [he]81-mr. corbet could not help looking upon [himself]81-mr. corbet a little in the light of [a martyr to duty]1585-a martyr to duty ; and perhaps this view of [his]81-mr. corbet own merits made [him]81-mr. corbet chafe under [[his]81-mr. corbet future father]1586-his future father - in - law 's irritability of manner , which now showed itself even to [him]81-mr. corbet . [He]81-mr. corbet found [himself]81-mr. corbet distinctly regretting that [he]81-mr. corbet had suffered [himself]81-mr. corbet to be engaged so early in life ; and having become conscious of the temptation and not having repelled it at once , of course it returned and returned , and gradually obtained the mastery over [him]81-mr. corbet . What was to be gained by keeping to [his]81-mr. corbet engagement with [Ellinor]73-ellinor ? [He]81-mr. corbet should have [a delicate wife to look after]1587-a delicate wife to look after , and even more than the common additional expenses of married life . [He]81-mr. corbet should have [a father - in - law whose character at best had had only a local and provincial respectability , which it was now daily losing by habits which were both sensual and vulgarising]1588-a father - in - law whose character at best had had only a local and provincial respectability , which it was now daily losing by habits which were both sensual and vulgarising ; [a man , too , who was strangely changing from joyous geniality into moody surliness]1589-a man , too , who was strangely changing from joyous geniality into moody surliness . Besides , [he]81-mr. corbet doubted if , in the evident change in the prosperity of [the family]2680-the family , the fortune to be paid down on the occasion of [his]81-mr. corbet marriage to [Ellinor]73-ellinor could be forthcoming . And above all , and around all , there hovered the shadow of some unrevealed disgrace , which might come to light at any time and involve [him]81-mr. corbet in it . [He]81-mr. corbet thought [he]81-mr. corbet had pretty well ascertained the nature of this possible shame , and had little doubt it would turn out to be that [Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's disappearance , to [America]25-america or elsewhere , had been an arranged plan with [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins . Although [Mr. Ralph Corbet]81-mr. corbet was capable of suspecting [him]81-mr. corbet of this mean crime ( so far removed from the impulsive commission of the past sin which was dragging [him]81-mr. corbet daily lower and lower down ) , it was of a kind that was peculiarly distasteful to [the acute lawyer]1591-the acute lawyer , who foresaw how such base conduct would taint all whose names were ever mentioned , even by chance , in connection with it . [He]81-mr. corbet used to lie miserably tossing on [his]81-mr. corbet sleepless bed , turning over these things in the night season . [He]81-mr. corbet was tormented by all these thoughts ; [he]81-mr. corbet would bitterly regret the past events that connected [him]81-mr. corbet with [Ellinor]73-ellinor , from the day when [he]81-mr. corbet first came to read with [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness up to the present time . But when [he]81-mr. corbet came down in the morning , and saw [the faded Ellinor]73-ellinor flash into momentary beauty at [his]81-mr. corbet entrance into [the dining - room]745-the dining - room , and when [she]73-ellinor blushingly drew near with the one single flower freshly gathered , which it had been [her]73-ellinor custom to place in [his]81-mr. corbet button - hole when [he]81-mr. corbet came down to breakfast , [he]81-mr. corbet felt as if [his]81-mr. corbet better self was stronger than temptation , and as if [he]81-mr. corbet must be [an honest man]1593-an honest man and [honourable lover]1594-honourable lover , even against [his]81-mr. corbet wish . As the day wore on the temptation gathered strength . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins came down , and while [he]66-mr. wilkins was on the scene [Ellinor]73-ellinor seemed always engrossed by [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , who apparently cared little enough for all [her]73-ellinor attentions . Then there was a complaining of the food , which did not suit the sickly palate of [a man who had drunk hard the night before]1596-a man who had drunk hard the night before ; and possibly these complaints were extended to [the servants]1099-the servants , and [their]1099-the servants incompleteness or incapacity was thus brought prominently before the eyes of [Ralph]81-mr. corbet , who would have [preferred to eat a dry crust in silence , or to have gone without breakfast]1598-preferred to eat a dry crust in silence , or to have gone without breakfast altogether , if [he]81-mr. corbet could have had intellectual conversation of some high order , to having the greatest dainties with the knowledge of the care required in [their]1099-the servants preparation thus coarsely discussed before [him]81-mr. corbet . By the time such breakfasts were finished , [Ellinor]73-ellinor looked thirty , and [her]73-ellinor spirits were gone for the day . It had become difficult for [Ralph]81-mr. corbet to contract [his]81-mr. corbet mind to [her]73-ellinor small domestic interests , and [she]73-ellinor had little else to talk to [him]81-mr. corbet about , now that [he]81-mr. corbet responded but curtly to all [her]73-ellinor questions about [himself]81-mr. corbet , and was weary of professing a love which [he]81-mr. corbet was ceasing to feel , in all the passionate nothings which usually make up so much of [lovers]1049-lovers ' talk . The books [she]73-ellinor had been reading were old classics , whose place in literature no longer admitted of keen discussion ; [the poor whom [she]73-ellinor cared for]1600-the poor whom she cared for were all very well in [their]1600-the poor whom she cared for way ; and , if [they]1600-the poor whom she cared for could have been brought in to illustrate a theory , hearing about them might have been of some use ; but , as it was , it was simply tiresome to hear day after day of [Betty Palmer]134-betty palmer 's rheumatism and [[Mrs. Kay]135-mrs. kay 's baby]1601-mrs. kay 's baby 's fits . There was no talking politics with [her]73-ellinor , because [she]73-ellinor was so ignorant that [she]73-ellinor always agreed with everything [he]81-mr. corbet said . [He]81-mr. corbet even grew to find luncheon and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro not unpleasant varieties to [his]81-mr. corbet monotonous _ tete - a - tetes _ . Then came the walk , generally to [the town]277-the town to fetch [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins from [[his]66-mr. wilkins office]628-his office ; and once or twice it was pretty evident how [he]66-mr. wilkins had been employing [his]66-mr. wilkins hours . One day in particular [his]81-mr. corbet walk was so unsteady and [his]81-mr. corbet speech so thick , that [Ralph]81-mr. corbet could only wonder how it was that [Ellinor]73-ellinor did not perceive the cause ; but [she]73-ellinor was too openly anxious about the headache of which [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father complained to have been at all aware of the previous self - indulgence which must have brought it on . This very afternoon , as ill - luck would have it , [the Duke of [Hinton]30-hinton]1605-the duke of hinton and [a gentleman whom [Ralph]81-mr. corbet had met in [town]2661-town at [Lord Bolton]132-lord bolton 's]1606-a gentleman whom ralph had met in town at lord bolton 's rode by , and recognised [him]81-mr. corbet ; saw [Ralph]81-mr. corbet supporting [a tipsy man with such quiet friendly interest as must show all passers - by]1608-a tipsy man with such quiet friendly interest as must show all passers - by that [they]1609-they were [previous friends]1610-previous friends . [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet chafed and fumed inwardly all the way [home]230-home after this unfortunate occurrence ; [he]81-mr. corbet was in a thoroughly evil temper before [they]1612-they reached [Ford Bank]15-ford bank , but [he]81-mr. corbet had too much self - command to let this be very apparent . [He]81-mr. corbet turned into [the shrubbery paths]1613-the shrubbery paths , leaving [Ellinor]73-ellinor to take [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father into the quietness of [[his]398-her father own room]1158-his own room , there to lie down and shake off [his]398-her father headache . [Ralph]81-mr. corbet walked along , ruminating in gloomy mood as to what was to be done ; how [he]81-mr. corbet could best extricate [himself]81-mr. corbet from the miserable relation in which [he]81-mr. corbet had placed [himself]81-mr. corbet by giving way to impulse . Almost before [he]81-mr. corbet was aware , a little hand stole within [his]81-mr. corbet folded arms , and [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's sweet sad eyes looked into [his]81-mr. corbet . " [I]73-ellinor have put [papa]2614-papa down for an hour 's rest before dinner , "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor . " [His]2614-papa head seems to ache terribly . "[73-ellinor] [Ralph]81-mr. corbet was silent and unsympathising , trying to nerve [himself]81-mr. corbet up to be disagreeable , but finding it difficult in the face of such sweet trust . "[81-mr. corbet] [He]81-mr. corbet was startled beyond [his]81-mr. corbet power of self - control by the instantaneous change in [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins which [his]81-mr. corbet question produced . While [he]81-mr. corbet hesitated how to begin again on the subject , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins pulled the bottle of brandy to [himself]66-mr. wilkins and filled [his]66-mr. wilkins glass again , tossing off the spirit as if it had been water . Then [he]66-mr. wilkins tried to look [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet full in the face , with a stare as pertinacious as [he]66-mr. wilkins could make it , but very different from the keen observant gaze which was trying to read [him]81-mr. corbet through . " What were [we]590-both talking about ? "[81-mr. corbet] said [Ralph]81-mr. corbet , starting to [his]81-mr. corbet feet with real passion at being so addressed by " [Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins [the attorney]307-the attorney . "[66-mr. wilkins] " Yes , "[271-the latter] continued [the latter]271-the latter , " [I]271-the latter 'll manage [my]271-the latter own affairs , and allow of no meddling and no questioning . [I]271-the latter said so once before , and [I]271-the latter was not minded and bad came of it ; and now [I]271-the latter say it again . And if [you]81-mr. corbet 're to come here and put impertinent questions , and stare at [me]271-the latter as [you]81-mr. corbet 've been doing this half - hour past , why , the sooner [you]81-mr. corbet leave [this house]2805-this house the better ! "[271-the latter] [Ralph]81-mr. corbet half turned to take [him]66-mr. wilkins at [his]81-mr. corbet word , and go at once ; but then [he]81-mr. corbet " gave [Ellinor]73-ellinor another chance , "[81-mr. corbet] as [he]81-mr. corbet worded it in [his]81-mr. corbet thoughts ; but it was in no spirit of conciliation that [he]81-mr. corbet said : " [You]81-mr. corbet 've taken too much of that stuff , [sir]2656-sir . [You]81-mr. corbet do n't know what [you]81-mr. corbet 're saying . If [you]81-mr. corbet did , [I]81-mr. corbet should leave [[your]81-mr. corbet house]2918-your house at once , never to return . "[81-mr. corbet] " [You]66-mr. wilkins think so , do [you]66-mr. wilkins ? "[66-mr. wilkins] said [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , trying to stand up , and look dignified and sober . " [I]66-mr. wilkins say , [sir]2656-sir , that if [you]2656-sir ever venture again to talk and look as [you]2656-sir have done to - night , why , [sir]2656-sir , [I]66-mr. wilkins will ring the bell and have [you]2656-sir shown the door by [[my]66-mr. wilkins servants]2921-my servants . So now [you]2656-sir 're warned , [[my]66-mr. wilkins fine fellow]2922-my fine fellow ! "[66-mr. wilkins] [He]66-mr. wilkins sat down , laughing a foolish tipsy laugh of triumph . In another minute [his]66-mr. wilkins arm was held firmly but gently by [Ralph]81-mr. corbet . " Listen , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins , "[66-mr. wilkins] [he]66-mr. wilkins said , in a low hoarse voice . " [You]66-mr. wilkins shall never have to say to [me]66-mr. wilkins twice what [you]66-mr. wilkins have said to - night . Henceforward [we]2923-we are as [strangers to each other]2924-strangers to each other . As to [Ellinor"--his]136-ellinor"--his[66-mr. wilkins] tones softened a little , and [he]66-mr. wilkins sighed in spite of himself--"I do not think [we]2923-we should have been happy . [I]66-mr. wilkins believe [our]2923-we engagement was formed when [we]2923-we were too young to know [our]2923-we own minds , but [I]66-mr. wilkins would have done [my]66-mr. wilkins duty and kept to [my]66-mr. wilkins word ; but [you]66-mr. wilkins , [sir]2656-sir , have [yourself]66-mr. wilkins severed the connection between [us]2923-we by [your]66-mr. wilkins insolence to - night . [I]66-mr. wilkins , to be turned out of [[your]66-mr. wilkins house]2918-your house by [[your]66-mr. wilkins servants!--I]2927-your servants!--i , [a Corbet of [Westley]32-westley , who would not submit to such threats from [a peer of the realm]2929-a peer of the realm]2928-a corbet of westley , who would not submit to such threats from a peer of the realm , let [him]2928-a corbet of westley , who would not submit to such threats from a peer of the realm be ever so drunk ! "[66-mr. wilkins] [He]1642-he was out of [the room]479-the room , almost out of [the house]761-the house , before [he]1642-he had spoken the last words . [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins sat still , first fiercely angry , then astonished , and lastly dismayed into sobriety . " [Corbet]81-mr. corbet , [Corbet]81-mr. corbet ! [Ralph]81-mr. corbet ! "[1642-he] [he]1642-he called in vain ; then [he]1642-he got up and went to the door , opened it , looked into [the fully- lighted hall]1645-the fully- lighted hall ; all was so quiet there that [he]1642-he could hear the quiet voices of [the women in the drawing - room]1646-the women in the drawing - room talking together . [He]1642-he thought for a moment , went to the hat - stand , and missed [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's low - crowned straw hat . Then [he]1642-he sat down once more in [the dining - room]745-the dining - room , and endeavoured to make out exactly what had passed ; but [he]1642-he could not believe that [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet had come to any enduring or final resolution to break off [his]81-mr. corbet engagement , and [he]1642-he had almost reasoned [himself]1642-he back into [his]1642-he former state of indignation at impertinence and injury , when [Ellinor]73-ellinor came in , pale , hurried , and anxious . " [Papa]109-papa ! what does this mean ? "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor , putting an open note into [his]1642-he hand . [He]1642-he took up [his]1642-he glasses , but [his]1642-he hand shook so that [he]1642-he could hardly read . The note was from [the Parsonage]581-the parsonage , to [Ellinor]73-ellinor ; only three lines sent by [[Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness 's servant]1649-mr. ness 's servant , who had come to fetch [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet 's things . [He]1642-he had written three lines with some consideration for [Ellinor]73-ellinor , even when [he]1642-he was in [his]1642-he first flush of anger against [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , and it must be confessed of relief at [his]1642-he own freedom , thus brought about by the act of another , and not of [his]1642-he own working out , which partly saved [his]1642-he conscience . The note ran thus : " [DEAR ELLINOR,--Words]137-dear ellinor,--words have passed between [[your]73-ellinor father]2658-your father and [me]73-ellinor which have obliged [me]73-ellinor to leave [[his]2658-your father house]552-his house , [I]73-ellinor fear , never to return to [it]552-his house . [I]73-ellinor will write more fully to - morrow . But do not grieve too much , for [I]73-ellinor am not , and never have been , good enough for [you]73-ellinor . God bless [you]73-ellinor , [[my]73-ellinor dearest]2932-my dearest [Nelly]111-nelly , though [I]73-ellinor call [you]73-ellinor so for the last time.--R. C. "[73-ellinor] " [Papa]109-papa , what is it ? "[73-ellinor] [Ellinor]73-ellinor cried , clasping [her]73-ellinor hands together , as [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father sat silent , vacantly gazing into the fire , after finishing the note . " [I]398-her father do n't know ! "[398-her father] said [he]398-her father , looking up at [her]73-ellinor piteously ; " it 's [the world]609-the world , [I]398-her father think . Everything goes wrong with [me]398-her father and [mine]398-her father : it went wrong before THAT night -- so it ca n't be that , can it , [Ellinor]73-ellinor ? "[398-her father] " Oh , [papa]2614-papa ! "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor , kneeling down by [him]398-her father , [her]73-ellinor face hidden on [his]398-her father breast . " [I]398-her father used to read of [Orestes]138-orestes and the Furies at [Eton]2-eton when [I]398-her father was [a boy]389-a boy , and [I]398-her father thought it was all a heathen fiction . [Poor little motherless girl]2936-poor little motherless girl ! " Did [you]73-ellinor love [him]398-her father so very dearly , [Nelly]111-nelly ? "[398-her father] [he]398-her father whispered , [his]398-her father cheek against [her]73-ellinor : " for somehow of late [he]398-her father has not seemed to [me]398-her father good enough for [thee]73-ellinor . [He]398-her father has got an inkling that something has gone wrong , and [he]398-her father was very inquisitive -- [I]398-her father may say [he]398-her father questioned [me]398-her father in a relentless kind of way . "[398-her father] " Oh , [papa]2614-papa , it was [my]398-her father doing , [I]398-her father 'm afraid . [I]398-her father said something long ago about possible disgrace . "[398-her father] [He]398-her father pushed [her]73-ellinor away ; [he]398-her father stood up , and looked at [her]73-ellinor with the eyes dilated , half in fear , half in fierceness , of an animal at bay ; [he]398-her father did not heed that [his]398-her father abrupt movement had almost thrown [her]73-ellinor prostrate on the ground . " [You]73-ellinor , [Ellinor]73-ellinor ! [You]73-ellinor -- [you--]73-ellinor "[398-her father] " Oh , [darling father]2938-darling father , listen ! " [I]73-ellinor said it , as if it were a possible case , of [some one else]2939-some one else -- last August -- but [he]398-her father immediately applied it , and asked [me]73-ellinor if it was over [me]73-ellinor the disgrace , or shame -- [I]73-ellinor forget the words [we]2940-we used -- hung ; and what could [I]73-ellinor say ? "[73-ellinor] " Anything -- anything to put [him]398-her father off the scent . God help [me]73-ellinor , [I]73-ellinor am [a lost man]2941-a lost man , betrayed by [[my]73-ellinor child]2777-my child ! "[73-ellinor] [Ellinor]73-ellinor let go [his]398-her father knees , and covered [her]73-ellinor face . [Every one]497-every one stabbed at that poor heart . "[73-ellinor] cried [Ellinor]73-ellinor , bursting into tears--"how very miserable ! It seems almost as if [God]119-god had forgotten to comfort [us]2946-we ! "[398-her father] " Hush ! hush ! "[398-her father] said [he]398-her father . " [[Your]466-child mother]2947-your mother said once [she]2947-your mother did so pray that [you]466-child might grow up religious ; [you]466-child must be religious , [child]466-child , because [she]2947-your mother prayed for it so often . [Poor Lettice]69-lettice , how glad [I]398-her father am that [you]466-child are dead ! "[398-her father] Here [he]398-her father began to cry like [a child]584-a child . [Ellinor]73-ellinor comforted [him]398-her father with kisses rather than words . [He]398-her father pushed [her]73-ellinor away , after a while , and said , sharply : " How much does [he]398-her father know ? [I]398-her father must make sure of that . ' "[398-her father] " That was all , [you]73-ellinor are sure ? "[398-her father] " Yes . [He]398-her father immediately applied the case to [me]398-her father -- to [ourselves]2952-ourselves . [You]1657-you quite believe [me]1656-he , do n't [you]1657-you , [papa]2614-papa ? "[1656-he] [He]1656-he pressed [her]1657-you to [him]1656-he , but did not speak . Then [he]1656-he took the note up again , and read it with as much care and attention as [he]1656-he could collect in [his]1656-he agitated state of mind . " [Nelly]111-nelly , "[1656-he] said [he]1656-he , at length , " [he]398-her father says true ; [he]398-her father is not good enough for [thee]111-nelly . [He]398-her father shrinks from the thought of the disgrace . [Thou]111-nelly must stand alone , and bear the sins of [[thy]111-nelly father]2954-thy father . "[1656-he] [He]1656-he shook so much as [he]1656-he said this , that [Ellinor]73-ellinor had to put any suffering of [her]73-ellinor own on one side , and try to confine [her]73-ellinor thoughts to the necessity of getting [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father immediately up to bed . [She]73-ellinor sat by [him]1656-he till [he]1656-he went to sleep , and [she]73-ellinor could leave [him]1656-he , and go to [[her]73-ellinor own room]1181-her own room , to forgetfulness and rest , if [she]73-ellinor could find those priceless blessings . CHAPTER X. [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet was so well known at [the Parsonage]581-the parsonage by [the two old servants]1661-the two old servants , that [he]81-mr. corbet had no difficulty , on reaching [it]581-the parsonage , after [his]81-mr. corbet departure from [Ford Bank]15-ford bank , in having [the spare bed - chamber]1662-the spare bed - chamber made ready for [him]81-mr. corbet , late as it was , and in the absence of [the master]2636-the master , who had taken a little holiday , now that Lent and [Easter]29-easter were over , for the purpose of fishing . While [[his]81-mr. corbet room]1664-his room was getting ready , [Ralph]81-mr. corbet sent for [his]81-mr. corbet clothes , and by the same messenger [he]81-mr. corbet despatched the little note to [Ellinor]73-ellinor . But there was the letter [he]81-mr. corbet had promised [her]73-ellinor in it still to be written ; and it was almost [his]81-mr. corbet night 's employment to say enough , yet not too much ; for , as [he]81-mr. corbet expressed it to [himself]81-mr. corbet , [he]81-mr. corbet was half way over [the stream]1665-the stream , and it would be folly to turn back , for [he]81-mr. corbet had given nearly as much pain both to [himself]81-mr. corbet and [Ellinor]73-ellinor by this time as [he]81-mr. corbet should do by making the separation final . Besides , after [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's speeches that evening -- but [he]81-mr. corbet was candid enough to acknowledge that , bad and offensive as they had been , if [they]1666-they had stood alone [they]1666-they might have been condoned . [His]81-mr. corbet letter ran as follows : " [DEAREST ELLINOR]73-ellinor , for dearest [you]73-ellinor are , and [I]81-mr. corbet think will ever be , [my]81-mr. corbet judgment has consented to a step which is giving [me]81-mr. corbet great pain , greater than [you]73-ellinor will readily believe . [I]81-mr. corbet am convinced that it is better that [we]2955-we should part ; for circumstances have occurred since [we]2955-we formed [our]2955-we engagement which , although [I]81-mr. corbet am unaware of [their]1666-they exact nature , [I]81-mr. corbet can see weigh heavily upon [you]73-ellinor , and have materially affected [[your]73-ellinor father]2658-your father 's behaviour . Nay , [I]81-mr. corbet think , after to - night , [I]81-mr. corbet may almost say have entirely altered [his]2658-your father feelings towards [me]81-mr. corbet . What these circumstances are [I]81-mr. corbet am ignorant , any further than that [I]81-mr. corbet know from [your]73-ellinor own admission , that they may lead to some future disgrace . Now , it may be [my]81-mr. corbet fault , it may be in [my]81-mr. corbet temperament , to be anxious , above all things earthly , to obtain and possess a high reputation . [I]81-mr. corbet can only say that it is so , and leave [you]73-ellinor to blame [me]81-mr. corbet for [my]81-mr. corbet weakness as much as [you]73-ellinor like . But anything that might come in between [me]81-mr. corbet and this object would , [I]81-mr. corbet own , be ill tolerated by [me]81-mr. corbet ; the very dread of such an obstacle intervening would paralyse [me]81-mr. corbet . [I]81-mr. corbet should become irritable , and , deep as [my]81-mr. corbet affection is , and always must be , towards [you]73-ellinor , [I]81-mr. corbet could not promise [you]73-ellinor a happy , peaceful life . [I]81-mr. corbet should be perpetually haunted by the idea of what might happen in the way of discovery and shame . [I]81-mr. corbet am the more convinced of this from [my]81-mr. corbet observation of [[your]73-ellinor father]2658-your father 's altered character -- an alteration which [I]81-mr. corbet trace back to the time when [I]81-mr. corbet conjecture that the secret affairs took place to which [you]73-ellinor have alluded . In short , it is for [your]73-ellinor sake , [[my]81-mr. corbet dear]2732-my dear [Ellinor]73-ellinor , even more than for [my]81-mr. corbet own , that [I]81-mr. corbet feel compelled to affix a final meaning to the words which [[your]73-ellinor father]2658-your father addressed to [me]81-mr. corbet last night , when [he]2658-your father desired [me]81-mr. corbet to leave [[his]2658-your father house]552-his house for ever . God bless [you]73-ellinor , [[my]81-mr. corbet Ellinor]2660-my ellinor , for the last time [[my]81-mr. corbet Ellinor]2660-my ellinor . Try to forget as soon as [you]73-ellinor can the unfortunate tie which has bound [you]73-ellinor for a time to one so unsuitable -- [I]81-mr. corbet believe [I]81-mr. corbet ought to say so unworthy of [you]73-ellinor -- as -- [RALPH CORBET]81-mr. corbet . "[81-mr. corbet] [Ellinor]73-ellinor was making breakfast when this letter was given [her]73-ellinor . According to the wo nt of [the servants of [the respective households of the Parsonage]1668-the respective households of the parsonage and [Ford Bank]15-ford bank]1667-the servants of the respective households of the parsonage and ford bank , [the man]1225-the man asked if there was any answer . It was only custom ; for [he]1225-the man had not been desired to do so . [Ellinor]73-ellinor went to the window to read [her]73-ellinor letter ; [the man]1225-the man waiting all the time respectfully for [her]73-ellinor reply . [She]73-ellinor went to the writing - table , and wrote : " It is all right -- quite right . [I]73-ellinor ought to have thought of it all last August . [I]73-ellinor do not think [you]1225-the man will forget [me]73-ellinor easily , but [I]73-ellinor entreat [you]1225-the man never at any future time to blame [yourself]1225-the man . [I]73-ellinor hope [you]1225-the man will be happy and successful . [I]73-ellinor suppose [I]73-ellinor must never write to [you]1225-the man again : but [I]73-ellinor shall always pray for [you]1225-the man . [Papa]109-papa was very sorry last night for having spoken angrily to [you]1225-the man . [You]1225-the man must forgive [him]109-papa -- there is great need for forgiveness in this world.--ELLINOR . "[73-ellinor] [She]73-ellinor kept putting down thought after thought , just to prolong the last pleasure of writing to [him]1671-him . [She]73-ellinor sealed the note , and gave it to [the man]1225-the man . Then [she]73-ellinor sat down and waited for [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , who had gone to bed on the previous night without awaiting [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's return from [the dining - room]745-the dining - room . " [I]77-miss monro am late , [[my]77-miss monro dear]2732-my dear , "[77-miss monro] said [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , on coming down , " but [I]77-miss monro have a bad headache , and [I]77-miss monro knew [you]2732-my dear had [a pleasant companion]2964-a pleasant companion . "[77-miss monro] Then , looking round , [she]73-ellinor perceived [Ralph]81-mr. corbet 's absence . " [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet not down yet ! "[73-ellinor] [she]73-ellinor exclaimed . And then [Ellinor]73-ellinor had to tell [her]77-miss monro the outline of the facts so soon likely to be made public ; that [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet and [she]73-ellinor had determined to break off [their]1674-their engagement ; and that [Mr. Corbet]81-mr. corbet had accordingly betaken [himself]81-mr. corbet to [the Parsonage]581-the parsonage ; and that [she]73-ellinor did not expect [him]81-mr. corbet to return to [Ford Bank]15-ford bank . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro 's astonishment was unbounded . [She]73-ellinor kept going over and over all the little circumstances [she]73-ellinor had noticed during the last visit , only on yesterday , in fact , which [she]73-ellinor could not reconcile with the notion that [the two]807-the two , apparently so much attached to [each other but a few hours before]1677-each other but a few hours before , were now to be for ever separated and estranged . [Ellinor]73-ellinor sickened under the torture ; which yet seemed like torture in a dream , from which there must come an awakening and a relief . [She]73-ellinor felt as if [she]73-ellinor could not hear any more ; yet there was more to hear . [[Her]73-ellinor father]398-her father , as it turned out , was very ill , and had been so all night long ; [he]398-her father had evidently had some kind of attack on the brain , whether apoplectic or paralytic it was for [the doctors]1679-the doctors to decide . In the hurry and anxiety of this day of misery succeeding to misery , [she]73-ellinor almost forgot to wonder whether [Ralph]81-mr. corbet were still at [the Parsonage]581-the parsonage -- still in [Hamley]1-hamley ; it was not till the evening visit of [the physician]1681-the physician that [she]73-ellinor learnt that [he]398-her father had been seen by [Dr. Moore]142-dr. moore as [he]398-her father was taking [his]398-her father place in the morning mail to [London]4-london . [Dr. Moore]142-dr. moore alluded to [his]398-her father name as to a thought that would cheer and comfort [the fragile girl]1682-the fragile girl during [her]1682-the fragile girl night- watch by [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's bedside . But [Miss Monro]77-miss monro stole out after [the doctor]348-the doctor to warn [him]348-the doctor off the subject for the future , crying bitterly over the forlorn position of [[her]77-miss monro darling]459-her darling as [she]77-miss monro spoke -- crying as [Ellinor]73-ellinor had never yet been able to cry : though all the time , in the pride of [her]77-miss monro sex , [she]77-miss monro was as endeavouring to persuade [the doctor]348-the doctor it was entirely [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's doing , and the wisest and best thing [she]77-miss monro could have done , as [he]398-her father was not good enough for [her]77-miss monro , only [a poor barrister struggling for a livelihood]1687-a poor barrister struggling for a livelihood . Like [many other kind - hearted people]1688-many other kind - hearted people , [she]77-miss monro fell into the blunder of lowering the moral character of those whom it is [their]1688-many other kind - hearted people greatest wish to exalt . But [Dr. Moore]142-dr. moore knew [Ellinor]73-ellinor too well to believe the whole of what [Miss Monro]77-miss monro said ; [she]77-miss monro would never act from interested motives , and was all the more likely to cling to [a man]286-a man because [he]286-a man was down and unsuccessful . No ! there had been a [lovers]1049-lovers ' quarrel ; and it could not have happened at a sadder time . Before the June roses were in full bloom , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins was dead . [He]66-mr. wilkins had left [[his]66-mr. wilkins daughter]520-his daughter to the guardianship of [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness by some will made years ago ; but [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness had caught a rheumatic fever with [his]80-mr. ness Easter fishings , and been unable to be moved [home]230-home from [the little Welsh inn where [he]80-mr. ness had been staying when [he]80-mr. ness was taken ill]1693-the little welsh inn where he had been staying when he was taken ill . Since [his]66-mr. wilkins last attack , [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's mind had been much affected ; [he]66-mr. wilkins often talked strangely and wildly ; but [he]66-mr. wilkins had rare intervals of quietness and full possession of [his]66-mr. wilkins senses . At one of these times [he]66-mr. wilkins must have written a half - finished pencil note , which [[his]66-mr. wilkins nurse]1694-his nurse found under [his]66-mr. wilkins pillow after [his]66-mr. wilkins death , and brought to [Ellinor]73-ellinor . Through [her]73-ellinor tear - blinded eyes [she]73-ellinor read the weak , faltering words : " [I]73-ellinor am very ill . [I]73-ellinor sometimes think [I]73-ellinor shall never get better , so [I]73-ellinor wish to ask [your]73-ellinor pardon for what [I]73-ellinor said the night before [I]73-ellinor was taken ill . [I]73-ellinor am afraid [my]73-ellinor anger made mischief between [you]73-ellinor and [Ellinor]73-ellinor , but [I]73-ellinor think [you]73-ellinor will forgive [a dying man]2965-a dying man . If [you]73-ellinor will come back and let all be as it used to be , [I]73-ellinor will make any apology [you]73-ellinor may require . If [I]73-ellinor go , [she]73-ellinor will be so very friendless ; and [I]73-ellinor have looked to [you]73-ellinor to care for [her]73-ellinor ever since [you]73-ellinor first-- "[73-ellinor] Then came some illegible and incoherent writing , ending with , " From [my]73-ellinor deathbed [I]73-ellinor adjure [you]73-ellinor to stand [[her]73-ellinor friend]2966-her friend ; [I]73-ellinor will beg pardon on [my]73-ellinor knees for anything-- "[73-ellinor] And there strength had failed ; the paper and pencil had been laid aside to be resumed at some time when the brain was clearer , the hand stronger . [Ellinor]73-ellinor kissed the letter , reverently folded it up , and laid it among [her]73-ellinor sacred treasures , by [[her]73-ellinor mother]458-her mother 's half - finished sewing , and a little curl of [[her]73-ellinor baby sister]485-her baby sister 's golden hair . [Mr. Johnson]143-mr. johnson , who had been [one of [the trustees for [Mrs. Wilkins]144-mrs. wilkins 's marriage settlement]1698-the trustees for mrs. wilkins 's marriage settlement]1697-one of the trustees for mrs. wilkins 's marriage settlement , [a respectable solicitor in [the county town]211-the county town]1699-a respectable solicitor in the county town , and [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness , had been appointed executors of [his]143-mr. johnson will , and [[guardians]1701-guardians to [Ellinor]73-ellinor]1702-guardians to ellinor . The will itself had been made several years before , when [he]143-mr. johnson imagined [himself]143-mr. johnson [the possessor of a handsome fortune , the bulk of which [he]143-mr. johnson bequeathed to [[his]143-mr. johnson only child]899-his only child]1703-the possessor of a handsome fortune , the bulk of which he bequeathed to his only child . By [[her]899-his only child mother]458-her mother 's marriage - settlement , [Ford Bank]15-ford bank was held in trust for [the children of the marriage]1706-the children of the marriage ; [the trustees]1707-the trustees being [Sir Frank Holster]68-sir frank holster and [Mr. Johnson]143-mr. johnson . There were legacies to [[his]143-mr. johnson executors]1708-his executors ; a small annuity to [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , with the expression of a hope that it might be arranged for [her]77-miss monro to continue living with [Ellinor]73-ellinor as long as [the latter remained unmarried]1709-the latter remained unmarried ; all [[his]143-mr. johnson servants]1710-his servants were remembered , [Dixon]86-dixon especially , and most liberally . What remained of the handsome fortune once possessed by [the testator]1711-the testator ? [The executors]1712-the executors asked in vain ; there was nothing . [They]1712-the executors could hardly make out what had become of it , in such utter confusion were all the accounts , both personal and official . [Mr. Johnson]143-mr. johnson was hardly restrained by [his]143-mr. johnson compassion for [the orphan]1713-the orphan from throwing up the executorship in disgust . [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness roused [himself]80-mr. ness from [his]80-mr. ness scholarlike abstraction to labour at the examination of books , parchments , and papers , for [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's sake . [Sir Frank Holster]68-sir frank holster professed [himself]68-sir frank holster only [a trustee for [Ford Bank]15-ford bank]1714-a trustee for ford bank . Meanwhile [she]77-miss monro went on living at [Ford Bank]15-ford bank , quite unconscious of the state of [[her]77-miss monro father]398-her father 's affairs , but sunk into a deep , plaintive melancholy , which affected [her]77-miss monro looks and the tones of [her]77-miss monro voice in such a manner as to distress [Miss Monro]77-miss monro exceedingly . It was not that [the good lady]1716-the good lady did not quite acknowledge the great cause [[her]1716-the good lady pupil]1717-her pupil had for grieving -- deserted by [[her]77-miss monro lover]890-her lover , [[her]77-miss monro father]398-her father dead -- but that [she]1716-the good lady could not bear the outward signs of how much these sorrows had told on [Ellinor]73-ellinor . [Her]1716-the good lady love for [the poor girl]1058-the poor girl was infinitely distressed by seeing the daily wasting away , the constant heavy depression of spirits , and [she]1716-the good lady grew impatient of the continual pain of sympathy . If [Miss Monro]77-miss monro could have done something to relieve [Ellinor]73-ellinor of [her]1716-the good lady woe , [she]1716-the good lady would have been less inclined to scold [her]1716-the good lady for giving way to it . The time came when [Miss Monro]77-miss monro could act ; and after that , there was no more irritation on [her]1716-the good lady part . When all hope of [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's having anything beyond [the house and grounds of [Ford Bank]15-ford bank]1721-the house and grounds of ford bank was gone ; when it was proved that all the legacies bequeathed by [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins not one farthing could ever be paid ; when it came to be a question how far the beautiful pictures and other objects of art in [the house]761-the house were not legally the property of [unsatisfied creditors]1723-unsatisfied creditors , the state of [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's affairs was communicated to [Ellinor]73-ellinor as delicately as [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness knew how . [She]73-ellinor was drooping over [her]73-ellinor work -- [she]73-ellinor always drooped now -- and [she]73-ellinor left off sewing to listen to [him]80-mr. ness , leaning [her]73-ellinor head on the arm which rested on the table . [She]73-ellinor did not speak when [he]80-mr. ness had ended [his]80-mr. ness statement . [She]73-ellinor was silent for whole minutes afterwards ; [he]80-mr. ness went on speaking out of very agitation and awkwardness . " It was all [the rascal Dunster]84-mr. dunster 's doing , [I]80-mr. ness 've no doubt , "[80-mr. ness] said [he]80-mr. ness , trying to account for the entire loss of [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's fortune . "[73-ellinor] " [[My]73-ellinor dear]2732-my dear [Ellinor]73-ellinor , there can be no doubt about it . " [God]119-god forgive [us]2969-we all , "[73-ellinor] [she]73-ellinor said , and relapsed into the old unbearable silence . [You]73-ellinor will have the rent of [this house]2805-this house , and [we]2969-we have a very good offer for [it]2805-this house -- [a tenant]2973-a tenant on lease of seven years at a hundred and twenty pounds a year-- "[73-ellinor] " [I]73-ellinor will never let [this house]2805-this house , "[73-ellinor] said [she]73-ellinor , standing up suddenly , and as if defying [him]80-mr. ness . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro loved [[her]77-miss monro pupil]1717-her pupil so dearly , that , if [her]77-miss monro own pleasure only were to be consulted , this projected life would be more agreeable to [her]77-miss monro than if [Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's legacy had set [her]77-miss monro in independence , with [Ellinor]73-ellinor away from [her]77-miss monro , married , and with interests in which [[her]77-miss monro former governess]1739-her former governess had but little part . " [I]1749-i know how sad it is , but , oh ! remember how [I]1749-i shall want [a friend]2793-a friend when [you]3009-missy 're gone , to advise [me]1749-i as [you]3009-missy have done to - day . [You]3009-missy 're not feeling ill , [Dixon]86-dixon , are [you]3009-missy ? "[1749-i] [she]1749-i continued , anxiously . " No ! [I]1749-i 'm hearty enough , and likely for t ' live . [Father]146-father was eighty - one , and [mother above the seventies]3022-mother above the seventies , when [they]1750-they died . It 's only [my]1749-i heart as is got to feel so heavy ; and as for that matter , so is [yours]3009-missy , [I]1749-i 'll be bound . And it 's a comfort to [us]1750-they both if [we]1750-they can serve [him]86-dixon as is dead by any care of [ours]1750-they , for [he]86-dixon were such [a bright handsome lad]3023-a bright handsome lad , with such a cheery face , as never should ha ' known shame . "[1749-i] [They]1750-they rode on without much more speaking . [Ellinor]73-ellinor was silently planning for [Dixon]86-dixon , and [he]86-dixon , not caring to look forward to the future , was bringing up before [his]86-dixon fancy the time , thirty years ago , when [he]86-dixon had first entered [the elder Mr. Wilkins]66-mr. wilkins 's service as [stable - lad]1751-stable - lad , and [pretty Molly]147-pretty molly , [the scullery - maid]1752-the scullery - maid , was [his]86-dixon daily delight . [Pretty Molly]147-pretty molly lay buried in [Hamley churchyard]1753-hamley churchyard , and [few living]1754-few living , except [Dixon]86-dixon , could have gone straight to [her]147-pretty molly grave . [CHAPTER XI]35-chapter xi . In a few days [Miss Monro]77-miss monro obtained a most satisfactory reply to [her]77-miss monro letter of inquiries as to whether [a daily governess]1755-a daily governess could find employment in [East Chester]33-east chester . For once the application seemed to have come just at the right time . [The canons]1756-the canons were [most of [them]1756-the canons married men , with [young families]1758-young families]1757-most of them married men , with young families ; [those at present in residence]1759-those at present in residence welcomed the idea of such instruction as [Miss Monro]77-miss monro could offer for [[their]1759-those at present in residence children]1760-their children , and could almost answer for [[their]1759-those at present in residence successors]1761-their successors in office . This was a great step gained . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , [the daughter of [a precentor to this very cathedral]1763-a precentor to this very cathedral]1762-the daughter of a precentor to this very cathedral , had a secret unwillingness to being engaged as [a teacher]1764-a teacher by [any wealthy tradesman there]1765-any wealthy tradesman there ; but to be received into [[the canons]1756-the canons ' families]1767-the canons ' families , in almost any capacity , was like going [home]230-home . Moreover , besides the empty honour of the thing , there were many small pieces of patronage in the gift of [the Chapter]1769-the chapter -- such as [a small house opening on to [the Close]1771-the close , which had formerly belonged to [the verger]1772-the verger , but which was now vacant , and was offered to [Miss Monro]77-miss monro at a nominal rent]1770-a small house opening on to the close , which had formerly belonged to the verger , but which was now vacant , and was offered to miss monro at a nominal rent . [Ellinor]73-ellinor had once more sunk into [her]73-ellinor old depressed passive state ; [Mr. Ness]80-mr. ness and [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , modest and undecided as [they]1759-those at present in residence both were in general , had to fix and arrange everything for [her]73-ellinor . [Her]73-ellinor great interest seemed to be in [the old servant [Dixon]86-dixon]1773-the old servant dixon , and [her]73-ellinor great pleasure to lie in seeing [him]86-dixon , and talking over old times ; so [[her]73-ellinor two friends]1774-her two friends talked about [her]73-ellinor , little knowing what a bitter , stinging pain [her]73-ellinor " pleasure "[73-ellinor] was . In vain [Ellinor]73-ellinor tried to plan how [they]1774-her two friends could take [Dixon]86-dixon with [them]1774-her two friends to [East Chester]33-east chester . If [he]86-dixon had been [a woman]585-a woman it would have been a feasible step ; but [they]1774-her two friends were only to keep [one servant]1776-one servant , and [Dixon]86-dixon , capable and versatile as [he]86-dixon was , would not do for [that servant]1777-that servant . All this was what passed through [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's mind : it is still a question whether [Dixon]86-dixon would have felt [his]86-dixon love of [[his]86-dixon native place]1778-his native place , with all its associations and remembrances , or [his]86-dixon love for [Ellinor]73-ellinor , the stronger . But [he]86-dixon was not put to the proof ; [he]86-dixon was only told that [he]86-dixon must leave , and seeing [Ellinor]73-ellinor 's extreme grief at the idea of [their]1774-her two friends separation , [he]86-dixon set [himself]86-dixon to comfort [her]73-ellinor by every means in [his]86-dixon power , reminding [her]73-ellinor , with tender choice of words , how necessary it was that [he]86-dixon should remain on the spot , in [Mr. Osbaldistone]145-mr. osbaldistone 's service , in order to frustrate , by any small influence [he]86-dixon might have , every project of alteration in [the garden that contained the dreadful secret]1779-the garden that contained the dreadful secret . [He]86-dixon persisted in this view , though [Ellinor]73-ellinor repeated , with pertinacious anxiety , the care which [Mr. Johnson]143-mr. johnson had taken , in drawing up the lease , to provide against any change or alteration being made in the present disposition of [the house]761-the house or [grounds]1781-grounds . [People in general]1782-people in general were rather astonished at the eagerness [Miss Wilkins]106-miss wilkins showed to sell all the [Ford Bank]15-ford bank furniture . Even [Miss Monro]77-miss monro was a little scandalized at this want of sentiment , although [she]77-miss monro said nothing about it ; indeed justified the step , by telling [every one]497-every one how wisely [Ellinor]73-ellinor was acting , as the large , handsome , tables and chairs would be very much out of place and keeping with [the small , oddly - shaped rooms of [[their]1785-their future home in [East Chester Close]36-east chester close]1786-their future home in east chester close]1784-the small , oddly - shaped rooms of their future home in east chester close . [None]1787-none knew how strong was the instinct of self - preservation , it may almost be called , which impelled [Ellinor]73-ellinor to shake off , at any cost of present pain , the incubus of a terrible remembrance . [She]73-ellinor wanted to go into [an unhaunted dwelling in [a free , unknown country]1789-a free , unknown country]1788-an unhaunted dwelling in a free , unknown country -- [she]73-ellinor felt as if it was [her]73-ellinor only chance of sanity . Sometimes [she]73-ellinor thought [her]73-ellinor senses would not hold together till the time when all these arrangements were ended . But [she]73-ellinor did not speak to [any one]616-any one about [her]73-ellinor feelings , [poor child]728-poor child ; to whom could [she]73-ellinor speak on the subject but to [Dixon]86-dixon ? Nor did [she]73-ellinor define them to [herself]73-ellinor . All [she]73-ellinor knew was , that [she]73-ellinor was as nearly going mad as possible ; and if [she]73-ellinor did , [she]73-ellinor feared that [she]73-ellinor might betray [[her]73-ellinor father]398-her father 's guilt . All this time [she]73-ellinor never cried , or varied from [her]73-ellinor dull , passive demeanour . And [they]1793-they were blessed tears of relief that [she]73-ellinor shed when [Miss Monro]77-miss monro , [herself]77-miss monro weeping bitterly , told [her]73-ellinor to put [her]73-ellinor head out of the post - chaise window , for at the next turning of [the road]1794-the road [they]1795-they would catch the last glimpse of [Hamley church]27-hamley church spire . Late one October evening , [Ellinor]73-ellinor had [her]73-ellinor first sight of [East Chester Close]36-east chester close , where [she]73-ellinor was to pass the remainder of [her]73-ellinor life . [Miss Monro]77-miss monro had been backwards and forwards between [Hamley]1-hamley and [East Chester]33-east chester more than once , while [Ellinor]73-ellinor remained at [the parsonage]581-the parsonage ; so [she]73-ellinor had not only the pride of proprietorship in [the whole of [the beautiful city]1798-the beautiful city]1797-the whole of the beautiful city , but something of the desire of hospitably welcoming [Ellinor]73-ellinor to [[their]1795-they joint future home]1799-their joint future home . " Look ! the fly must take [us]1795-they a long round , because of [our]1795-they luggage ; but behind these high old walls are [[the canons]1756-the canons ' gardens]3025-the canons ' gardens . That high - pitched roof , with the clumps of stonecrop on the walls near it , is [Canon Wilson]148-canon wilson 's , whose [four little girls [I]73-ellinor am to teach]3026-four little girls i am to teach . Hark ! the great cathedral clock . How proud [I]73-ellinor used to be of [its]148-canon wilson great boom when [I]73-ellinor was [a child]584-a child ! [I]73-ellinor thought [all the other church clocks in [the town]277-the town]3028-all the other church clocks in the town sounded so shrill and poor after that , which [I]73-ellinor considered mine especially . [They]3033-they say the rook is a very long - lived bird , and [I]73-ellinor feel as if [I]73-ellinor could swear to the way [they]3033-they are cawing . "[73-ellinor] It was a mere slip of [a house]1801-a house ; [the kitchen]750-the kitchen being wisely placed close to the front - door , and so reserving the pretty view for [the little dining- room]1803-the little dining- room , out of which a glass - door opened into [a small walled - in garden]1804-a small walled - in garden , which had again an entrance into [the Close]37-the close . [East Chester Cathedral]38-east chester cathedral is [Norman]39-norman , with a low , massive tower , a grand , majestic nave , and [a choir full of stately historic tombs]1813-a choir full of stately historic tombs . [The whole city]1814-the whole city is so quiet and decorous [a place]1815-a place , that the perpetual daily chants and hymns of praise seemed to sound far and wide over the roofs of [the houses]1816-the houses . [Ellinor]73-ellinor soon became [a regular attendant]1817-a regular attendant at all the morning and evening services . The sense of worship calmed and soothed [her]73-ellinor aching weary heart , and to be punctual to the cathedral hours [she]73-ellinor roused and exerted [herself]73-ellinor , when probably nothing else would have been sufficient to this end . [A clergyman from [a distant county]555-a distant county]1892-a clergyman from a distant county was appointed , and [all the Close]1894-all the close was astir to learn and hear every particular connected with [him]1892-a clergyman from a distant county .
